reviewText: Warning: If you don't want spoiled, STAY AWAY!Thank you :-D.OMG, You have GOT to see this movie!!!Johnny Depp's odd take on Wonka has him with pale skin, antisocial/kid-like behavior, weird haircut... he's creepy, but unlike Gene Wilder's portayal *no offense to fans of his* it doesn't want to make me hurl or run for cover.And well let's face it, if you were cooped up in a chocolate factory and out of touch with you family and the outside world PLUS if you were picked on as a kid *as I suspect Mr. Wonka probly was) you WOULD be a tad offbeat.I don't really see how Depp! Wonka looks like Michael Jackson, aside from the pael complexion. And people comparing when he invited JUST Charlie to the factory in the movie to MJ's molestation trial... NOBODY PLANNED THAT WHEN THEY WROTE THE SCRIPT SO DROP IT!!!! *deep breath* Okay then...This adaptation is much more faithful to Roald Dahl's characters then the original. Not as many liberties were taken with the plot. *With the exception of some flashback's of Wonka dentist dad/childhood... nice touch I thought :), gives Willy and his behavior a bit more depth* Plus with all the new technology (and a bigger budget didn't hurt), they were able to make things seem a bit more real for Wonka's marvelous world (not to mention no orange faced-green haired oompa loompas).OMG the music!!! Danny Elfman did a spectacular job with the arrangements! These songs stay in your heard long after the movie is over *a good thing* The Oompa Loompas songs about the four brats are exceptionally well-done and they used Dahl's own words (in the original they probly cut some to save time I imagine and to get the point faster)... my favorites of those were the 'Mike Teavee' and 'Violet Beaureguarde (sp?)' tracks.The cast... their acting was so wonderful. Helena Bonham Carter and Noah Taylor did a great job Charlie's Mum and Dad, Freddie Highmore was perfect for the role of Charlie.. nice, quiet, and looked poor unlike the last boy who played him (again no offense to fans of the original cast). Everyone had great chemistry and put so much heart into their roles.They updated a couple things, Mike being obsessed with Video games instead of just TV programs and Violet/Her Mother being very competitive but it fit the story.Only complaint I had at the end was that Augustus wasn't skinny after going up the pipe, still his fat self.. but only a minor nitpick in such an amazing movie.I can't recommend this movie enough (seen it 5 times already :-D)... definitely a must-see, totally worth your time. I betcha this will sell out VERY quickly once it's released on DVD (hopefully before Black Friday). Johnny's take on Willy is so delicious! You wanna hug this poor guy and take him home lol.If they decide to film 'Charlie and the Great Glass Elevator', I hope: Johnny and everyone comes back for it and John August does the screenplay again *MAGNIFICENT JOB* Tim Burton already said he wouldn't direct the sequel so I hope it's put in capable hands. Though, when/if they decide to do this movie, it probly won't be for a few years (as Johnny's got a few other projects lined up lol, didn't check on the rest yet).Well, what are you waiting for?! Go see it! *waves bye*AuroraP.S. Yes I know I'm 'pathetic' *rolls eyes* Does it look like I care? *raises eyebrows* :-P.ignore any typos please lol
summary: WILLY WONKA, WILL WONKA.. THE AMAZING CHOCOLATIER!

reviewText: I finally got around to seeing Tim Burton's remake of Roald Dahl's "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory". As much as I love the 1971 version "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" starring Gene Wilder, I thought this new version was just as good. Johnny Depp as the eccentric, mysterious Willy Wonka was hilarious. I definitely could see the Michael Jackson comparisons in the way Willy Wonka spoke and attitude. "Finding Neverland" co-star Freddie Highmore once again co-starred with Johnny Depp as the good-hearted Charlie, and was a delight to watch. Given his recent film roles, Freddie Highmore is going to be around in the film business for a  long time (I hope). He truly embodied the goodness and innocence in his character Charlie. The scenery in the candy factory was pure visual candy. It was stunning especially with the river of chocolate. I loved the oompah loompahs. Their musical numbers were hilarious although they did tend to drag on a bit which was one of the few flaws I found with the film. The flashbacks were interesting but again annoying. Then again they did serve its purpose and gave the viewer a glimpse into Willy Wonka's childhood. Christopher Lee was excellent as Willy's father with his deep, forboding voice. I loved it when the not-so nice children got their comeuppance especially Veruca Salt and the squirrels scene. Despite the minor flaws, Tim Burton did a fantastic job with his modern take on "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory".

reviewText: In the world of movie remakes, you never know what you get.  Sometimes you get a "Psycho" style remake, a movie so like the original you are suprised someone ever produced it.  Other times, though, things work out.  You get a movie that is just as good or better than the orginal.  With this in mind, I can honestly say that Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is an excellent film.The film approaches the novel from a different direction than the movie.  Its producers claim this movie "follows the original story" closer than the first movie.  There are differences.  Willy Wonka is made into a three-dimensional character, we see the circumstances that led to his obsession with candy, how he meant the Oompa Loompas (now played by a single actor, the famous Deep Roy, multiplied a million times over via computer animation).  Charlie may be the same, but he now has a father as well as a mother and his home gives the phrase "fixer upper" new meaning.The film progresses much as the original did, but again there are differences.  The Oompa Loompa song and dance numbers are more lively, the feeling of the film more positive, the greatest suprise is a plot twist when Charlie - but I will not tell.All in all, I give this movie a definite thumbs up.  I liked the first, but I really like the seond!!!WHO CAN TAKE THE SUNSHINE.....

reviewText: Sometimes movies surprise you.  For some reason, every time Johnny Depp is in a movie, it's one of those surprising ones, at least for me.  I thought "Pirates of the Caribbean" was going to flop (A movie based on a ride?  C'mon!), but we all know how successful that was.  And I thought "Secret Window" would be a tense thriller, but it turned out to be a predictable snoozer.  And once again, Johnny Depp has surprised me:  starring in a not-too-shabby film version of "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory", not to be confused with the 1971 musical film "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory".  Same story, but an utterly different experience.First of all, this film is directed by Tim Burton, known for darker, edgier films, which is just fine because the original book, written by Roald Dahl (also known for "James and the Giant Peach" and "Matilda") is dark and edgy too, at least for a children's book.Willy Wonka (Johnny Depp), a very eccentric candy maker who runs a secretive and mysterious factory, plants five golden tickets in the wrappers of his chocolate bars, and the five lucky children who find them are invited to see his bizarre hideaway.All the children are perfect stereotypes of various kinds of kids:  There's the gluttonous one, the bratty one, the competitive one, the critical one, and, most importantly, the wholesome one, Charlie (Freddie Highmore).  It may seem pretty simplistic to have all of these characters so cut-and-dried, but Dahl's work tends toward stereotypical characters that are easy to identify.  One must remember that no matter how creepy it may seem, this is, at the end of the day, based on a children's book.And at times, it is a bit creepy.  Willy Wonka, with his pale face, strange hair, and high-pitched voice bears a frightening resemblance to Michael Jackson.  But the resemblance isn't so over-powering that you feel uncomfortable with the fact that he's in his "neverland" with these kids, and I got the impression that Willy Wonka is the person Michael Jackson tries to emulate, rather than the other way around.Wonka himself is very much like a child, with giddy naveté and an almost bratty quality to him.  Through the course of the film, as the various bad stereotypes learn their lessons, Willy discovers he has a thing or two to learn as well.I must admit I have not seen the old musical, and know of it only by reputation, so I cannot fairly compare the two films.  However, I will say that this rendition has a fair amount of musical numbers, which start off as quite a surprise but soon become quite predictable.Despite sparkling with Johnny Depp-flavored wit and Roald Dahl's beloved story, "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is blemished by Tim Burton's spooky touch, somehow managing to feel eerie even when it should be lighter.

reviewText: Oh, Tim Burton, I never lost my faith in you. After Burton's output significantly slowed down during the late '90s, some wondered if his best years were behind him. Then Burton follows up his excellent 1999 pic Sleepy Hollow with a dreadful remake of the sci-fi classic, Planet of the Apes. Oh dear. Will we never see another Burtonian masterpiece? Will we never be blessed with another imaginative fairytale like Edward Scissorhands? Or an oddball biopic like Ed Wood? Or a dark comic tale like Batman Returns? Well, perhaps the failure of Planet of the Apes shook Burton back to his senses. He returned, as if from a sabbatical in the depths of the Batcave, in 2003 with a fabulous movie called Big Fish. Ah yes, this is the Tim Burton that we love. Now in 2005 we have two new Burton flicks to savor. Corpse Bride, another stop-motion triumph marrying Burton's macabre characters with Edgar Allan Poe sensibilities, and of course, a live action marvel of a movie: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. Tim Burton is back with a vengeance!!Now while I loved Big Fish, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is without a doubt Burton's best movie in a decade. It's all here - everything that we love about Tim Burton as a storyteller. All of his trademarks, the creepy, kooky, mysterious and spooky, are all here in abundance. Roald Dahl's classic book was begging for a Burtonization. Why did no one think of this sooner? Johnny Depp takes the role of the mysterious candy maker Willy Wonka, in what is sure to be a controversial performance among fans. I thought he was great. He does not attempt to recapture Gene Wilder's Wonka in any way. Depp recreates the character as his own. Tim Burton also found a perfect Charlie in Freddie Highmore. As the key character in the movie, Highmore's Charlie is always believable and sympathetic. David Kelly is simply a delight as Grandpa Joe. I also loved Deep Roy's performance(s) as the Oompa Loompas. I love that Burton went in a completely different direction and didn't try to copy the Oompa Loompas of the 1971 film. Burton's Oompa Loompas are far more fun and imaginative.You've also got marvelous production design and Tim Burton's visual genius which bring to life Roald Dahl's world in a way that we've never imagined. This movie simply looks splendid. Scrumdiddlyumptious, if you will. The production design and art direction should certainly get Oscar nominations next February. Then we have Danny Elfman's excellent music. Just what would a Tim Burton movie be without a Danny Elfman score? As always, Elfman captures the perfect tone for this wild, fantastic world. One of the best additions to this movie is the subplot featuring the great Christopher Lee as Willy Wonka's father. That's exactly what the story needed, a bit more dramatic depth and some additional characterization for Wonka.Fans of the 1971 Gene Wilder version will certainly have much to debate upon seeing this new movie. I personally feel that this movie far surpasses the 1971 movie. I am a big fan of the old one, yes, but I always felt that Gene Wilder's excellent performance stood head and shoulders above the rest of the movie. Peter Ostrum's Charlie was less compelling than he should have been and none of the other characters were particularly fleshed out enough for me to care about them. I did love the movie's sense of dark humor, but as a whole I felt it was a flawed as a story. However, in comparison, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is practically flawless. I honestly loved everything about this movie. There is not one complaint or quibble I have with it. This is quite simply everything I could have wished for in a Tim Burton take on Roald Dahl's story. Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is a Tim Burton masterpiece. His best movie since 1994's Ed Wood and one of the best movies of 2005.

reviewText: When I first heard that they were doing a remake I was totally shocked and worried. Gene Wilder did such a good job that I was reluctant to go see this one. But, as soon as I heard that Johnny Depp was playing Wonka and that Tim Burton was directing all my worries just dirfted away. What I like about this one is that it's not exactly the same as the original. After watching the other one a million times . . . I was expecting something different. The sets were real, people. No CGI there. The acting was hilarious and all the characters gave something different to the remake. But, however possible, in this one, Wonka slightly takes on a creepier tone. Gene wilder was playful, but in this one, Wonka almost has a glimmer of sadism in his eyes. Watch the Sqirrel scene, you'll see what I'm talking about. Anyhow, the misfortunes of the children were very funny and gave me back the memories from before. The only thing that I really didn't like were two very distinctive things:One, the oompa loompas were totally wrong. All of them looked depressed or just plain angry. Not like the orange-faced goof balls in the last one.Two, the songs were not as pleasing. They say that the songs were taken straight from the book. The whole movie, in fact is based soley on the book, give or take a few scenes, while the original was made with a genrally understanding of the book. But, all in all, the 1974 WILLY WONKA AND THE CHOCOLATE FACOTRY still does better at the songs. That's my opinion. But the movie still is enjoyable.Final Verdict: The Shananigans are back.Enjoy!

reviewText: Initially, I was one of the skeptical people who wondered why remake such as classic film? I love Johnny Depp and the book so I saw the film. It was wonderful. Not to take anything from the Gene Wilder version, which is also wonderful. This film is much more like the book. The songs are straight from the book. I particularly liked the Veruca Salt scene with the squirrels, which was not possible with the technology in the original. You really can't compare the two films. They are each beautiful in their own way. I loved the original, but I also loved this version. It was well acted and the scenery, everything, was incredible. I loved seening Willy Wonka in Oompa Loompa land making the deal with the chief. My students love this book and this version goes along with the book much more accurately. I feel that Roald Dahl would have loved this version. Johnny took a another character and made it his own. Wonderful job.

reviewText: Come one come all to Willie Wonkas's house of horrors. And kids, don't take candy from strangers especially if it's chocolate from the Wonka factory.  Willie's running the old bait and switch here. You may think possession of the Golden Ticket will allow you entrance to chocolate nirvana where you'll get what you desire but oops...joke's on you kid. Mr. Wonka's going to give you what he thinks you deserve. All odious brats better run for your lives. And yes that goes for the audience too. I admit I hate the story and think it's mean spirited and sadistic. But I went to see the movie because of the collaboration of Johnny Depp and Tim Burton who take an artistic vision and run with it in a quirky interesting way. And true to form the film is a Burton world of the fantastic, a huge mesmerizing storybook reality taking place in another dimension.  This time you are grateful to leave at the end and put it back on the shelf. Burton has attempted to give Wonka some humanity by inserting a "back story" not part of Dahl's original book.  Wonka's present life is intermittently tormented by flashbacks of his childhood of abuse and cruelty at the hands of his father.  Does this make Wonka more sympathetic? No. Depp always a brilliantly inventive actor wasn't able to make me like this character in any way shape or form. I know this is supposed to be a children's movie but it's misanthropy makes it one that not every kid or adult will enjoy. I was not amused.

reviewText: I really liked this movie.  I liked the Tim Burton trademark on it.  I loved the look of Johnny Depp.  I'm still not happy when people compare him to Michael Jackson, though. Where did that come from!? Still, I think the original movie is better for one reason.  It has to do with the character of Willy Wonka and I am not talking about the acting ability of Johnny Depp compared with Gene Wilder. Both of them are great actors!  But, the Gene Wilder Willy Wonka was definitely a morally better character than the Johnny Depp version.  The Johnny Depp Willy Wonka had some serious problems himself.  The back story of Willy Wonka in the new movie has nothing to do with the book and I believe there is a good chance that Roald Dahl would likely have objected to it.  (Note that he was on the set of the first movie.) I think it all combines to make the Johnny Depp character appear to be more of a "psychotic" Willy Wonka, especially when compared to the "eccentric" character of the book and the Wilder movie.  The moral high ground that the Gene Wilder character seems to have, makes it seem more natural that he has the authority and right to teach the kids and parents their lessons.  That being said, the new movie is otherwise a bit truer to the original story.  The advance of special effects allows them do some things that they couldn't do in the older movie. Moreover, the older movie looks dated, especially the scene of his mother working in the laundry.  My suggestion is to watch both movies.  On top of everything, don't forget to read the book.  It's a wonderful story.

reviewText: First off, the movie is more of a drama than a comedy. I was hoping to be laughing at Johnny Depp's comments, but was dumbfounded.The movie begins with Wonka closing the factory and years later reopening the factory to the public. Unfortunately, only 5 lucky children will be allowed to enter. We have kids from different parts of the world winning including Charlie, who is lives in a run down cottage but has his family. The group is given a tour of the factory by the eccentric, but disturbed Wonka. Johnny Depp is a little too weird as oppose to Gene Wilder's sacastic, but lovable Wonka. This new Wonka is too strange and I don't think I'd feel comfortable with him giving me a tour. On the other hand, the factory itself is so imaginative and truly represents Burton's strange mind. The Oompa Loopa's is played by one person and the songs, clearly by Danny Elfman, sounds like he can't change his 80s new wave sound. In addition, it was hard to hear the lyrics, therefore the lesson to be learned was hard to understand.The relationship of family is explored throughout the movie from Charlie's relationship to his family and Wonka's relationship to his father. The movie seems to be Tim Burton's way of teaching children the dangers of overindulgence and love of family. Unfortunately, the movie, although imaginative, was not very entertaining. I was hoping for more, especially with the combo of Tim Burton and Johnny Depp, but was left disappointed.

reviewText: I absolutely loved this movie. It has reminded me why the original film was so special. Even though the original will always be a classic, in some ways, I almost think that this movie surpassed the original. For example, it actually showed more than the original film. In the original "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory", it is only mentioned how the Oompa Loompas came to work in the factory. But in "Charlie", you actually see Wonka go to their home country and find out why they are even working for him. Another interesting thing about this movie is that we get to see into the life of a young Willy Wonka when he was just a child; he has been emotionally scarred by his strict father who never allowed him to eat chocolate or any other candy because his dad was a dentist.The scenery for this film is amazing. From the snow covered city, to the candy room in the factory, it was very beautiful and set the perfect mood for the story. Tim Burton in a recent interview said that it is real chocolate that you see coming down the waterfall, no fake stuff. All in all, it is very wonderful eye candy.As my brother, who was with me mentioned, it was amazing how well the young actors in this film did. Very talented and eerily resembling the actors who were in the original film. The person who was Charlie in the film did an excellent job, and so did the person who played his grandfather. Johnny Depp is the perfect choice for Wonka. Wonka comes off as a big kid and Depp played it brilliantly. He is just what you see on the TV commercials, a very cool character that made the movie even more interesting.The music was very catchy, with each new person that was eliminated from the contest; the Oompa Loompas changed the music entirely for each one. These songs had me tapping my toes at many parts, it has inspired me to go out and buy the soundtrack, and I did. And the classical scores by Danny Elfman were fantastic as well, he is sure to be the next John Williams. His music help set the mood during the opening credits when the chocolate bars are shown being made.Overall, this film is everything I had hoped it would be. This has become my favorite Burton film. The entire time, I can't remember when a smile wasn't literally on my face; it was just like being a kid again watching the original for the first time, even though in some ways the stories are completely different, this movie being closer to the book than the original. This is probably the funniest time I've had in the theater this summer and it was just as enjoyable on the DVD. On a pure enjoyment factor, this movie is tops. What's not to like? It's a feel good movie that touches the inner child in us and leaves you feeling good by the end. If you miss this movie and don't buy it, you are missing something huge.First, when mentioning the special features, I first have to mention the menu screens. Excellently done, each different menu stared Deep Roy as an Oompa Loompa and each screen he is always doing something different. A lot of time was put into just the menu screen; it's nice to know so much care was put into that alone. It was also nice to see Deep Roy do this for us DVD viewers, he is always entertaining.  Now to the special features:Attack of the Squirrels- This is a short making of that shows that these squirrels weren't the easiest actors to work with. It is amazing how much of what we see on the film, not all, was done by real squirrels. We also get a look at the CGI and mechanical squirrels. It's a very interesting look into all of this.The Fantastic Mr. Dahl- This is a touching look at the life of Mr. Roald Dahl, the author of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory among other novels. This documentary features Dahl's family and friends as their share stories of their lives living with the legend. It also features the family and friends reading excerpts from his various stories. At times, it is very touching to the point tears begin to form. This was a very loving tribute to the author who loved and understood children.Becoming Oompa Loompa- Deep Roy is probably the most talented actor of this film, and this is really shown when you see how much work he put into his performance as an Oompa Loompa. From learning the choreography to having to do the same moves time after time after time, when it's all finished, you find a new appreciation for Deep Roy as an actor.The Five Making of Featurretes- These small mini-documentaries go into detail about how the factory/music and so on was made. My favorite part being how the music was made since this movie has such a brilliant soundtrack.Challenges- These are mini-games that are lots of fun for any age. Oompa-Loompa Dance Machine being my favorite. In this game, you can watch how Deep Roy does the moves for the songs "Augustus Gloop" and "Violet Beauregarde" and you can watch and rewatch the steps to learn how to dance like an Oompa Loompa. Then the second part of the game is that when he is dancing, you can use your remote control and follow his dance moves with the remote. If you mess up, the Oompa Loompa will fall and you have to start over. Once you successfully do one dance, more moves are added and the game becomes more difficult. Real fun!Overall this DVD is excellent! A lot of time was put into it and I couldn't be happier.
summary: Second Favorite Movie Of The Year!!!!!!

reviewText: Though I am getting tired of this new trend of remaking old movies, I have to admit that this is one of the best movies I've seen in awhile. I typically do not even like Tim Burton's movies very much, but Charlie and the Chocolate Factory was definitely an exception. Some of the characters have been modified slightly from the book and original movie, but in a good way. Johnny Depp did an excellent job as Wonka, as did the boy who played Charlie. The score by Danny Elfman was superb.I think what made this movie so great was that it was not really an attempt to remake an old movie, but rather a new adaptation of the book. Now, it's probably been 20 years since I read the book by Roald Dahl, but I thought this movie stayed truer to the book than the original movie did, if memory serves me correctly. Of course, a separate side story about how Willy Wonka became a "chocolateer" was added. Correct me if I'm wrong, but I don't remember this aspect being in the original book.Overall, this is a great movie for the whole family to enjoy. The kid-friendly story, language, and characters combined with the comedy that even adults can enjoy make this a must-see for anyone.
summary: Forget That It's a Remake...Just Watch It!

reviewText: I adored the first movie and loved how Gene Wilder played Willy Wonka.  I wasn't sure at first about Johnny Depp's performance (even though I think JD is a genius), but it kind of grew on me and, eventually, I felt more sad for him than anything else.  Which made Charlie's redeeming of Willy Wonka all the more special in the end.  Charlie ended up with money/a future, but Willy Wonka ended up with affection/a family.  It all balanced out in the end, aka "life had never been sweeter."The special effects are eye-popping and the bright color scheme of the interior of the factory makes the dull colors of the world that Charlie lived in all the more distinctive.  Willy Wonka is decidely odd, a bit spooky, and even a touch cold at times, a much closer representation of the character in the book than the performance by Gene Wilder.  Neither movie comes close to how malicious he can seem in the book as he brings the "bad" children to their iconic dooms, though this second movie is nearer to the mark.The background story of Willy Wonka and his father don't add as much to the movie as they should and could possibly have been left out, though there is a sly humor in the idea that the world's greatest chocolatier came from such a strict dentist.  This is not the best of Tim Burton's movies, but I freely admit that my standards where he is concerned are quite high.  The songs were great and the visuals stunning, and the theme of the movie quite family-supportive.Overall, I would recommend owning both movies and showing the orginal to younger children and saving the later one for older children.
summary: Oddly Charming But Can Be Disturbing

reviewText: Last night's bargain-rack movie was "Charlie and The Chocolate Factory," a movie by Tim Burton and starring Johnny Depp. That says a lot doesn't it? Would you be expecting weird, or what? Remember, these guys have teamed up in "Edward Scissorhands" and "The Corpse Bride." Well, you can also add the music of Danny Elfman, former leader of "Oingo Boingo" fame. Strange, strange movie. Oh, and by the way, if you've ever had the experience of a "fixer-upper" house or have even considered it, viewing the "fixer-upper" in this movie is worth the admission or DVD price.In any case, the Willy Wonka Chocolate Factory, closed for some time with all the employees fired, has reopened and has offered a "Golden Ticket" to the first five people who find it inside five of their Willy Wonka Chocolate Bars sold on a world-wide basis. Their prize is a one-day all-you-can-eat tour of the new factory. The first four tickets were easy to find and, let's-just-say, they went to kids that you or Johnny Depp, the leader of the tour, would probably not care to spend a day with. The fifth kid, Charlie, came from an extended family who lived in the "fixer-upper" place and he was accompanied by his grandfather, a former laid-off worker in the old Willy Wonka Factory, who was suspected of giving away trade secrets in the old Willy Wonka days. Anyway, it's a weird tour. All the rivers, waterfalls, lakes and any other forms of water are liquid chocolate and the grass, flowers and anything else on the tour is one or another form of edible candy. Weird place. The elevators go up and down or sideways, depending on which way you want to go. The actors are all real (well, the lilleputian-sized people are an animation trick), but the factory, tour and everything else is one of these computer animation jobs, and it's clever and amusing. It's a fun, frivolous movie. Relax and enjoy.Gary Peterson
summary: Fun Frivolous Movie. Relax and Enjoy.

reviewText: It isn't a new thing to see Johnny Depp surrounded by chocolate (Chocolat), or for him to act for director Tim Burton (Edward Scissorhands, Ed Wood). Neither it is a new thing to make a film adaption of Roald Dahl's "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" (there's the 1971 version starring Gene Wilder). Still, in the previews it did look like it was going to be a treat. It wasn't as sweet as I'd hoped though.Charlie (Freddie Highmore) is a poor but good hearted child, and he, his parents, and his four grandparents, all live together in a crooked old house. Charlie's a creative child, he uses toothpaste tubes from his father's work to build a model chocolate factory. He wishes he could visit the town's real one, owned by the eccentric Willy Wonka (Johnny Depp).  Charlie's wish comes true when he finds a golden ticket in a chocolate bar, which invites him to the factory. Taking his Grampa Joe (David Kelly) with him, Charlie meets Willy and goes with him, along with four, less good natured children into the wonderous world of the factory. They'll discover a chocolate waterfall, three - course meal chewing gum, the Oompa - Loompas (all played by Deep Roy) and the incredible glass elevator.I like the design of the film, and I love the colour scheme. Its rich like chocolate. I remember seeing the posters a couple of months before the film came out: Augustus' blonde hair, powdery pink face and bright blue eyes, and it was really evocative. In some shots it almost has a colorized feel. I also like the look of the factory, the casting of the children (which I think was perfect) and the fact you get to see them after their comeuppance. I like the look of Depp's Wonka and for the most part, I like Depp's perfomance too. Reminded me a little of his performance as Ed Wood, in terms of enthusiasm, but more child-like and neurotic.However, I didn't like the more selfish side to Depp's character. He doesn't particularly like children or family for most of the film, and is rather impatient at times, and his friendliness is often forced. Gene Wilder's Wonka was a awe-inspiring but friendly, lonely man. Watching the 1971 version as a child, you wanted to go to the factory, not just to eat the amazing candies, but to meet the man. If I was a child now, I wouldn't know what to make of Depp's Wonka's selfish side. He doesn't really want anyone in his factory. He just wants to show it off! This is rather different from the book, which Tim Burton claims to be trying to be faithful to.Another difference from the book is an inclusion of a backstory to Willy Wonka. It turns out his father was ironically a rather intimidating dentist who wouldn't let him eat candy, played by none other than Christopher Lee, a man whose roles have included Dracula, Fu Manchu, Count Dooku, Sauruman and the voice of Discworld's Grim Reaper. Now I love Christopher Lee, I really, really do, but his appearance in this film seems to me to be just for appearance's sake, just because he's experiencing a resurgence of popularity after "Star Wars" and "Lord of the Rings".Due to the addition of this backstory, there are a series of flashbacks interdispersed throughout the film. The backstory is very Tim Burton. Willy is an outsider as a child, and with his mouth and head full of wires, he's kind of a freak. The flashbacks have a kind of "Edward Scissorhands" vibe. Though its not in the book, I can see Dahl making Wonka's father a dentist if he had felt like elaborating in that direction, and I wouldn't have minded this backstory so much if it hadn't been for the consequences it has on the ending, which I found disappointing.The Oompa Loompas annoyed me also. I like Deep Roy, but there was just too much (or should that be "too many") of him in this film. The songs, penned, pitch shifted and sung by Danny Elfman (with lyrics from the Roald Dahl poems of the original novel), irritated me for the most part too. Just kind of tacky sounding, I felt. I did like the Beatle-esque song for Veruca Salt's exit though.The DVD is very well put together, capturing the spacious, colourful, odd world of Wonka's chocolate factory within the menus. Special features on the DVD include a selection of featurettes, including one about the squirrels (live, animatronic and otherwise), one about Deep Roy and his role(s) as an Oompa-Loompa, as well as an interesting documentary on Roald Dahl. There are also a few games for the viewer to play, such as making your own candy concoction and getting the poor Oompa - Loompa to try it. You can get some pretty funny results. There is also a game called "Find the Golden Ticket" that involves playing each of the children, trying to get their golden ticket. Charlie's game is a point and click style of game where you have to find various odds and ends (like money for a chocolate bar). Veruca's game sees you sorting boxes. You get to feed Augustus in his game. Mike's game is probably the hardest. There is a tangle of highways, and you have to figure out which one the truck will go to. Once you beat all of these children's games, you are rewarded with an animatic (rough computer animated storyboard) of the "Augustus Gloop" song with all the Deep Roy Oompas. Some of those games were hard (particulary Mike's level), and I didn't think this animatic was much of a reward! With the first Harry Potter film, you get seven deleted scenes for completing the main menu game, and that game was a fair bit easier than this one!Speaking of games, if you have a DVD ROM drive on your PC, you will be treated to a demo of the "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" video game, which is kind of fun.It's all worth a look, but I definitely prefer 1971 film.
summary: Not As Sweet As I'd Hoped

reviewText: The original 1971 movie "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" is still the best version, especially since author Roald Dahl wrote the script.  Any deviations he made from his book must be okay because he allowed it to happen.In the original, Gene Wilder, captured the eccentricity of Willy Wonka with a bit of warmth and whimsy.  Johnny Depp captured Wonka's eccentricity in typical cooky Tim Burton fashion.  While Wilder's Wonka was no big fan of the four naughty brats, he was never mean to them, even when they learned their lessons the hard way.  The worthy child left standing would make himself known.  Depp's Wonka seemed as if he designed to elminate the ones he didn't like. That just bugged me. A man wanting to keep his vision alive with the right child shouldn't seem so hasty to produce a winner.Another flaw of the new version are the kids that were cast.  One exception is the role of Charlie.  I actually prefer Freddie Highmore.  The brats in the new movie were weaker versions of their original counterparts.  Varuca Salt is my favorite.  She truly was a loud, impatient and indignant spoiled brat.  The newer Varuca Salt didn't seem that bratty at all.  I mean, a band named themselves after her.  They wouldn't do so if she wasn't so memorable.  Even worse were the parents's reactions to their naughty children's mischeviousness.  In the original, the parents actually freaked out as concerned parents would.  In the newer version, the parents just idly watched, mouth agape, barely uttering a word as if they were just going with the flow.Boat scene in the new version:  LAME!  The original was far more memorable. It's the scene we all think of when we you mention "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory".Oompa Loompas in the original and their songs...better.  Enough said.Finally, what was the point of the flashbacks to Wonka's childhood?  Completely unncessary.Despite all that, the film exhibited true Tim Burton style and aesthetics. If it was only for those reasons, then the new version would have been a great film.  Otherwise, if you want the dreamy tale of a kid, a chocolatier and his factory, stick to the original.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The first third of this movie, where you meet poor little Charlie Bucket and his family in their dilipidated home, where they are so poor that his grandparents sleep in one bed by the fire, head to toe, is so nearly perfect and straight from the novel by Roald Dahl that I actually got tense as Charlie would open each candy bar and still not find that golden ticket. The disgusting children around the world finding those tickets were spot-on as well, including the best update whatsover in the movie, where Mike Teavee, who in the book dresses as a cowboy and shoots his toy gun at the TV screen, is translated into an expert videogamer playing a Quake-like game while being interviewed.Of course, perfection when it comes to translating a movie from book to screen is something rarely achieved, and I should be grateful for even that first third. Because as soon as Willy Wonka greets the children, the flaw in this movie becomes all-too-readily apparent: Tim Burton repeats the mistake he made in the first Batman film by putting a famous actor in the lead role who doesn't so much play the role as he plays himself playing the role. In Batman, it was Jack Nicholson who couldn't see the movie because of his own greasepaint; here, it's Johnny Depp, who looks the part, but plays it with more ticks than Big Ben. Sometimes, as in Nicholson's Joker, it's funny--but the problem is that it is distracting from the story, and the story should be king.After his introduction, and we start the actual tour of the factory where the children show their true colors, we get back to the story, but every once and awhile Burton highlights Wonka again, with the addition of flashbacks to Wonka's own childhood that are not from the book and were totally unnecessary to the plot.On the plus side, Burton uses Dahl's lyrics for the songs that the Oompa Loompas sing about the bad children. Unfortunately, the songs are so overproduced in both sound (a typically Danny Elfman-type error with movie music--it was fine when he was in a rock band, but in a movie, you only get once chance to hear the lyrics and having the music overwhelm them defeats the purpose of having lyrics) and visuals (the Oompa Loompas are one man, digitally reproduced, and in the dance numbers this becomes so apparant that instead of enjoying the visuals, you are distracted by noticing the filmmaking).All in all, I liked the movie, for when Burton gets it right, such as when the squirrels decide the Veruca Salt is a very bad nut, it captures the book perfectly. I'm just saddened that Burton (or the studio?) felt that they had to insert differences from the book. Danny deVito's Matilda remains the best adaptation of Dahl from book to screen, and that's because he didn't waver from the book, in large part due to his children threatening him that doing so would make them very, very mad. I guess Burton didn't have that type of editor.

reviewText: This show is really hilarious, and yet serious in its underlying messages. This 2005 film is an adaptation of the 1964 book of the same name, which was written by Roald Dahl.The first message is that of loyalty and the price that comes with betrayal. Because of this, one of Charlie's grandfathers lost his job, along with all the other human employees.The second lesson is that of hope and destiny. Charlie, and his parents and all four grandparents live in a run down hut. His hope is to get a golden ticket that would allow him to tour the Chocolate Factory and get the opportunity to get a 'grand prize'.The sets and the music in the movie are really catchy, the Oompa-Loompas (all played by Deep Roy) are really cool... It is amazing how they had him do all of those roles, especially when synchronized.The most important lesson that I feel that this movies teaches is that children ought to obey and respect their elders. Otherwise there can be dire consequences, which are as so graphically portrayed in this film. It is a very enjoyable movie for the whole family to watch.

reviewText: I could barely get through the...um...er...reimagination...of the childern's classic - while the set design and special FX are state of the art, as usual for a Tim Burton film, the actual movie is hard to watch. Why? Depp's "performance" is chock full of ticks and mannerisms, off-putting, flat, self-absorbed, and finally, one-note. Rather than the quirky fun of the original 1972 Gene Wilder version, Burton's film is more horror than fantasy, often casually cruel and sadistic to the point of being far from family fare.  While deliberate on Burton's part, that doesn't make the final product any more watchable. It's one grim, dismal, downward spiral slog. Not much holidday fun, huh? As with most of Burton's other big, expensive failures, he knows how to CREATE a convincing world, but has no clue how to POPULATE it with characters and situations we identify with and/or could care less about.  The final result is a film that's like a fragile, hermetically sealed curio on the shelf - nice to look at from afar, but hard to get attached to, much less involved with. What a waste of millions of studio $$$.

reviewText: Ever since I read the books I always thought that Tim Burton would be a great choice to direct the remake. I was right. Everything was much better than the original, which I still like an awful lot, and very wisely he only had the Oompa Loompas' sing in this version, with Danny Elfman's voice no less!I didn't think everything was perfect however. Burton obviously can't help but add scenes like the Automated Puppets bursting into flame and showing oh too loving closeups of the resulting mutilations which, If I were six or seven, would have made me hate the film as a whole.I also think that if you could transplant Gene Wilder's portrayal of Willy Wonka from the first version into this version, it would make the movie even more enjoyable. Wilder captured that mad quality Wonka had in the book, sly, mischievous, but not too mean or nasty. I do have to applaud Johnny Depp, though. He certainly made his Wonka memorable and unique.All in all, a very satisfying movie, and one of the better ones this year. I would probably place it in my top five favorites of the year, alongside Star Wars Episode III, Batman Begins, Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, and the Brothers Grimm.
summary: Excellent, but I like Wilder better

reviewText: When I went to see this movie I had no idea what to expect.  Most re-makes that I've seen have not been very good, so I was a bit nervous.  But this one I was quite satisfied with.This version of the story can stand on its own, because Tim Burton did not attempt to simply "copy" the original.  He mostly stuck to the book, with a few changes.  Johnny Depp had me laughing hysterically throughout the movie.  Sure, he may seem to be over-acting at points, but that's part of what makes it funny.  My first reaction to seeing pictures of him was like many others: it's Michael Jackson.  But you forget all about that in the movie.  I could almost picture Paul Rubens (Pee-Wee Herman) playing Willy Wonka; at some parts I was almost expecting Johnny Depp to let out a Pee-Wee Herman laugh.  I really enjoyed how we got sort of a side-story of Mr. Wonka's childhood through a series of flashbacks.  And while I won't give details about the ending, it is slightly different from the way the original film and the book end.  So, while we all mostly know what is going to happen throughout the film, we don't know exactly what the people (mostly Willy Wonka) are going to say, making the movie not-so-predictable.There were a few things that I didn't like, of course.  First, while many of the CGI effects were great, some felt like they were incomplete, or not detailed enough.  But maybe Tim Burton wanted them to seem a bit cartoonish.  Second, some parts of the movie feel sort of rushed.  Like finding the Golden Tickets.  We see Charlie and his family watching the news about Augustus Gloop finding the first ticket, then right away, we see Veruca, so it's like the tickets are all found right away.  This also happens while the people are in the factory; they enter the chocolate room, and before you know it, they're on the boat, then on to the inventing room, and so on.  So the kids keep disappearing so fast that we hardly get to know them.I really didn't mind the Oompa Loompa songs as much as some people.  The first one reminds me just a little bit of "Lavida-Loca".  The main thing I didn't like about them is that you can hardly understand what is being said, making them not-so-memorable.The original film with Gene Wilder will always be my favorite, but this one was very enjoyable as well.  I know some people feel that a re-make just wasn't necessary and don't see why it was made, but think, when you were young, didn't you ever watch a movie and imagine making that movie yourself?  Because that is what Tim Burton has done.  I just can't wait for this movie to come out on DVD.

reviewText: To be fair - this is not Gene Wilder's Wonka character, nor should it be confused with Wilder. reviewText: This new film version of the much-loved children's classic book"Charlie And The Chocolate Factory" by Roald Dahl from director Tim Burton ("The Nightmare Before Christmas," "Batman," "Batman Returns," "Edward Scissorhands") is more faithful to the original story than the much-lauded 1971 film "Willy Wonka And The Chocolate Factory" starring Gene Wilder, which the author disapproved of. I've seen both movies and I can honestly say that, while the screenwriter made some changes (including-SPOILER!!!-expanding the original ending to include an important message about family-SPOILER OVER!!!), they help, rather than hurt the film and do not detract from the novel in any way. In his third family movie, Johnny Depp ("Finding Neverland," "Pirates Of The Caribbean: The Curse Of The Black Pearl") plays the lovable chocolate maker with indelible charm. Freddie Highmore, Depp's co-star in "Finding Neverland," is a joy as Charlie Bucket. The other child actors are supported by an A-list adult cast which includes David Kelly ("October Sky"), Helena Bonham-Carter (Franco Z.'s misguided "Hamlet," Kenneth Branagh's excellent film version of "Mary Shelley's Frankenstein," TV's "Merlin," the upcoming "Harry Potter And The Order Of The Phoenix"), Noah Taylor and horror master Christopher Lee (Sir Laurence Olivier's masterful version of "Hamlet," the 1958 film version of "Dracula," the James Bond adventure "The Man With The Golden Gun," the 1973 version of "The Three Musketeers" and its two sequels, "STAR WARS Episode II: Attack Of The Clones" and "STAR WARS Episode III: Revenge Of The Sith"). Rated G.
summary: A Delightful Experience For The Entire Family. Better Than The 1971 Film. The Changes Help, Rather Than Hurt, This New Version.

reviewText: The real star of this story is not the quasi-humans who populate its color-saturated Dali-esque landscape, but the candy around whom their lives center.  It becomes the central metaphor around which all the good and bad strains of modern life gather to compete for dominance.Willy Wonka is raised by a dentist-father intent on making his son the embodiment of the father's view of perfection -- a perfect set of teeth.  Driven to physical and emotional humiliation by this quest, Willy develops an obsessive craving for the one thing that would most undermine that goal -- candy.This obsession spawns a genius in Willy for inventing candies like no other -- candies with magical properties of taste, shape, texture, and longevity.  But in Willy's success with his obsession lie the seeds of his undoing.  The world of unimaginative capitalists deploys its spies to steal Willy's secrets and turn the magic of his candy into a commodity available on every block at a cut-rate price.  This leaves Willy with the world's biggest candy factory on his hands and nothing to do with it.With the light of Willy's fame and genius faded to an ember, he looks to find another to rekindle the flame.  The only possibility lies with a child, as only a child can grasp the illogical wonders of candy and proceed, as Willy once did, with inventing things adults know to be unattainable.  The problem is that modern childhood offers a pretty pitiful field for producing such a child.Candy becomes the icon around which this unseemly array of children gather.  One child can see in candy only the means of satisfying his gluttony.  For another Willy's candy represents the insistence on having the best of everything; cost, fairness and consideration of the rights and feelings of others be damned.  Another child finds visiting Willy's factory to be just another highly-publicized stage upon which she and her stage-mom mother can demonstrate her ability to out-compete anyone at anything.  Yet another child sees in candy only an opportunity to apply his scientific acumen and analytic incredulity to debunking the mystique of something too many kids have approached too uncritically.  Only one child -- Charlie -- can still feel the wonder of candy and of Willy's quest.  But Charlie's a good-hearted kid with a family so mired in poverty that he cannot bear the thought of putting his own childlike desires ahead of their needs.But Willy, who is demonically willing to put the lives of these miscreant children at stake right before their parent's confused eyes, is not daunted as he plows on with his quest to find the least unsuitable child to carry on his legacy.  As the title leads one to assume, Charlie emerges the most likely candidate.  But late in the game, Charlie throws Willy a curve ball which leaves Willy with a more difficult task than fobbing off his chocolate factory.  Willy must confront the demons of his childhood and, at long last, grow up.In the end, it all comes to rights . . . except for four now very deformed children who paid quite a price for their visit to Willy's chocolate factory.But Willy wins.  Charlie wins.  Candy wins.  This is one very, very strange movie from a quirky director, using this generation's oddest actor to tell a story penned by a children's author most parents might want to read thoroughly before letting his books fall into the hands of their tykes.But it's great fun . . . in a very colorful, unsettling way.
summary: And You Thought Cavities Were Bad . . . .

reviewText: This new take on Roald Dahl's classic book is a GREAT movie! It is very loyal to the original story and the scenery is outstanding. If you are a Tim Burton fan, you will love this film and will definitely want to own this deluxe-edition dvd. The special features are kind of neat. My daughter is a fan of the "Learn to dance like an Oompa-Loompa" part. :)While the old movie focused mainly on songs and being cute, this new version really went right along with the book. Don't get me wrong, I like the old movie, but this one is just so much better. I've read the book at least four times now and it is THIS movie that is accurate to the book and that's pretty much why I like it best. Well, that and the fact that Johnny Depp is in it. :)In this movie, the children who are cast as the "rotten kids" are perfect for their parts and really fit one's mental image of what these kids should look like. The best of these, I'd say, had to be Augustus, who was shoving candy into his face faster than his arms could go. Even my five-year-old was pretty disgusted by him and that's saying a lot, if you've ever seen any of the little boys in her class eat.The only disturbing thing about this movie, however, were the Oompa-Loompas. Yep, there was only one guy playing the part, which was probably the only downfall of the film. The fact that the Oompa-Loompas had a very striking resemblance to my husband's ex-girlfriend was the thing that kinda freaked me out (we both looked at each other when we saw this one in the theater; why was his ex dressed up as an oompa-loompa? It was a strange night).In my opinion, this is Johnny Depp's best performance since "Pirates of the Caribbean" and that's saying a lot (I LOVED him as a pirate!). Also, one of the best Tim Burton films to date. If you haven't seen this one yet, the special edition dvd is worth the few extra bucks. You get a lot more features and you'll definitely have a good time enjoying all of the extras!
summary: Good morning Starshine, the Earth says "Hello!"

reviewText: This version may be more faithful to Roald Dahl's classic tale, but there wasn't as much life in those everlasting gob stoppers as I would have imagined.  Depp deftly captures Willie Wonka and Burton creates a vivid set of images of the novella, but the movie looked too much like a picture book and failed to create the tension and thrill of the story the way the original version with Gene Wilder did. This movie is amazingly somber and dull, with the characters walking gingerly over the sets, afraid it seems to touch the world Burton has created.  He turns each scene carefully over, like one would do in a pop-out children's book.  The kids are faithful restorations of those in the novel, when Burton could have updated them and given them far more spunk.  Anyway, the film is a visual treat with some fun side stories like Wonka's discovery of the Oompa Loompas.

reviewText: There is no doubt that Tim Burton has a penchant for things that are eccentric and sometimes plain creepy.  This isn't a bad thing, however -- as he demonstrates in CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY, being different can be fun and quite exciting.For starters, the film has special effects and visuals that anyone would marvel at.  From the opening sequence onward, the viewer is awestruck at the Factory itself, the town below, and the sharp distinction made between these places and Charlie's little house.  The lighting is superb and the music is magnificent, making for a delectable opening sequence.  Grandpa Joe's storytelling then ensues with rich, vibrant colors and amazing scenery.As the action continues and kids begin finding Wonka's Golden Tickets, we are introduced in turn to the winners (plus parents) and each of their peculiar quirks.  By the time the children end up in the Factory, we are formally introduced to Wonka himself -- a wonderfully odd, zany, and weird character in his own right (played beautifully by Depp).The Factory tour consumes much of the rest of the film and accounts for a considerable amount of wackiness.  The verdant Candy Meadow, the River of Chocolate (plus the Waterfall!), and many other gorgeous locales await the viewer.  Each has its own peculiarities, but the adventure never stops as the group treks through the Factory, finding excitement and humor around every corner.At the end of the day, this film radiates with Burton's creative talents.  I agree, however, that it is not for all ages.  Even some adults will be taken aback by the film's eccentricities, so letting really small kids watch it first might be reconsidered.  Keep in mind, however, that the wackiness is the only reason why this might be said -- the film is clean, fresh, and appropriate for children and adults (particularly the young at heart!).My suggestion:  Let your mind go and relax as you take in the wild world of Willy Wonka.  And, if you have the chance, see this film in IMAX -- the true surround sound and size of the screen make it an unbelievable experience.  Very highly recommended.
summary: A fun, kooky, and slightly creepy adventure...

reviewText: Jameson Thottam ... A trip down memory lane with Willy WOnkaDid I just see a movie? Or did I eat so much sugar that I went on a trip through the brain of a psychotic eight year old child?Storyline: Jameson ThottamLet's open with the general storyline for the people who haven't happened to read the book or see the original film.Charlie bucket is dirt poor. He and his family live in a small shack on the outskirts of town and the only thing he has to look foreward to each year, is one bar of chocolate on his birthday. It is truly pitiful, poor kid. So when he hears of a contest awarding five children the chance to tour the mysterious chocolate factory owned by Willy Wonka himself, Charlie decides he wants to win.After all five golden tickets are discovered in bars of Wonka's chocolate, and through some miracle that only happens in the land of movies, Charlie gets one too, the story takes off.The kids tour the factory alongside Wonka with the promise of a huge reward at the end for only one of them. As we watch the truly loathesome kiddies spit, fight, bicker, gorge, chew their cud and tumble headfirst down garbage chutes, we wonder why Wonka bothered in the first place.Analysis: Jameson Luke ThottamAs predictable as it is, I won't give away who...if anyone...wins the contest. I will however, tell you that Tim Burton tried far too hard to insert a meaningful life lesson into a movie that clearly has no meaning what-so-ever.New Version COre: Jameson ThottamThe new version has the same core as the original movie, and seems to stay truer to the book. However, it adds something a little more. Willy Wonka has regular flashbacks, a la war vet., about his childhood. I believe it is meant to make us understand why he is the way he is, and why he does the things he does. I couldn't follow this at all and just ended up wondering why Wonka thinks that being denied a few sweets here and there makes his childhood traumatic.Ooompa Oopsy: Jameson ThottamThe Oompa Loompas were played by the same man. He was incredibly odd looking and sounded hilarious. I would have liked to have seen the original songs revamped for the new film, instead of the writers just coming up with whole new ones.Shallow but Thanks to Johnny: Jameson L. ThottamIt's a bit shallow overall. Johnny Depp was brilliant as Willy Wonka, though he reeked a little of Michael Jackson, but no harm, no foul. Annasophia Robb, for some reason, really caught my attention as the gum chewing Violet Baureguard. The other three children were forgettable, and Charlie was horribly drippy and cute. I couldn't stand how unbearably sweet he was. I know his character was meant to be considerate, but come on, he's a 10 year old boy!The colours, songs, dances, and strange CG work on the faces of the children, made the movie resemble a cartoon.Final Comments...Jameson ThottamRent the original and watch it first. If you don't enjoy it...don't bother going to see this one. If you do enjoy it, you'll probably enjoy this one far less, but may as well give it a go.Jameson Thottam
summary: Jameson Thottam ... A trip down memory lane with Willy WOnka

reviewText: Sterile is the one word I would use to sum up Tim Burton's Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. We never really get to know any of the characters in the story in a deep or meaningful way. In fact, the children are presented so matter of factly that the viewer feels indifference toward their impending plight. Johnny Depp does a decent job as a somewhat dark, disturbed version of Willie Wonka. His quips to the children are funny but in most cases he is guilty of overacting. The best parts of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory are the flashbacks to Charlie's childhood. Here we learn about his father, Wilbur Wonka (played to perfection by Christopher Lee)  who is a dentist with an extreme dislike for any type of candy. The viewer also glimpses how Willie Wonka met and recruited the Oompa Loompa's to come and work in his factory which is an interesting side bar. I don't know, call me nostalgic but this version couldn't hold a candle to the original. Gene Wilder was absolute perfection and although Depp handles the role, this is clearly not one of his shining screen moments. I can relate to  Tim Burton's vision but to me there's just not enough heart in this one to make it a winner. Recommended(Barely).
summary: Great Visuals but None of the Charm of the Original...

reviewText: After reading a number of negative reviews on the web by 'movie critiques', I stayed away from the film for years. Finally, I was channel surfin and locked into this movie.Well, I really enjoyed the movie. Johnny Depp played Willy Wonka like Jim Carrey would. Somewhat exaggerated and silly, but very very funny. There were a number of comical scenes which made me giggle and there were enough of them to keep the viewer engaged (notice all the Umpa-loompas are the same guy--even the office lady!). Although, I have to say the scene of eating worms was totally uncalled for, especially for a children movie. One suggestion for improvement is adding closed captions for the lyrics sung by the Umpa-loompas. It was very hard to understand what they were saying.While the old version by Wilder did not have too much psychology involved, this version had plenty of it. For example, we can better understand what motivated Willy Wonka to be the best Chocolatier in the world when he had flashbacks to his unhappy childhood. Also, the bratty children showed mature acting when they really oozed out vicious attitudes towards each other (competing to be selected by Wonka). Funny, a 10-year-old (?) kid displaying such competitive behavior and playing politics of backstabbing just like adults in the office. The movie seems to suggest the evilness of adults already start at the tender age of youth, unless they are well raised and educated to be a good person.
summary: Fun movie to watch, but some scenes too gross for kids.

reviewText: This new version of the famous Willy Wonka story is fun and interesting despite its flaws. Fans of Tim Burton will recognize his distinct, gothic style and fantastical soundtrack from the very beginning of the film. His love of special effects is here as well, but unlike some modern day movies (ex. the very sad new Star Wars trilogy), Burton's effects never take center stage to the story. The movie's real strength is in the first forty minutes or so when we meet Charlie Bucket and his poor, but gentle and loving family. It is here that the heart of the movie truly lies and the part which is most accomidating to younger audience members, thus earning the movie's title as "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory," rather than the previously named 1971 film "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory."Once the movie moves toward Willy Wonka and the tour through his enormous factory, the dark undertone that the story has held since its conception is taken up a notch. If the 1971 movie did not creep you out as a child (as it did me) then this one is a sure-fire gaurentee. For one, Johnny Deep's Willy Wonka bare's such and obvious resemblance to Michael Jackson that it is truly difficult to believe Johnny Depp's denial of Jackson's inspiration for the character. From his pale skin and clothing fetishes to his reclusive lifestyle in an enormous playland to childhood issues with an estranged father, Wonka so resembles Jackson that one feels genuinely uneasy and concerned for Charlie Bucket when the two of them form a close (and unsupervised) relationship at the end of the movie. In spite of this, however, fans of Depp who appreciate his accentric and imaginative movie career will be able to appreciate and even laugh along with his bizaare portrayel.The most interesting and surreal aspect of the movie of course is the creation of the Oompa Lumpas, played by Deep Roy multiplied by a hundred in a special effects miracle. The extravegent song and dance numbers of the small and somewhat creepy Oompa Lumpas, combined with Depp's bizaare and over the top peformance, earn this movie the adjective "trippy," all the more enhanced by the goofy, yet frightening fates of the "naughty children" (these include getting stuck in a chocolate pipe, turning into a giant blueberry, getting thrown into an incinerator by murderous squirrels, and being shrunk to the size of a candy bar in a freak television transmission accident). Therefore if you are not a child, but still enjoy dooby-enhanced mind trip or generally odd, Alice-in-Wonderland-esque stories, then you will find interest in this movie. The movie of course, is suitable for children, but can also entertain (with both light and dark humor) adults. Still, if you have an especially squeemish or sensative child, you might want to leave him or her at home and check it out yourself.
summary: Inspiring to the Imagination and fun for both kids and adults

reviewText: Hi, everybody. I'm back. And I am going to compare the two film adaptations of "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory", one of Roald Dahl's novels. The original from 1971 directed by Mel Stuart is known as "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory", while the new one from 2005 directed by Tim Burton has the same name as the book. There have been people who compared the new one unfavorably to the original, thinking of it as another half-baked remake, like that of the over-budgeted & over-hyped Planet of the Apes remake that Burton also directed, but there are others like me that beg to differ. After all, it is NOT a remake of a classic movie, but another film adaptation of a classic book. Here is my comparison between the two in my personal opinion.First off, let's compare the depictions of Willy Wonka in both movies. Even though Johnny Depp gave a weird, creepy, and decent performance of Wonka like in the books, no one can beat the delightful, charming, and friendly Gene Wilder. From Depp's portrayal in the new one, Wonka shows disdain for families as a disadvantage on fulfilling your dreams because his dentist father, Dr. Wilbur Wonka (Christopher Lee) deprives Willy of candy due to risks to the teeth. More details later in the review. Does that happen in the original? NO! In the end, Wonka brings in the rest of Charlie's family in the first place. He was also more concerned for the others in the old one as well. I have also seen better Johnny Depp performances from Edward Scizzorhands, Benny and Joon, and the Pirates of the Caribbean trilogy, for example. No offense.Now for the supporting cast of both films. They vary in terms of advantages and disadvantages. the five Golden Ticket finders, Augustus Gloop, Veruca Salt, Violet Beauregarde, Mike Teavee (yeah, I know, a silly pun), and Charlie Bucket were noticeably older in the original, but were younger in the book and new one. Veruca seemed more spoiled and grumpy in the original. In the newer film, Augustus was more of a pig and bites his ticket for comic relief, Violet processes Martial Arts skills, and Mike is smarter when it comes to technology and shows a dislike for chocolate (PPPHHHTTT!). Charlie and his family seem more poor and his father (Noah Taylor) was alive like in the book. In the book, the Golden Ticket winners could bring one or two relatives to look after you. In the films, it was reduced to just one to keep the budgets under control. So, I would give the new one the win overall.Next up is the music department. Let's discuss the songs. The songs of the original were memorable and original, while those of the newer one were catchy and loyal to the book. To be fair, I had a little difficulty remembering the lyrics when I first saw the new film, so I looked them up on the internet and read the book. The only exception is the annoying introduction song before the puppet set catches on fire and the music distorts (now that's funny). Sorry, new Carlie, even though your songs are catchy, I have to give the original the win because of it having more songs with an Oscar nomination. In terms of the score, however, the new one by Danny Elfman was more catchy and suits the film like a glove, and when it comes to Elfman's other scores, let's say I came to expect that. So yeah, the new version wins in the score, but let's face it, in musicals like these, the songs are usually the main focus, so I'll give the original the win to be fair.It seems that one common aspect that remakes improve over the original is the visual effects. In the original, some of the candy pumpkins were obviously balloons, the chocolate river looks like a YooHoo drink, you can barely see the tube connected to Violet's suit when she becomes a humanoid blueberry, and it features the infamous demon tunnel from Hell. The visuals of the newer film were more refined and advanced. The river actually looks like chocolate, everything looks more real, the Great Glass Elevator is made entirely out of glass, and the tunnel is more of a park ride instead of a freak-out (thank god). The new film wins on the effects by a long shot.Last, but not least, let's talk about the plot, the aspect that matters the most. The premise is the same. It is about a poor boy named Charlie Bucket, who is a big fan-boy of Willy Wonka. Wonka decodes to hold a competition to search for five golden tickets hidden in five Wonka bars and the winners would gain access to the factory for a tour and a chance to win a lifetime supply of chocolate. I already discussed the ticket winners in the supporting cast section. The greedy kids would mess up and end up in a horrific fate. Augustus would fall into the Chocolate river and get sucked up by a pipe, Violet would try Wonka's meal gum and become a blueberry, Veruca gets ambushed by squirrels and dropped down the garbage chute like a bad nut (falls down a trap door in the Golden Goose room like a bad egg in the original during her musical number), and Mike tests himself for a television project like the giant candy bar and becomes tiny. All that leaving the room for Charlie to win the factory as Wonka's successor. The plot in the new one is more in depth. It is closer to the source material in terms of main premise and tone, but has its share of minor changes as well. For example, the subplot on Wonka's troubled past is original to explain his origins and keep things fresh. The events of the past when Wonka went downhill thanks to spies stealing his secret recipies were also shown and features a bit with Prince Pondicherry and the chocolate palace that melted into a giant chocolate puddle on a hot day. Like the book, it shows what happened to the other contenders. Augustus seemed a little thinner and covered in chocolate and apparently fused with it. Gee, does that sound familiar at all? Violet became more flexible and still blue. Veruca and her father are covered in garbage and Mike was overstretched by the taffy puller. Also in the new one, continuing from Willy's past, while helping clean the fireplace while his father was busy with a patient, he finds a piece of chocolate that missed the fire, tastes it, and was hooked. He goes on a journey of knowledge about candy. When his father disapproves of this, Willy leaves for Switzerland with his mother to follow his dreams. He sees that his old home disappeared when he went to stay with a neighbor for the night. Willy goes to see his father with Charlie and it was revealed that he showed remorse for his actions since he had a ton of media from Willy's fame. Willy learns the true value of family and still took care of his teeth and Wilbur learned to accept his son for who he is. Another key difference is like in the book, Charlie and Grandpa Joe do not mess up! It's just more straightforward and knows what it wants to be.In conclusion, even though I loved both of these movies, I enjoyed the new one a little more (3-2), mainly because of a more developed plot and was more similar to the book. Congratulations, Tim Burton, on another job well done! I also did a survey at my school one time on both films, and the original received the most votes from adults, and that is understandable because it was probably the one they grew up with. If you are like me, I would check them both out. They are worthy additions to add to your movie collection. See you next time!
summary: Not just a review of the film itself, but a comparison with the original

reviewText: I know I'm in the minority here, but I wasn't jumping up and down about this movie. I loved the book as a child and loved the original film with Gene Wilder for its own original contributions...perhaps I'm biased. Still, I have always admired Tim Burton and Johnny Depp's work, and had been looking forward to this new interpretation of Roald Dahl's book.This film was, indeed, more true to the book than the 1971 version...the squirrel room, the jungle scene, the children leaving the factory, perhaps a little "wiser for the wear." However, the character development of the 1971 version was MUCH better than here...you were actually given an opportunity to like or dislike each character, including Willy Wonka. I did think that Johnny Depp's portrayal of Wonka was more true to the book than Gene Wilder's...Willy Wonka is supposed to be quite childish and eccentric. However, I thought that this film's preoccupation with being true to the book caused it to overlook what is more important, which is to establish the intentions of each character. At least in the 1971 version, it's pretty clear what each character's intentions are...even if establishing some of these intentions requires a conspiracy involving "Slugworth." And though I haven't read the book in a very long time, I do NOT remember any details being given as to Willy Wonka's childhood...I thought these were unnecessary, distracting, and a waste of time. This energy could have been better spent on the children's' character development, in my opinion. This is, after all, supposed to be a story for and about children.The oompa loompas. It's true that they are physically portrayed accurately here more so than in the 1971 version, i.e. very small people and not midgets with orange skin and green hair. However, though the songs they sing here are true to the book, they are less charismatic than those of the 1971 film and sometimes seem over the top. Also, I didn't like that they were all clones of each other...I think that was a poor choice.Finally, I was appalled with the ending...this ties in with my previous comments re: Willy Wonka's childhood. It changed the whole idea behind the story itself, which is supposed to be (from my perspective) that people can overcome their hardships to have a happy and prosperous ending, as long as they're honest, selfless, and generous. This movie changes the whole theme of the story to one that emphasizes the importance of family over any kind of material wealth or prosperity. Both are perfectly good and legitimate themes, but my reading of the book left me with an impression that Roald Dahl was more concerned with the former theme than the latter. Accordingly then, this movie did not do the book justice in the most important and fundamental way, whereas the 1971 film was able to do so despite its shortcomings. My kids didn't quite enjoy this film, I mean can you blame them.
summary: What in the world have they done to this Film?

reviewText: Is anyone else catching on that Freddie Highmore is always playing the role of some poor, down-on-his-luck kid, whose life sucks bigtime, but he is always happy and cheerful? Here is how th intro to Charlie and the Chocolate Factory should have gone:Charlie goes to school. Out in the courtyard are about 20 bullies waiting for him. When Charlie arrives the bullies say "Hey there he is. Let's get 'em". A couple of bullies hold his arms back, and spread his legs apart. Then the remainding bullies line up to each give Charlie a swift kick in the jimmie. The camera starts off on the first kicker as his leg goes back, and quickly zooms in and pans up to Charlies face. You don't actually see the kicks, but you hear them, and you see Charlie shake. With each kick Freddie Highmore is making his stupid half-smile, and saying in a soft-British accent "That's wonderful".The next scene Charlie comes home from school, walking bow legged through the door. "How was school?" ask Charlie's mom. "It was absolutely marvelous" says a resilient Charlie as he shoves an icepack down his pants. Well anyway go clean up for your Birthday party.The next scene Charlie is blowing out the candles on his cake, when his mom says "Oh Charlie, we have a surprise for you." She pulls back a blanket and reveals a piniatta and about 20 baseball bats. "We invited some of your friends from school over to play break the piniatta with". Walking through the door are the same 20 bullies from school. As they walk in the house, the camera pans in on Charlie as he is silent, but has that same stupid half-smile on his face, and a twinkle in his eye, as if his face is suggesting that he's thinking "This is great". "We'll just leave you boys alone to have some fun" says Charlie's parents as they leave the room.The bullies now have Charlie held down again, as they are taking turns hitting him in the jimmy with baseball bats. Once again we don't see the hits, as the camera has panned to the outside of the house. But every few seconds we hear a thump sound, followed by a "That's Scrumdiddlyumtpious" and " Hit me in my Wonkar Bar one more time" from Charlie.
summary: Charlie Sure does love his Crappy Life
