reviewText: Wow.  I took my children to see this film and they absolutely loved it.  They are very familiar with the original version, as we have watched it many times.  It took me a while to "get it" so to speak, but when I did, something really weird happened.  Has Tim Burton figured out a way to send real physical euphoria through a movie screen?  I ask this because I left the theatre and could not stop laughing. I could not believe what I had just seen and that it was affecting me physically.  Mind you, in a very strange (but fun) way.  Let me put it this way, it's true, you can get "high" without drugs.  Of course this went completely over the heads of the kids so no worries there.The songs were so much fun that we immediatley went out and got the soundtrack!  Depp was very good.  The only strange thing is that he had this Michael Jackson thing going on.  By the time the euphoria hit, I did not care.  There is a sub-plot that is not in the original movie and a nice little story in itself.About the visuals...(I am laughing just writing this), just phenominal.  There was so much to look at and appreciate in this film.I went to see this knowing that I was going to hate it.  I put it off until the very last day it was at the theatre. I would not even have gone, but the kids talked me into it.  Don't make the same mistake.  Buy it, and enjoy it.  This is most definitely a film that you can watch over and over.
summary: Just get it...and you will GET IT!

reviewText: Visually stunning (but not to the detriment of the story).  Musically amazing.  Wickedly demented.  Incredible casting.  This is a movie to be enjoyed completely separately from the original big-screen adaptation of Roald Dahl's book.  Dahl is a dark writer who borders on being suitable for children, and this movie is true to his vision.  It's darkly touching, not candy-coated or softened-up in any way.  Watch this movie to see a young boy triumph over adversity and an overgrown child come to find the family he never had,
summary: Brilliant adaptation of Dahl's dark novel

reviewText: Though having unintentionally missed the film in theatres, I finally got to see Charlie And The Chocolate Factory on it's two disc deluxe edition DVD recently! I never have disliked a Tim Burton film, though I realize that his track record has it's overall ups and down.  I thoroughly enjoyed the film on nearly every level. Being the children's story that it is, I really appreciate the effort to use imagination while not bothering with credible reality at every turn. After all, this is a child's fantasy and doesn`t need to be weighted down with explanations for everything. The entire cast was perfect in every way. Johnny Depp, of course, turned in another very original and unique performance.  Really, what more can be said about this fine actor?Of course, the look of the film wasn't a disappointment. This film was visually reminiscent of Burton`s earlier works and succeeded for that very reason. . While I actually am one of the few to enjoy his version of Planet Of The Apes, that film does lack his overall visual signature that I so enjoy and comes across as the least impressive in Burton`s filmography. I love the fact that so much of what is seen in this film is actually real sets as opposed to CGI. Sadly, when CGI is used, it is kind of obvious to me. The opening credits are one such example of the blatantly awful looking animation, though Danny Elfman's score more than makes up for it.  Thankfully, these overdone CGI moments are few and far between.I have heard many opinions about the Oompa Loompas in the film as portrayed by actor Deep Roy, opinions that range from good to bad, but I honestly cannot understand why anybody would have a problem here. I thought the Oompas were a highlight of the film and I quite enjoyed their hilarity.  Deep Roy did an amazing job of performing all of the dances and singing all of the lyrics over and over multiple times for the complex visual effects required to pull off the "Oompa effect". I  also really enjoyed all of the creative songs they performed, put to a wide variety of differing styles  by composer Danny Elfman.  My favorite song was the first one we hear as gluttonous Augustus Gloop gets what's coming to him. Of interest to me was that the lyrics of the songs were straight out of Roald Dahl's book! I think that creating such different songs based on old monologues is amazing in and of itself.Another complaint I have heard about the film most commonly in reviews and such is the flashbacks concerning Willy Wonka's father. While this plotline was indeed created for the film, it didn't bother me in the least.  I do not feel that the inclusion of Willy's father in any way hampers the film. Christopher Lee plays Willy's father, and it is always pleasurable to watch this great actor do what he does best. I loved the surreal way these flashbacks were told as well, right down to how a particular building "disappears" completely. What did I say earlier about a child's imagination and not needing to adhere to reality? It was perfect! Anyhow, I thought the new material worked just fine and helped support the additional material at the end of the film. Speaking of the ending, I liked the new tweaks and additions there as well, for I was never a fan of Charlie winning, flying around in a flying elevator, and never really knowing anything else beyond that moment.  It isn't so much an explanation as it is just taking things a step further, to a more satisfying result. I know the original film reflects how Mr. Dahl wrote it, but after watching the documentary about him on the DVD, I cannot help but think he would have approved of this alteration.If I had a complaint about ANYTHING in the film, it would be about the scene in which we see what happened to the other four children after their mishaps in the factory. I very much think their fate was better left to our imagination as opposed to seeing this new addition.  Again, what did I say about the need to explain things?  Well, this scene is delivering in an area that was best left undressed originally, as Willy himself offered enough to let us know that the kids were going to be alright. Of course, this is a merely a small nitpick.The special features are also worthy of one's time, though I am a bit disappointed that the DVD contains no audio commentary featuring Tim Burton.  With that said, the animated menus are fun, and the documentaries and very informative.  In addition to the very interesting documentary on Mr. Dahl that I mentioned earlier, the disc contains a plethora of other insightful glimpses into the making of the film.  Of particular note is the feature dealing with the squirrels used in the film`s nut cracking room, as well as a detailed feature on the extensive work that went into creating the multitudes of various Oompa Loompas seen throughout the film. Sadly the interactive games included on the discs are disappointing, though aimed at very young children.  Interviews with the director, composer, and actors make for an exciting look into the making of this surreal film.  All in all, a very well put together supplemental package.I would recommend this film to any who are fans of either the original film starring Gene Wilder in the starring role, or fans of Mr. Dahl's book in general.  If you like interesting documentaries and other supplements on your DVD, waste no time in obtaining the two-disc deluxe edition!  4.5 stars!
summary: A Remake that Is Actually WORTH Your Time
Title: N/A

reviewText: Hey kids, Mister Wonka just put out a new flavor! I hope you like double-glazed crapcake, because that's what it tastes like. It seems Wonka, Inc. was bought out by a glitzy Hollywood outfit that booted out all of the loveable characters, simple charm and oh-so hummable songs and replaced them with high-gloss, coldly computerized eye-candy. The oompah loompahs are all played by one ugly old man who is digitally recreated, neat trick, but a piss-poor substitute for the original hard-working wee people. Miscast Johnny Depp pales (figuratively and literally) in comparison to Gene Wilder. He plays Wonka like an old Dave Foley character from "Kids in The Hall," but creepier and completely unlikable. Not to be an "older is always better" guy, but not one single thing in this high-tech remake is better than the original. The songs just plain stink and the kids, except for Charlie, are less than sweet simulacrums of the original stellar cast. I can't remember the book that well, but I'm pretty damn sure that Roald Dahl did not have the hackneyed story line about Wonka having "father issues" that need to be addressed and happily remedied in the last five minutes. The beauty of the original was the mystery around the factory and the enigmatic Wonka, like many simple joys, I don't need to have everything explained to me and have "back stories" shoved down my throat.

reviewText: Not everybody reviews things they like, or understand.  "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" really has to be seen from a kid's eye view to be grasped.  Adult commentaries don't seem appropriate for something like this.Having said that, and also having revealed in this review's title that I don't care much for the story itself, I was much more interested in this version of the film than its predecessor.  I should also mention that I'm generally lukewarm about Tim Burton's body of work as well.Nevertheless, this is the film I believe Tim Burton was destined to create.Burton usually finds the dark side of a story to play in, but here at last he seemed to find the exact balance needed to tell this story properly.  This story is about the grotesque character types of childhood - poverty-stricken Charlie observing children over-indulged and overloaded in what they eat, what they play with, what they're presented with, and what they compete for - and Dahl's ways of showing them up for what it ultimately brings them all.  It's aimed at a child's morality and sense of justice, not an adult's.  Adults who dismiss this story as somehow sick or scary really don't get it.  But I think that perhaps Burton does.Charlie, himself, is wonderfully played by young master Highmore without being too gushy or syrupy.  Johnny Depp's (and I imagine Tim Burton's) version of Willy Wonka loses some of the sinister schizoid clown aspect that Gene Wilder had and replaces it with quirks associated with never quite growing up properly.  And who can ever slight David Kelly's performances in anything?  Much more fitting casting here as Grandpa Joe than Jack Albertson in the earlier version.The special effects are relatively tame in this film, but seem to concentrate more on it really being a factory than a theme park ride as the earlier film version of the story always strikes me (or even a psychedelic nightmare at times).  The look feels right for nowadays, and Danny Elfman's score is equally fitting and witty.To the reviewer who claimed that Depp played two roles, look again.  Mrs. Bucket is definitely NOT Johnny Depp, but Helena Bonham Carter, who will do the voice of the Corpse Bride (in release September, 2005) alongside Depp and under the direction of Tim Burton.I expected little from this film, and couldn't even talk my 17-year-old into seeing it, but I was pleasantly surprised by it.  I have great difficulty getting through the earlier version with Gene Wilder without falling asleep, but this one kept me interested and involved throughout.  Give it a shot.
summary: Not a fan of the story, but this is what Tim Burton was meant for
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's almost heresy to redo Gene Wilder's classic interpretation of Willy Wonka, but Tim Burton's version of Roald Dahl's slightly poisonous sweet story is in a way more faithful to the famous, if dark children's author, and certainly it stands on its own. I enjoyed it, and one way to enjoy it is just to put aside any thoughts of the original film and go along for the ride.There are a few clinkers; I loved Deep Roy as all the Oompa Loompas, and also as a few single roles (the psychiatrist.) But the computer graphics that replicated him to become ALL the Oompa Loompas was a bit boring, and he was too small--the teensiness of the new Oompa Loompas made them almost insignificant. Likewise, some of Danny Elfman's Oompa songs got a bit dull--though they weren't bad. Just not catchy, like the original.Johnny Depp is a troubled Willy, who has more than a streak of mean in him. He seems somewhat unengaged. The annoying children are fine (I loved Veruca, she was by far the best) and the casting for Charlie Bucket and his grandad were right on. Helen Bonham Carter, however, looked a bit out of place.The factory failed to dazzle me, but I loved the elevator. I just went along for the ride and enjoyed it almost as much as the original. You just have to take it at face value.
summary: Less sweet, still filling---an interesting remake

reviewText: No matter if you love or loathe chocolate, or admire or despise the 1971 adaptation of `Ronald Dahl's `Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory', starring Gene Wilder, of which Ronald Dahl wrote the screenplay himself - both bars of confectionary should be eaten and savoured upon separately. However there are many edible gratifications to be found in each ambitious undertaking to bring `Charlie and the Chocolate Factory' to the screen for everyone to feast their eyes upon without gaining an ounce of weight. All this and more can be found nestled on a slim versatile video disc called DVD for a lifetime of enjoyment.With twelve notable films under his belt according to Empire magazine, the latest being `Corpse Bride', original Black Knight `Batman' director Tim Burton, with eccentric films and hair to match movie producer Brian Grazer's hairdo, failed to get through to the register with his chocolate bar (perhaps due to the long line of people ahead of him desperate to consume the new sensation sweeping the nation), and so has moulded a classic film for his eleventh directorial effort that is perhaps his finest hour yet. For Graeme Base it was, and for talented children's author Ronald Dahl's sixth novel it has proven to be a sweet worth sharing with the world. Thirty four years after the original film, that was vehemently despised by its author comes a wilder, wickeder, brooding interpretation. So expect a distinctly darker block of chocolate now on the market, that, if Ronald Dahl was alive today might delight in the change or cause him to turn is his grave. So versatile is this story it comes in drinkable liquid form being hot chocolate.From early indications when poster work went into production, it was anyone's guess how the finished product would turn out. It's only in the experimental taste-testing, movie preview screenings that we get to indulge in the delectable new creation from renowned chocolate constructer Willy Wonka. There's something under his hat that might warrant some close examination in a padded cell, by a doctor House, with a cane who could meet a man who shares a similar crooked disposition as Peter Laurie's creation.There has been some tinkering done here, with some sections split into bite sized pieces, but with the most memorable scenes intact. However it only enriches the original story, and only encourages more children to turn the pages of the book with appropriately chocolate covered fingers. You'll either find a treasure trove of treats in a colourful landscape that the poster artwork might suggest could be a rainbow after a rainstorm. Be careful though as you consume this for I feel a vomiting sensation will overcome the eater that will leave you feeling sick to your stomach and abandon you as you are burdened with a severe case of indigestion. If this film spoils your appetite like a `Milky Way' promises not to do, you'll be cursing the day you came across this chocolate bar that will forever leave a despicable taste in your mouth for years to come and cause you to spit at like pips in an orange. The pips are coming if you don't think this film has anything to do with oranges but to me it does. You'll implore to anyone who will listen that this chocolate bar doesn't belong to you.Coming from poor yet humble beginnings, we meet Charlie Bucket, (Freddie Highmore) who live with his ailing grandparents, who are in desperate need of an adventure, having been cooped up in a big bed for years on end, and a life-long staple diet of boring old cabbage, that will surely see the grandparents kick the bucket well before Charlie if something isn't done fast. Yet it is a stroke of pure luck and a yearly birthday for Charlie that holds the promise of turning everyone's life around. Peeling back the wrapper of an enticing chocolate bar, hoping for a golden ticket that will secure Charlie's place in a tour of the infamous recluse Willy Wonka's once opulent factory. That was until the factory closed, and one of the afore mentioned grandparents, who used to work diligently for Mr. Wonka, was laid off and replaced by a more efficient, yet impersonal machine.They say time heals all wounds and after years of closure, Willy Wonka (Johnny Depp) entertains the idea of five lucky children having a tour of his world-renowned factory.It's then we have the distinct pleasure of meeting four other winning children lacking in social graces and delightfully repugnant, Mike Teavee, (Jordon Fry) Veruca Salt, (Julia Winter) Violet Beauregarde, (Annasophia Robb) and Augustus Gloop, (Philip Wiegrat) who fill this film with so much enthusiasm, and an over abundance of self-worth in their daily pursuits, that their luck must surely change before there is time for the children's rotten exploits to decay the smooth flowing mechanics of this film. They would too if it wasn't for Willy Wonka's adept knowledge of his beloved factory to dispose of each contestant in distinctly different, yet ingeniously characteristic methods. A humongous block of chocolate and score fitting to Stanley Kubrick's '2001: A Space Odyssey' is spectacular. The pips I mention before as in the bad children I think of `A Clockwork Orange'. Controversial in its day I can't really comment on it having not seen it, but `Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds' also comes to mind even though there is no music from them. Eminem doesn't get a mention either, Michael Jackson and comparisons about him are a little unfair. He made `History' so he must be doing something worthy enough to record.John August who wrote the script for this and Tim Burton's previous film `Big Fish', does a good job, although I'm more inclined to prefer the `Big Fish' script over `Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'.When thinking of Ronald Dahl's books `Charlie and the Chocolate Factory' is indeed memorable. There will never be a movie sequel to `Charlie and the Chocolate Factory', but there is more great glass elevator in this film. To me, I enjoyed `The Witches' and `Matilda'. Miss Honey in Danny DeVito's film is a honey! I just don't own any of the books or films. I think this will have to change! A movie and book series that comes to mind of a similar dark design are `Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events'.For me it's all about the adorably deplorable children with kudos to all of them they are all destined to be big stars. For me I liked Veruca Salt who had a blatant disregard for anyone who didn't give her what she wanted, was wonderfully self absorbed in herself and particularly adorable to me. I also wonder if the band of the same name headed by Nina Gordon was an inspiration for them from this book. Violet Beauregard who was a constant gum chewing champion I couldn't help but get attached to. The inclusion of musical numbers is almost nonexistent in Hollywood these days, so to see them in the mix is a welcome addition to Willy Wonka's recipe for success. It would be understandable if people don't lap this movie up in droves. Still if it gets you tongues waging and your mouths chewing on gum, chocolate and the like then it must be doing something right. I loved writing this review and I enjoy the hot chocolate and chocolate bar from Nestle. I'd love to give this film five stars but it just didn't feel exactly right to me so four will have to saffice. This DVD is near perfection just didn't quite do it for me. I can just hear Veruca Salt saying "Daddy, I WANT 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory' DVD right now!" In the end it all comes down to taste and it is indeed an aquired taste at that. Try to restrain yourselves everyone!
summary: Warning! Chocolate may contain traces of nuts! Unwrap a darker block and vomit it out if contents don't agree with you

reviewText: "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" (2005) is a fantasy world created by director Tim Burton who has done some off-the-wall movie work. It stars Johnny Depp, lipstick and all, as an androgynous Michael Jackson lookalike. He's playing Willie Wonka, the owner of a candy factory that no longer employs any local people.Charlie, the title character, has a grandfather who formerly worked in the plant. Willie offers five prize certificates in his candy bars. That way he sells a lot of candy. The lucky five finders of the coupon will receive a tour of the factory accompanied by one companion, and one of the five will get a special gift.Five kids find the prizes, nice kid Charlie and four awful, nasty, despicable brats, rotten little twirps who each gets his or her comeuppance while touring the factory.The wild colors in the factory with its rivers and waterfalls of chocolate are more vivid and startling when seen on in a high definition television screen with a Blu-Ray machine.Are we in a candy factory or a nut house? One actor, Deep Roy, plays all of the hundreds of the Oompa-Loompa tribe that works in the factory. The Oompa-Loompas perform musical numbers, which are like Busby Berkley gone to cuckooland.At times it's a sweet story of a sweets factory, at times is cloyingly sweet, and at other times Johnny Depp plays a cruelly misanthropic and nasty person. He doesn't like kids. He plays a real weirdo.There are some Dickensian touches: Charlie's four pleasant, kindly grandparents spend their time lying in interlocking beds facing each other in front of the fireplace. Charlie and his wonderful loving family live in their ramshackled tipsy house with holes in the roof. It's based upon a famous Roald Dahl children's story and was a movie previously with Gene Wilder.
summary: Johnny Depp, Tim Burton - A Strange Combo

reviewText: Every one of the 1 star reviews laments that this is not the Gene Wilder version. Well, duh! And boy do I hate that pointless movie almost as much as the author of the book, Roald Dahl, did. Those dreadful songs by that hack Anthony Newley and dumb looking green faced Oompa Loompas are way worse than any song or Oompa Loompa clone in this version by Burton.So forgetting that lame musical version from the 70's [which was a box office flop, BTW] what we have here is an imaginative and quirky film that actually, alas, doesn't live up to its potential. Oh the FX is spectacular and imaginative to be sure, and Depp's performance is unique and has zero to do with Michael Jackson....intentionally at any rate, [these get it the 4 stars] but it all adds up to...what? Yes there are lessons to be learned but it's mainly a excessive film about the dangers of excess. And, hello....not all families are great. Some people need to jettison their families in order to become something and feel good. Still, it's something to see!I believe the backstory about Dr. Wonka, DDS, was originally devised by Dahl himself when he attempted an early screenplay.... so you can complain all you want about that, but let's leave off  the "it doesn't fit Dahl's intentions at all" argument.

reviewText: Tim Burton's "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is a much darker film adaptation of the Road Dahl novel than "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory". Without question, this adaptation is much truer in spirit to the dark, caustic humor of Dahl's prose. I don't exaggerate stating that in Burton, Dahl has found the best artistic kindred spirit capable of rendering his tale into film, while Johnny Depp is a more troubled, emotionally disturbed Willy Wonka than Gene Wilder's exuberant version. And yet, inspite of its often morose, dark spirit, "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is deliciously funny, especially in the scenes where Charlie Buckett's (Freddie Highmore) obnoxious young companions get their just desserts (Each time this happens, the film goes into warp speed, offering scenes which are hysterically funny.). As Charlie, Freddie Highmore offers yet another spellbinding performance (He acted alongside Depp in "Finding Neverland", portraying the young boy who was the inspiration for Peter Pan.), portraying the young hero of Dahl's novel as a generous, thoughtful kid who is wiser beyond his years. David Kelly's portrayal of Grandpa Joe is also spellbinding, as the dear old friend and confidant to young Charlie Bucket. Composer Danny Elfman contributes an intriguing musical score which runs the gamut from Philip Glass to the Beatles and Kiss in its musical influences; it may be the most consistently exuberant aspect of this film, along with the lavish sets constructed for the Wonka Chocolate Factory. And speaking of exuberance, there's a silly, but appropriate homage to the opening scenes of Kubrick's "2001: A Space Odyssey" which I think is absolutely brilliant.I greatly enjoyed viewing this film, which I would recommend without reservation to any kid above the age of five (However, there may be some scenes, such as the "squirrel attack" which may be disturbing to some younger children.). My only reservation is in Burton's shifting of the tale from Charlie's to Wonka's perspective, adding in a rather gratuitious series of flashbacks with a young Wonka and his dentist father portrayed brilliantly by Christopher Lee. This leads unfortunately to a rather extended ending in which Wonka comes to grips finally with maturity (If I write more, I will be yielding a major spoiler!). Still, despite this caveat, I have no doubt that many will find this film most enjoyable.  I couldn't help but laugh at every funny moment, joined by a chorus of enthusiastic film goers each time I've seen "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory". It is my favorite film of the summer so far, and one destined to become a future cinematic classic.
summary: Splendid, Darker, Truer Adaptation of  Dahl's Novel

reviewText: I was almost dreading the day I would have to see this film -- I did so only because someone purchased the DVD for me as a present.  I sat down, fully expecting to loathe this new venture, especially considering my love for the original film.  I was pleasantly surprised, however.I like Tim Burton films, so I was immediately tickled by the offbeat humor (I am one of the few people who actually enjoyed "Mars Attacks").  Danny Elfman's music score is catchy and the songs inventively delightful (each song for each kid is from a different era of popular music -- though you may want to flip on the subtitles so you can understand the lyrics).  Johnny Depp's Wonka is weird but not repulsive, and the flashbacks to his childhood (with a dentist father chillingly essayed by Christopher Lee)give us a solid understanding of his excentricities.Perhaps more amazing is the focus on Charlie Bucket, a delightfully normal kid if there ever was one, as the stablizing force for the story.  Not only is Charlie's family more accessible and real than the 1970's version, but it manages to conclude the film with a surprising yet satisfying pro-family statement.  Those disappointed by the closing line of the original film ("But you know what happened to the boy who suddenly got everything he wanted...he lived happily ever after.") because it seemed to contradict every oompa loompa song that preceded it, will be pleased with the sober ending of this film which is strongly reminiscent of Dahl's own "James and the Giant Peach" and even Dr. Seuss' "How the Grinch Stole Christmas."While trying hard not to give things away, it can be said that the Wonka weirdness becomes perfectly acceptable, because Wonka is a character in the process of becoming better, and it is Charlie who manages to be the catalyst for change.While the weirdness is weird enough so that I would not immediately call this a "family" film, it is still an impressive piece of work that is worth a look.  One of Tim Burton's best films.
summary: "It makes the chocolate light and frothy..."

reviewText: This 2005 movie features Johnny Depp playing Willy Wonka. Weird. A very weird portrayal of Wonka. I think Johnny Depp is one of the great actors out there, but I really didn't care for how he played the role of Wonka. Those sunglasses, the pale skin, the smile, it all makes him resemble Michael Jackson in a way. His personality seems low-key and quiet.  No spunk.  In contrast, Gene Wilder as Willy Wonka in Willy Wonka & The Chocolate Factory (1971) was much more energetic and enthusiastic.  I realize this 2005 movie follows the book, but I prefer Gene Wilder's Willy Wonka.  Sometimes changing a character's personality in contrast to the book works out for the better.I must say that the blueberry scene in this movie was overdone. It seems that everything was overdone and had lots of CGI.The kids in this movie weren't as memorable as they were in the 1971 movie. Some of them have the really snotty attitude, but not quite reaching the same level as in the 1971 movie.The Oompas weren't nearly as good as they were in the 1971 movie.  The Oompa song from '71 was great.  The songs in this 2005 movie were fair to pretty good at best.  The musical score by Danny Elfman, however, was good.To sum up, it's a pretty good movie, but I still prefer Willy Wonka & The Chocolate Factory.

reviewText: If you still love "Charlie/Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" but didn't think it needed a remake, you've got another think coming. Tim Burton, the man who took the "Addams Family" theme ("it's creepy and its kooky") and made it into an art form in both live and animated classics, has given Roald Dahl's timeless fable a faithful, yet fresh, retelling.Johnny Depp, Burton's favorite leading man and himself the master of eccentric-loner character, won't make you forget Gene Wilder's Willy Wonka. Instead, he brings the candy man into a place called WonkaWorld. Where Wilder gave you a wink and a nod throughout, Depp- in his Marcel Marceau mask, Edwardian derby, and pretty-boy delivery- makes Willy Wonka a weird, ghostly creation that's still a magnet on the screen. In contrast, the kids- played cute and/or broadly the first time- are all down-to-earth yet put over Dahl's traits very well. Freddie Highmore (who worked with Depp in "Finding Neverland") gives Charlie a modest, English-schoolboy manner; the best of the kids is Anna Sophia Robb ("Because of Winn-Dixie"), whose Violet Beauregarde is a slightly-tacky little Southern belle with a mouthful of gum. My favorite performance, though, is by David Kelly ("Waking Ned Devine"), the grizzled Irish stage actor whose Grandpa Joe- a lovable old-timer with a delightful Irish lilt and twinkle- is priceless (dare we say Oscar-worthy?)Burton and his crew of designers, animators and costumers have an absolute field day with the movie's look. The cold gray Northern English (Northern Ohio? Northern Germany?) factory town with the Bucket's tilted, off-kilter house suddenly goes "Wizard of Oz" on us as Willy Wonka emerges from the gates and leads the group to the gaudy chocolate waterfall room. Look also for the "Sgt. Pepper"-esque nut house with the (largely real) team of nut-cracking squirrels, the "2001: Space Odyssey" (with the bombastic Strauss fanfare) WonkaVision studios, and other touches that really make Depp, in particular, such a marvelously spooky-kooky guy.Did I mention the very talented Danny Elfman, that quirkiest of movie composers and a Burton partner for 20 years? This guy's one of my new heroes. Not only does he back the pre-factory sections with brooding, yet witty, music that has distinct Anglo-Russian overtones, he dips into everything from Bollywood musicals to "Bohemian Rhapsody" for the Oompa-Loompa songs (using parts of Dahl's original poems)...and sings them with nifty '60s-style voice tricks. The "Augustus Gloop" number alone's worth the price.Burton and writer John August worked very closely with Dahl's widow, and it shows; not only is half of the dialogue taken right from the book but they added a bio for Willy Wonka that's really in Dahl's dark-but-moral spirit. It's told in dream sequences that involve old horror-movie fave Christopher Lee as the senior Wonka, who's...an orthodontist! Take a look at the hideous brace/mask/helmet little Willy must wear, and you'll see why he's obsessed with candy. This doesn't spoil the story, but adds that dark Dr. Demento edge that's so much a part of Burton's work. (It's a wonder the kid wasn't electrocuted at 10!)Wisely, the DVD package doesn't include a feature commentary; this movie doesn't need it. The bonus disc, however, has some great stuff on it. Burton, the cast and crew are all major parts of features that cover the squirrel and Oompa-Loompa sequences; the former were both animated and real, while the latter is Deep Roy, a diminutive Anglo-Indian actor/stuntman, multiplied by dozens of CGI and/or robot duplicates. (Watch Deep wear two dozen costumes, play drums, and do disco-style dance steps!) Danny Elfman, too, has his own well-deserved feature- I mean, the guy does everything and he's very funny to boot. Even the kids' games, especially the one with the squirrels, are clever (and not so easy)."Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" may not be for the youngest audiences; the rating was unique (PG/"quirky situations"), and it's quirky, all right. Veruca does get swamped by marauding squirrels and the Wonka puppet show catches on fire...but those are Tim Burton moments, all right. Creepy and kooky indeed. If you're still a great fan of both the book and the original movie, you won't be disappointed in this one. In fact, I think it will be as popular decades from now as the Wilder version...or, dare I say, "The Wizard of Oz"? Highly recommended!

reviewText: Ok, Johnny Depp has an underniable talent in acting. He can magically craft himself into any role he needs to do. So can he morph himself into the already made Willy Wanka? Yes and no. His characters works, being a nice comic relief for the movie. But you can't help but feel that he basically ripped his character off of Michael Jackson, which he can swear up and down he didn't do but the audience has eyes and wont be fooled.You are taken to a strange world, which ranges from the chocolate palace, to Charlie's deformed house, to the inside of Wanka's factory. Many will quickly take a liking to Charlie, a polite yet poor boy who miraculously got into the factory. And accompanying him are four other brats adjoined with their own type of sins. Veruca is a snotty spoiled brat, Viola being a competitive twit, Mike is another brat living his life through videogames, and Augustus makes a pig out of himself. Each end up getting what comes to them, which stays loyal to both the book and movie.The acting is done wonderfuly, even so with the questionable Johnny Depp. It also branches out from the original in true Tim Burton style to prevent it from being a clone of the book and previous movie. The visuals are stunning, and the oompa loompas' musical scenes are humorous and left me with some laughs. The only draw back is that the ending was a tad rushed, and Johnny Depp doesn't seem to do the role justice. But other than that, the movie is clever and creative.
summary: Charlie and The Chocolate Factory by Tim Burton

reviewText: Tim Burton's "Charlie & the Chocolate Factory" is a remake as well as an adaptation of both the Roald Dahl novel and screenplay as well as a visual wonder of a film. Comparing it to "Willy Wonka & the Charlie Factory" it is a lot more faithful to the book and is a lot better visually. All the actors play their parts well; the visual effects, makeup, and set direction are worthy of Oscar nods. Johnny Depp's portrayal of the androgynous candy maker is spectacular. People compare his performance to Michael Jackson, and there's obviously some Jacko in there, but he also reminded me of an equally controversial singer (Marilyn Manson). The look Depp has in the film brought to mind both Manson and Jackson, the voice Jackson. Whatever it is, Depp is great. The script, adapted by John August, has a lot more depth; Even diving into Wonka's childhood. Burton is still himself, the film has the Burton mood and music (composed by Danny Elfman). Anyway, the film is about Charlie (Freddie Highmore, Finding Neverland) who lives with his father (Noah Taylor), his mother (Helena Bonham Carter) and his bedridden grandparents in their lopsided house. Everyday, Charlie passes Willy Wonka's chocolate factory. A factory which has been open for a while, but seems to never have anybody going in or out. But then suddenly it is announced that Willy Wonka has hidden five golden tickets in candy bars that are to be shipped around the world. Anyway, same ol' story; Charlie finds the golden ticket and along with four other children go into Wonka's famous factory. Now for the children and their parents. Well, there are some changes. The parents of the children are quite different. The kids are pretty much the same; Augustus Gloop is a fat disgusting child. Veruca Salt is a spoiled brat. Violet Beauregard is a competitive gum chewing over-achieving little girl. And then Mike Teevee is still the kid who sits in front of the TV all day, except this time he plays video games. The Oompa-Loompa's have changed quite a bit as well. Instead of the green haired, orange faced midgets we're used too. We have a single actor (Deep Roy) playing the Oompa-Loompa's who now merely wear orange jumpsuits. Very well done. A-.
summary: Better than the Original. Lovely Set Direction

reviewText: This is a Tim Burton movie - dark, creepy, drippy, and cold. When it starts, you think you're watching Batman - loud elaborate sound track, cold villainous set design. Really, you expect a shot of the Penguin or Riddler to pop in anytime.The storyline is VERY much like the 1971 movie . . . except different. Because you know the plot line so well, much of the movie is very predictable. I guess Burton really tried making it interesting, but it comes across as contrived, dark, and, well, Burtonesque.Burton has a fixation on dark fathers and oppressed sons. There's this odd backstory about Wonka and his overbearing father, making him wear some kind of torture device orthodontics that look like something Scissorhand would wear. Very Hellraiser-like.Wonka. Really bad. Depp is lost here. He mixes bits and pieces of other characters into his roles, and it shows here. You first see him after this bizarre candyland introduction that bursts into flames, and all the cute dolls violently melt before your eyes. (Very disturbing for children to watch. Which is why Burton does it, of course.) He acts like Michael Jackson, and you wonder if that's going to be the essence of his role.Nope. Depp's Wonka can't ever figure out who he is: malicious, misopedic, moody, petulant, weird. And more. He really makes no sense, and this is Burton's fault because Depp does basically whatever Burton wants.Remember Scissorhand's odd father/son complex? Well, its back, only this time with Christopher Lee as the father-God figure, and Depp's Wonka as the harmed child. Burton has some very long-standing, deep-seated emotional issues here, and I guess he doesn't mind because it makes him a lot of money. (And actually, I believe its his personal interpretation of God and His woeful, misbegotten creatures. You see it a lot in his movies.)The oompa loompas are really bad. They cloned this one Indian midget named Deep Roy - only adding to the cold, sterile nature of this movie - so you basically have one guy multiplied into a thousand.Yeah, this is a not good movie. Its confused, dark, and only marginally entertaining. Take a pass.
summary: A Clockwork Orange meets The Batman

reviewText: In Hollywood, repeat collaborations between certain actors and directors is a very popular, and generally lucrative prospect for all parties involved. Each partner in the collaboration walks away a winner, mostly because the movie that was worked on was a success, earning them more respect, bigger star power, and sometimes even critical acclaim. There are currently a few big name collaborations that have been prominent over the last few years, George Clooney and Steven Soderbergh ("Ocean's 11-13"), Christian Bale and Christopher Nolan ("Batman Begins" and "The Prestige"), Kevin Smith and the batch of actors that have appeared in almost every one of his films (from "Mallrats" to "Clerks 2"). But there is one collaboration that has existed longer than the others, since the 1990 release of "Edward Scissorhands", the collaborators are, of course, Johnny Depp ('Pirates of the Caribbean' trilogy) and director Tim Burton ("Batman"). What's impressive about this particular collaboration, sure the length of time is quite a feat by Hollywood standards, but the fact that this collaboration remains so powerful at the box office is astonishing. Almost every one of Johhny Depp's and Tim Burton's movies have turned a profit. In 2007, the duo came together yet again for the movie "Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street", but before this film the two worked on the remake of the Roald Dahl children's classic "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory", the novel that had been previously adapted in 1971 with "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory"."Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is the story of a sweet, good-hearted little boy named Charlie (Freddie Highmore) who lives in a rundown shack with his mother, father, and both sets of grandparents. They have next to nothing to live on, and Charlie's birthday is coming up, and the only thing they can afford is one single candy bar. But not just any candy bar, a Wonka Bar, made at the mysterious Wonka Chocolate Factory located in the same town. What makes the factory so mysterious is that not a single person has been seen coming or going from that factory in 15 years, that is until an announcement goes out to the whole world that 5 lucky people will be selected to visit the factory and meet the reclusive owner, Willy Wonka (Johnny Depp). Most of Charlie's life, good fortune has been rather elusive, but one lucky day changes everything as Charlie finds one of the 5 golden tickets that will give him access to Wonka's factory, and the wonders that Charlie will behold will change his life forever.When I first heard about this movie's release, I wasn't all that excited to see it, in fact I didn't even want to see it at all. For starters, I didn't care a whole lot for the original movie "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" starring Gene Wilder, so I didn't really see what I would find of interest here. Plus, the original film was so well received by critics and audiences, that I didn't understand the point behind making this updated version. However, one day I recorded the movie off of the Showtime network, and figured what the heck, I'll give it a try. I mean, it's Johnny Depp and Tim Burton together again, just how bad could this movie be.Truth be told, the movie's not all that bad. It's obvious the reason that Depp and Burton continue collaborating is that there is a chemistry there that allows their work together to be so successful, and "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" was at least a decent addition to their list of collaborations, though not their best by any means.As one could easily tell from the previews, and possibly the DVD cover for that matter, the movie is strange, no doubt about that. There's a lot of weird things that occur in the movie, some that happened in the original, and some new, but the story is actually quite endearing as you watch this young boy's innocence begins to reach this reclusive man, showing him that reaching out and trusting in others will bring a sense of belonging into his life. There were some elements to the film that I didn't care for, primarily the song numbers, they were just flat-out irritating to listen to, and I found myself skipping ahead to the end of the song as they did nothing more than slow the movie down. Some of the characters were extremely annoying, but that's not so much the actors fault as it was simply the way the character was meant to be, but I still didn't care for them and couldn't wait for them to get off the screen.Performance wise, Johnny Depp did an excellent job as the quirky eccentric Willy Wonka, a role I was surprised that Depp was chosen for, but his chameleon-like ways with characters continued to serve him well in this movie. Some critics of the film felt Depp's portrayal was a bit too much like Michael Jackson, leaving them with a creepy feeling when Wonka was on screen. Personally I didn't read that into his Depp's performance, though I can maybe see how some might think that. The other standout performance was Freddie Highmore's, this talented young actor, who previously appeared in "Finding Neverland" with Johnny Depp, convincingly conveyed the innocence and naive view of the world that Charlie possessed, and he seemed like the perfect good kid, to the point he was a little unbelievable as a character. Charlie's character, in this film, was just too perfect, he listened and obeyed everything that Wonka requested, yet in the original, if I remember correctly both he and his grandpa snuck away to mess around in some bubble room that caused them to fly for a little bit. To me this change came off a little too much like director Tim Burton was trying too hard to make Charlie seem so good compared to the other kids, so he changed the story to make Charlie seem perfect. Now I will say that I've never read the book, and I've heard that the original film changed numerous elements from the book, so maybe the reason Burton's version didn't have the scene was because the book didn't, so I don't know, maybe Burton got it right in the end, either way I would have preferred a little more complexity to Charlie to make his character a little more believable.The sets for this movie were all intricately detailed, from Charlie's family shack that was designed to be leaning as if it could fall over at any time, further illustrating the family's poor lot in life. To the extravagance of Wonka's factory, where each room was visually amazing, without feeling faked by CGI. Director Tim Burton's eye for the unusual and keen attention to detail was evident in his sets, and his strong imagination and storytelling ability was perfect for a movie such as this.Even with good performances, extravagant set pieces, and imaginative storytelling by director Tim Burton, this movie is still only average in my opinion. The parts I liked were entertaining, and the parts I didn't weren't that major, but as a whole the movie just didn't grab me to the point that I felt like it was a great movie. I thought it was good to see once, but I probably would not choose to watch it again."Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is rated PG for mild language.

reviewText: I once made the comment that most of the entertainment today is in very bad shape.  The industries are trying to relive past glories, especially music and movies.  Most of the money being made in the music industry is reissues, HDCD releases of well-known titles, delux reissues, legacy reissues, offical releases of bootlegs, greatest hits, and any and all repackaging of classic albums.  And they all use well known, classic, big name artists, because they know people will buy it.  Because the majority of new CDs, and new artists aren't of any real quality, they have to rely on the old stuff to make money.  The same can be said of the movies.  It's all sequels, prequels, remakes, and remodels.Accordingly, I was not thrilled when I heard a new version of "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" was coming out.  When I learned it was a Tim Burton/Danny Elfman/Johnny Depp production, I was less skeptical.  When I saw a trailer, I was interested.  When I heard Danny Elfman was writing/composing the music AND doing the vocals, I was excited.  The collaboration is great, almost to the point of excusing all their pretensiousness and self-absorbtion...  enough quibbling.  On to the movie!It holds many of Tim Burton's staples; it is dark, stark, eerie, and filled with the regular unnamable props, but he has allowed joy into the equation.  The movie is much better for it.  There is rich color, specifically in the factory, to match the rich imagery and funny comparisons of Willy Wonka.  Depp is cast perfectly in this role, which is not really apparent unless you see the movie.  He is funny, quirky, confused, and innocent; much different than the brilliant, strong character played by Gene Wilder in the original.  The children who find the golden tickets and their parents do a great job too.  Perhaps my favorite part is the wild card, Danny Elfman.  If you don't know WHO Elfman is, you're sure to have heard his music whether in any number of cult classic 80's films (Pee Wee's Big Adventure, Beetlejuice, Batman 1 & 2), his TV themes (The Simpsons), his musical-esque movies featuring his vocals (Nightmare Before Christmas-- an absolute classic soundtrack), or his 15-plus years of work as the vocalist/writer/guitarist for 80's heavyweight Oingo Boingo.  "Charlie" is the 11th time Tim Burton has used Elfman as his composer, and this is arguably their greatest work together (though I prefer "Nightmare Before Christmas").The movie itself is quite interesting, moving into parts of the Willy Wonka story the orignal movie didn't, relying more on the Ron Dahl book.  Note: even the lyrics to the four Oompa-Loompa songs are the lyrics from the novel.  We learn that Willy became a chocolateer to spite his father and is forever haunted by this falling out.  An eventual redemtion of their relationship serves as a very positive pro-family element.  Best of all, it's clean.  Nothing negative, offensive, or disturbing is presented, meaning a green light for families and kids; a HUGE plus.  The only problem with this version is the lacking special features,  but the casual viewer can always live without them, making for a less expensive buy.  A great, big, fun movie.Overall:  9 out of 10.

reviewText: MOVIE: The film opens to a montage of chocolate being made within the factory with the trademark Burton style and the trademark Elfman music. First off we must establish that this movie is aimed at the younger crowd, but I think Depp drew in the older crowd which led to the massive box office success. A lot of people compare this vision to the novel, but I like to look at the classic 1971 version of Roald Dahl's novel. The two are very different movies. Mel Stuart's Willy Wonka & The Chocolate Factory was much more subtle and a tad bit mysterious. When we see Tim Burton's version it is much more whimsical, zany, and very loud. Burton opens the film with Charlie living in his crooked house (all to similar to Big Fish) down the road from the massive factory.  In Burton's version we get much more backstory about the character of Willy Wonka, we understand why he closed off his factory and why he went into seclusion and that turns out to be the downfall of the movie in an artistic sense. The movie is very entertaining, and it is laugh out loud at times, but in the end that's all that it is. We lose the idea that this is a satire on the way children are raised in today's society. The Oompa Loompa songs have now become broadway musicals instead of quirky rhymes with a point to be made. At times you can barely understand the lyrics of the songs, and that is where the film's message lies.  Burton presents Wonka as a man who is still just a child inside, who is struggling with his lost childhood and strict father.  In the orginal film the audience never really figured out the character of Willy Wonka, and that is why I prefer Gene Wilder's brilliant performance over Johnny Depp's extravagent wardrobes and make-up.  Gene Wilder had a presence, he had joy watching all those kids fall one at a time because he despised their attitudes as well as their parents. Johnny Depp may as well be one of the kids, it looks as if he is enjoying all the sparks and whistles more than seeing that these kids are learning the reality of things, which is the whole point that I feel is being missed.  I like how Tim Burton makes London covered in a blanket of snow, all white, and absent of any color except for the browns on the houses. The moment the doors open to Wonka's factory we are ambushed not only with color from Wonka's wacky wardrobe, but with a visual feast for the eyes within the factory itself.  The movie closes back outside the wintry white city and the character of Willy Wonka does go through a change. But is that really the character we are focusing on? I thought the children were supposed to learn something, not Willy Wonka? Gene Wilder's Willy Wonka already knew everything the kids did, and that was the reason he tested them with the everlasting gobstopper. This movie throws that idea out completely. All in all, it was a fun ride to be had but it feels just like another product of Hollywood. It lost the magic and heart that the original had, and I think it missed the point that Roald Dahl was trying to make.ACTING: Johnny Depp is great actor, everyone knows that. He adds a wacky spin to Willy Wonka that will remind you all too much of Michael Jackson. He is the star of the movie, I believe the next star is Deep Roy. The little man who was cast as every Oompa Loompa you see on screen. I guess it was an easy job since all he had to do was learn the dances and do them on a green screen, he didn't even have to sing.  All the vocals to the Oompa Loompa songs were provided by Danny Elfman, who also did the singing voice of Jack in Tim Burton's A Nightmare Before Christmas. Then we come to the children who I thought were horribly done, all except for Charlie Bucket played by Freddie Highmore. I thought the parents were jokes as well, we see more of the children than the parents and that's a flaw. The original focused on the parents much more because it was the fault of the parents that caused their children to be spoiled.BOTTOM LINE: It may sound like I hated the movie, but I really enjoyed it. I thought it was funny and entertaining, but I'm just not pleased that movies today are lacking in social commentaries. The original was able to be fun yet still have a very strong commentary. I also liked Gene Wilder's mysterious and menacing Wonka versus Depp's squeaky voiced and pale Wonka. I think A.O Scott of The New York Times hit the nail on the head when he called Tim Burton's Charlie & The Chocolate Factory ". . . wonderous and flawed."
summary: A Wonderous & Different Vision of Roald Dahl's Novel

reviewText: Tim Burton's adaptation of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is nicely Roald Dahlish, while making Wonka's backstory nicely Burtonish. Deep Roy as all of the Oompa Loompas really is the best feature of the feature.Some of Dahl's more technically difficult scenes make it into this version, like the Chocolate Palace and the factory squirrels. The film contains a more solid end than the original, or the book (which hooks into the sequel "Charlie and Glass Elevator." Burton stays safely away from the 34 year-old classic, as Depp avoids any immiation of Wilder's performance.The film is good family fair, if over-grand "eye-candy."

reviewText: Tim Burton has almost always managed to please me with his directorial turns.  The only film of his that I haven't enjoyed was "Batman Returns," because I felt he took a little too much artistic license on that one.  In "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory," we have a twisted children's tale that seems to be tailored to Burton's vision.I'll bet that most folks are more familiar with the Gene Wilder "Wonka" of years past instead of Roald Dahl's wonderful book.  With that in mind, I'll use the Wilder feature for comparison.  First off, Johnny Depp is pretty good as Wonka.  He's somewhat creepy, with a look and tone almost like Michael Jackson.  He doesn't care for families that much, due to his own sick childhood.  In fact, he's more like a grown-up Peter Pan.  He seems to want to live in a fantasy world where he rules with a sugar-coated smile.The rest of the cast is nice.  The kid who plays Charlie has wonderful appeal.  Veruca Salt, Violet Beauregard, and Mike Teavee are also cast very well.  They are brats, and fit this story well.  The only kid I had a problem with was Augustus Gloop.  He almost looked fake.  He had a Wesson-like glow to his skin that made him appear unnatural and disturbing.  The adults were cast pretty good also.The Oompa Loompas were peculiar.  They shared the same face and were much smaller than the ones in the old version of the film.  I did enjoy their musical numbers in this flick more than in the original.The fates of each of the bratty children were well executed, but might scare the little ones.Overall, this is a twisted look at a story that was already twisted.  I enjoyed it, but I don't know how well it will go over with other folks.  For the adults in the audience, it's probably going to be a walk down memory lane.  For children uninitiated, it might be a little bit too different than their modern, politically-correct world where everybody's a winner and nobody's a bad person.Tim Burton is creepy.  I don't think anyone would argue with me on that.  In turn, he makes "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" even creepier.  Recommended for families with older kids(5 and up) since a few of the scenes(especially the demise of Veruca Salt) may come across a little bit too scary for the young'uns.
summary: A Twisted Look At An Already Twisted Tale

reviewText: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is the second time Tim Burton approaches Roald Dahl's creations, but it is his first time as a director.  Despite being the first time, as a director, there is something strikingly similar between Burton and Dahl if one looks away from the fact that one is a filmmaker and the other an author, and it is their unique way of telling a tale.  Dahl's many stories are mysterious, clever, and have valuable lessons, as do Burton's films.  Both storytellers convey moral lessons for any individual regardless of age, gender, and ethnicity.  This time Burton directs Charlie and the Chocolate Factory with the full approval of Felicity, Dahl's widow, and he captures the same puzzling world that Dahl once created through a grand adventure containing sweets and moral lessons.Freddie Highmore plays the main character, Charlie Bucket, a boy from a poverty stricken family where the parents nurture all four bedridden grandparents.  Charlie is polite, honorable, and noble, qualities that he most likely has acquired from his loving parents and guiding grandparents.  Nothing seems to touch the family, as they always see the glass as half full.  The Bucket family recognizes that money, possessions, and power do not grant them happiness.  The only thing that makes them truly happy is the love that they have for each other. It is announced to the world that Willy Wonka, the refined and enigmatic chocolatier, will invite five children that find five golden tickets to his factory.  These golden tickets can be found in his chocolate bars and they will provide entrance to his secretive chocolate factory to which no human has entered for years.  When Charlie hears about this he cannot help but dream of entering the factory up the street, and his birthday is just around the corner, which means that he will get a Wonka chocolate bar.In the meantime, Charlie and the folks in the small and raggedy Bucket residence will learn about who and how others have gained access to Wonka's chocolate factory.  Each of the lucky ticket winners brings up different notions of disrespectfulness, which further seems to stem from the seven deadly sins: pride, envy, gluttony, lust, anger, greed, and sloth.  These children are obvious in their character, as they might overtly express two or three of the deadly sins.  However, a younger audience will most likely not recognize the seven deadly sins, but it is nonetheless clear that these ticket winners are rude and have very bad manners.  The film even goes as far as openly suggesting the source, poor parenting.After an extensive introduction of the other characters, which is essential, as the film deals with what is right and wrong in the light of the consequences of being good, or bad, comes the biggest surprise, or maybe not as Charlie discovers the fifth and final ticket.  Together with Grandpa Joe (David Kelly) Charlie gladly leads into the legendary chocolate factory, as the other four children walk ahead of their parents into an adventure that will separate the good from the bad.  It is here, a good chunk into the film, where Willy Wonka (Johnny Depp) appears for the first time.Willy Wonka displays an overtly bizarre appearance with a large white smile and eccentric mannerisms that continue throughout the film.  Depp does an extraordinary job in bringing out an aloof and awkward character that frequently seems to drift off to some unknown time and place while standing among his newly arrived guests.  Those viewers who have seen Depp in other films will not identify this character from any of his previous performances.  It is also clear that Burton and Depp have a special relationship, as this is their fourth film and soon the public can see their fifth upcoming puppet film, Corpse Bride (2005).  Depp simply elevates the story far beyond mediocrity into the bizarre fantasy world where Burton seems to be most comfortable where the audience can relinquish it's thoughts completely to the filmmakers performances and storytelling.In 1971 Mel Stuart made Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory based on the same book, which for many has gained a status close to immortality in the world of cinema history.  Despite the notion of remaking an already good film, Burton forcefully delivers his version of the story with the help of a tremendous cast and spectacular cinematography that delivers a fantastic tale.  The film succeeds in reaching the level of the previous film from 1971 and with ease passes the former film based on Dahl's story of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.  This film should certainly gain a nod in the Oscars for the best writing and screenplay based on material previously produced or published.  Burton's film grasps the issues in an easily understandable manner which can be understood by both young and old, which does not leave anyone behind.  Yet, Burton leaves a little extra for the adult audience to ponder while also considering the youth by offering them several thoughtful lessons.  In the end, Burton's film delivers a tale that Dahl would have approved of, as it has all the genuine tangibles of both storytellers.
summary: A Sweet Tale with Breathtaking Imagery...

reviewText: Or, at least it is one of my favorite movies of all time. Everybody is cast very well, and I guess this is just one of those movies where you just love them to death, and I certainly do. This movie has everything you could want from the genre: Comedy, mystery, peculiarness, CGI effects, and beautiful sets. I just can't quite explain "Charlie and The Chocolate Factory" because it already seems to do everything for itself when you watch it.Johnny Depp is very well cast as the suspicious Willy Wonka who has been a recluse for 15 years in his chocolate factory. That's another glorious thing about Tim Burton's films is that they normally revolve around outsiders that are much different than they appear, but that's besides the point. Tim Burton is my favorite director and I think this movie was perfectly done, and I'm probably one out of few people who love both movie versions of the book. Deep Roy plays the oompa-loompas all by himself and performs their songs well in dance and tune, also. They all sound very different from each other, but maybe they're supposed to. I actually haven't read the entire book myself but I have skimmed through it a couple of times and it resembled both movies to me, and most people have compared at how close this was to it, but I don't really care. This is just one of my favorites out of many movies that are my favs, and I will continue to love it as much as I do now and might even grow to keep loving it even more. You just have to see it to believe it.
summary: My favorite movie of all time!

reviewText: i found this movie to be nothing what i expected. obviously hoping that it'd be a fun, updated wacky (Burtonish?) version of the original... I instead came upon a strange, unfunny retelling of our beloved first film. and please don't misunderstand... i absolutely love Tim Burton and his films, and am one of Johnny Depp's biggest fans... yet i found Depp's performance awkward, and the film itself not warm, endearing or funny.and what was with the single computer-cloned oompa loompa? and the overly serious child contestants? in the original they may have been brats, but at least they were funny. everything has such a serious, somber overtone here...i guess it's worth a look, maybe a rental, but overall for me, this was a real disappointment. please go find Gene Wilder instead. that's your true Wonka story.

reviewText: "Charlie And The Chocolate Factory" is impressive! Johnny Depp is eccentricly brilliant as Willy Wonka and Freddie Highmore is an impressive Charlie Bucket. Tim Burton's directing is excellent. The visual effects are impressive and Oscar-worthy. The screenplay by John August, based on the novel by Roald Dahl, is excellent. The music by Danny Elfman is excellent and stays with you even after the movie is over. The cinematography by Philippe Rousselot is excellent and remarkable. The film editing by Chris Lebenzon is excellent. The casting by Susie Figgis is excellent. The production design by Alex McDowell is impressive and a feast for the eyes. It is also Oscar-worthy, as well. The art direction by Francois Audouy, Sean Haworth, James Lewis, Andy Nicholson, Kevin Phipps (senior art director), Stuart Rose, and Leslie Tomkins is also impressive and a feast for the eyes and is Oscar-worthy, as well. The set decoration by Peter Young is just as impressive and is also a feast for the eyes and is also Oscar-worthy, as well. The costume design (Oscar nominated) by Gabriella Pescucci is excellent. This is one of the year's best! It is also an excellent remake to the original "Willy Wonka And The Chocolate Factory" (1971), as well.
summary: "Charlie And The Chocolate Factory" is impressive!

reviewText: I disregarded all the previews and intentionally avoided rewatching the Gene Wilder version. I like the Wilder version, but I thought it would be to my advantage to go in with a clean slate.  I went for Tim Burton, and Tim Burton alone. First I must agree with Roger Ebert about Depp looking and sounding like Michael Jackson. I'd been saying that from the first time I saw a preview.Everything in the film seems at odds with everything else. Depp makes your skin crawl(don't take that as a slam against the man's entire career.) The Oompa-Lumbaas are overly obnoxious and their songs are for the most part annoying and unmemorable. Sometimes I had a hard time discerning the lyrics, but from the ones I did hear I gather I didn't miss much.As for Tim Burton-his contributions seemed the most out-of-place. The beginning scenes might as well have had "Tim Burton" stamped across them. The setting is dreary but hopeful. Then we enter the factory and I was hoping for a pastel dreamscape, not unlike those in "Edward Scissor-Hands"  "Pee-Wee's Big Adventure" and "Big Fish". Instead, we get a loud, garish, overwhelming world painted with hot pinks and electric blues-some of it is actually a little ugly. Most of it, though is impressive to look at, but it's sort of like getting a present wrapped with bright wrapping paper that conceals a rather disappointing gift.
Title: N/A

reviewText: When Tim Burton and Johnny Depp teams up, they usually provide a darkly entertaining, but enchanting film.  Depp somehow looks great in Burton's dark blue lighting and macabre shapes.  Edward Scissorshand and Sleepy Hollow are some of their signature collaborations so far.  But, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory in dark blue and bebop music???  It may work, thanks in part to a very talented Johnny Depp, who was over-the-top in Pirates of the Carribbean.  The technicolor-crazed bright look of the Wilder film  and a too subtle Willy Wonka gave the film a family, almost toy-like feel.  Burton and Dep may just get older audiences like teens to 25 year olds to become fans of children's book author Dahl, who has created some of the most quirkiest characters in literature. On the other hand, it may be a horrible remake like Scooby Doo.  But looking at Burton and Depp's track record with Big Fish and Pirates, I think this film will do just fine.  And Burton is the director to provide the magic to this perennial children's favorite.  Other recommendations:  Lemony Snicket and Harry Potter.
summary: Fan of Depp and Burton, maybe for Charlie?
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was never uncertain of Burton's capability to pull together this movie. The book's satirical and playful twisted ness fits right into Burton's M.O (BATMAN, EDWARD SCISSORHANDS and SLEEPY HOLLOW are some of my favorite movies) It is quite evident that Burton had a vision is his mind for this film and for the most part he delivers a fun and satisfying film that serves for vast escapism, even though we have seen most of the content previous to in the original. While we've heard the story before and know exactly what happens to each character, it is still fun to get a tour of Wonka's factory through Burton's vision. The set crew has crafted some visually astounding sets from the Bucket's home to the colorful factory. Scenes that we will recall from the original, such as the boat ride, are more fun and exciting to watch. The original was very somber, but here things are pretty fast paced.With the exception of Depp playing Wonka, all the actors/actresses are duplicating the roles of the characters in the original. Each child plays up their signature bad character trait and Freddie Highmore is perfect as Charlie. Helena Bonham Carter is always a delight in Burton's films and does well here as Charlie's mother. It is Depp's performance that is significantly dissimilar from his counterpart. I believe Depp to be one of the most excellent character actors in Hollywood at this time. He adapts well and commits to his characters. Depp opted to go for the same sarcastic oddity we found with Wilder's Wonka, and his performance was excellent. Danny Elfman's fantastic musical score drives the film in a way that makes every musical scene even more magical. Conceivably an even more perfect team than Depp and Burton is Elfman and Burton, bouncing personalities off each other to create a brilliant mix of offbeat charm that never fails to amuse.Thankfully, the lamentful singing is replaced by the eccentric Oompa Loompa musical numbers. Each number is different and completely funny to watch. Lastly, what is also fun about this film is that you can see glimpses of Burton's other films on display here. The opening credits, which consist of a tour through Wonka's odd chocolate bar assembly line, reminded me a lot of the cookie maker machine in EDWARD SCISSORHANDS. Also, the Bucket's house looks like it was straightforwardly lifted out of BIG FISH with its odd slant. Just a few things Burton added in to bring together his style. In the end, CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY'S plot is reused from the original, but what else did you expect. A few things have been changed to follow more closely to the book. The film is fun, colorful and entertaining. Already pulling in the punters, Willy Wonka is sure to be one of the biggest films of this year.
summary: One of the best movies of 2005

reviewText: A pallid Willie Wonka (Johnny Depp) is an androgynous eccentric chocholateer who, with the help of Oompa Loompas (Deep Roy), is simultaneously teaching moral lessons in excess and respect to five children (and their mentors) while learning the same himself from an underprivileged little boy named Charlie Bucket (Freddie Highmore). The many choreographic technical masterpieces are appreciated even more after viewing the detailed behind-the-scenes bonus features on the DVD. Charlie is a stark contrast to outre characters with equally outlandish sets comprising the bulk of the movie. Children will find delight in the characters. Adults may highlight the morality while enjoying some of the tongue-in-cheek humor. As someone aptly said, this movie is literal eye candy for the family.Movie quote: "There's plenty of money out there. They print more of it every day. But that ticket? There are only five of them in the world, and that's all there's ever going to be. Only a dummy would give this up for something as common as money. Are you a dummy?"

reviewText: In the last two weeks, I have seen three different versions of CHARLIE & THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY; the two feature films and one youth play.  All three are based on the popular book and all three put their own spin on the clever tale.  The new version reunites long-time work pals Tim Burton and Johnny Depp.  The previews would make you believe that the 2005 remake is way overdone with computer imagery and overacting.  However, in some cases, the opposite is true.  The new computerized graphics are not overly distracting and feed the chocolate frenzy well.  It's Johnny Depp that, surprisingly, seems low-key for a character that has been presented in a much more bizarre way than when Gene Wilder filled Wonka's hat.  His reactions often don't feel like they are in direct response to the events that are taking place.  Many times, I felt like I was watching the dress rehearsal, as opposed to the final film.  That said, the movie leaves you with primarily the same feeling that you get if you were to just throw the 1971 version into your DVD player.  Both have elements that are amusing, and they both have elements that are odd.  The only real difference is that the 2005 version tries to stick closer to the original book, but then breaks free whenever it becomes too much of a shadow of the previous film.  You won't be disappointed by the new version, but chances are, you won't be overwhelmed either.  If I were to pick one as better than the other, I think I would have to go for Gene Wilder's more carefree presentation over Johnny's cynical approach.

reviewText: I saw Willy Wonka movie when I was child and fell in love with the movie, so I decided to watch this Charlie movie when it came out on DVD.  Even though lot of the reviewers gave a bad rating for this movie, I wanted to rent it and see it for myself.  While I was watching the movie, I could not help but keep saying to myself in my head the word "strange" over and over again.  I don't know how else to describe this movie.  The original movie took my breath away when the children first walked into the Willy Wonka factory, but in the Charlie movie, I thought the whole thing looked more fake then anything else, especially the grass part.  Some of the reviewers kept saying that Johnny Dep was not Willy Wonka, but it was the little kid Charlie that had grown up.  Then why did all the kids and the local towns people call him Willy?  Why did that little kid who went into the facotory was named Charlie?  Johnny Depp did played the part of Willy Wonka, because as you can see in the movie that this movie explained how Willy became Willy Wonka the candy maker.  This was the only part of the movie that I liked, because it explained little about Willy's child hood and how it all got started.  The part that I thought it was a little extremem was where the kids are walking through the Charlie factory, and you see a cow all strapped up getting whipped with wips over and over again.  Then, Charlie says "oh, I get it, a whiped milk".  I thought to myself "is this a kid's movie?"  I can just see bunch of kids running to a cow and start beating the cow with their dad's belt trying to get whipped milk.  I thought that was a little violent and was not necessary.  Also, this movie showed Willy arguing with little kids, or saying sarcastic remarks alot.  I liked the original Willy Wonka, because the character was belivable and likable.  This one with Johnny Depp, was not likable but just strange and bizzard.  Johnny Depp should stick with making movies like Pirates of Carribean.  I loved the Oompa music in the original one, but just end up hating it in this movie.  The music was not very catchy at all.  Does anyone who has seen the movie even remember one song from this movie?  Also, I thought when the last part where it showed Willy Wonka's elavator taking off the roof was a good idea, because it actually explained where they went when they took off from the eleavator, the original ended after taking off the elavator but did not explaine where they went.Spoiler!But, after seeing where they went, I just rolled my eyes.  The elavator crashed into Charlie's home.  I thought that they would just let the elavator down gently next to Charlie's home, but no they crashed through the roof.  I am supriesed that they didn't end up killing someone.  I thought this movie was not for kids at all, well at least not for really young kids.  I do regreat renting this movie.
