reviewText: Willie Wonka, Willie Wonka,The amazing chocolatier.Willie Wonka, Willie Wonka,Everybody give a cheer.He's modest, clever and so smartHe barely can restrain itWith so much generosityThere is no way to contain it!To contain it,To contain, to contain, to contain!Hooray!For those of us that grew up with "Willie Wonka & the Chocolate Factory" it is hard to approach "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" and not start doing the Oompa Loompa song from the former every time the computer cloned Deep Roy shows up in the latter.  I must admit to having not yet read Roald Dahl's original book to include it in the mix as well, and while I am sure that makes a difference to the millions who have, I would not be one of that number (although certainly I am curious as to how this movie will imprint on young children for whom this is their first cinematic trip to the Chocolate Factory).The justification for "remaking" the classic Gene Wilder film is established in the title, which indicates that this time the story is more about Charlie Bucket (Freddie Highmore) than it is about Willie Wonka (Johnny Depp).  That things will be different this time is not do so much that despite the above ditty and the Oompa Loompa's singing commentary on the demises of each of the other children this is not a musical, but that Tim Burton is the director.  As soon as you see the sorry state of the Bucket's shack it is clear this is one of his films, and the Teutonic architecture of the Chocolate Factory and the gardens of earthly delights inside is only more evidence for the inevitable conclusion that Burton is the perfect director for Dahl's story.Actually I liked the parts of this 2005 that took place outside the Chocolate Factory more than the trip inside, which is partially because basically the same things happen to the other kids that happened in the other film (and, I believe I can safely presume, in Dahl's book).  Before the journey inside Charlie's grandparents keep trying to steal all of the scenes inside the shack, but there is something endearing about a poor but happy family (think the Cratchits with another generation thrown into the mix, albeit all in one bed).  However, the best part of the film comes at the end when we go beyond the happy ending of the original film, and not just because it is something different.Freddie Highmore provides the same sort of simple, naturalistic performance he did in "Finding Neverland."  Consequently he makes Charlie a rather ordinary good kid, so that he comes out ahead on his own and not simply by default because the other children are such brats.  I found Johnny Depp's peculiar way of speaking as Willie Wonka to be pretty effective (clearly he is in his own little world) and commiserate with the focus this time around on Charlie rather than the chocolate maker.  As for the idea that Depp's performance is based on Michael Jackson, I have to say that I do not see it.  The pale skin is because Willie Wonka never goes outside into the sun and if such pigmentation was enough to invoke the new man without a country then Burton's "The Corpse Bride" represents Jacko-mania.  Depp's Wonka is a strange little man, who is not particularly endearing, which is exactly what is required for most of the proceedings.
summary: It really is more about Charlie than Willie Wonka this time around

reviewText: Neither Burton's Alice in Wonderland nor Charlie & the Chocolate Factory qualify as "remakes" because they are based on the books & not older movies, but Frankenweenie 2012 will qualify as a remake.In order for this to be a remake of Willy Wonka, it would have to  not be based on a common source material, have the same music, & not diverge in characters or story. This is simply a different "version" of the same story, only this one is not as loosely adapted as Willy Wonka.Personally I love both movies equally. Burton's has the hotter quirkier Wonka with father issues & a far less annoying Charlie. The secondary characters were cleverly modernized from the 60s book & made to address certain unhealthy addictions, but the music is horrible & just using one guy for all the Oompa Loompas was lame when many actors of short stature would have loved to have been in it; just as bad as Peter Jackson not using real little people to play Hobbits & Dwarves. WW has the funnier Wonka, though with less background & character development, & fantastic music but with a less interesting ending. It's pretty much impossible for Gene Wilder not to be funny.Imagine how much darker C&TCF; & AiW would have been if not produced by Disney & if Burton had actually written the scripts himself. Author Ronald Dahl, creator of the source material, would have loved that, because he despised the 70s movie for it's divergence & lightheartedness, so much so that he denied the rights to make a movie of Charlie & the Great Glass Elevator, which is a pity because the music would have been great & it would have been one more Gene Wilder movie to enjoy.

reviewerName: Linda Lou "Obsessive reader, 6-10 books a wee...
reviewText: I really tried hard not to like this movie, believing it to be for the kiddies, but it turned out to be a really pleasant surprise. Gene Wilder's "Willie Wonka & The Chocolate Factory" was tongue-in-cheek delightful in 1971 and, here, Tim Burton creates another masterful rendition - without LSD!!Young Freddie Highmore as Charlie Bucket is a refreshingly unpretentious child, with a wide-eyed innocence, a rarity among today's movie youth. I'm so sick of Haley Joel Osment (whose transformation from a child to a teen actor is as squeeky as his voice change) and Dakota Fanning (she's already developed the Hollywood Red Carpet fake-me-out "Opened Mouth Molar Exposing Smile" and "The Left Leg Crossed Over The Right From The Crotch" pose of her older contemporaries). The fabulous Helena Bonham Carter portrays a down-and-out mother with the same English grace and delicance as she does a noblewoman. But, it's under-rated actor Gordeep "Deep" Roy, cloned into a kazillion cavity-creating Oompa-Loompas, who really steals the show. He rocks more latex here than a Trojan factory!It's obvious that Johnny Depp puts a lot of thought into the roles that he chooses and he's not ashamed to just act a fool as evidenced by "Ed Wood" and "Pirates of the Caribbean". But, in the wake of the Michael Jackson scandals, Johnny Depp's domino-toothed Willie Wonka is a tad disturbing. I mean, holding a contest to lure young children "to tour your playland" doesn't really work for me right now.However, in the spirit of the 1964 book by British writer Roald Dahl, I decided not to be too literal in watching this. I just got out a pint of Haagen-Dazs ice cream, added a double-dose of hot fudge and a whole can of whipped cream, put on my bunny slippers, and enjoyed the ride.

reviewText: Since I was about four years old I remember watching the 1971 version of "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory".  I did not actually read the book until I was about sixteen.  Realizing that there were some major dispensaries between the text and that film adaptation, I began to enjoy it less and less.  I understand that book to movie adaptations are going to have many differences, and that does not bother me.  I suppose it was more that as I grew older, the 1971 version became kind of hokey.  It has its highlights and will remain a favorite of mine, but I was excited to see a new version coming out.The first thing you need to do before you see this movie is read the book.  It is very short, and about 80 pages.  If only to appreciate some of the things that are more accurately portrayed in this movie.  I actually do understand why many changes in the original film adaptation were made.  The squirrels were not at the time a very possible scene to put into film without the capabilities of CGI.  So, I understand the change to the geese, however, it is a delight to see it as it was originally envisioned in Dahl's book.  It is one of the best scenes in the movie.The film, from the beginning starts out quite a bit darker than the 1971 version.  This is after all a Tim Burton film, a man known for his dark yet colorful and flamboyant visuals.  This is Burton in top form, visuals in this really fit the tone of the book much better than did the 1971 version.  By the time we are introduced to Charlie we really understand how broke his family really is.  The house is dilapidated and falling apart, there is a hole in the roof above Charlie's head where he sleeps and every days they eat cabbage soup.  This is starkly contrasted with Wonka's factory and the other four children's decadent life-styles.The added details to the story and background of the character of Willy Wonka add a lot more depth to the character and actually makes sense of why he acts the way he does.  Although the parts with his father (played by Christopher Lee) were not in the book, they are some of the most enjoyable parts in the movie.  Watching Christopher Lee play Wilber Wonka, Willy Wonka's dentist father is absolutely a delight.  With such quotable lines as "Lollipops, what dentist call cavities on a stick." The theme of family ties and loyalty are much more clear in this version, and Charlie is a wiser person than the other children because rather than disregard his family and everyone else around them for a lifetime of chocolate, he puts his family and others first.  Something the 1971 film really missed the mark on with the inclusion of a scene where Charlie drinks the fizzy lifting drink.The performance by Johnny Depp is creepy and off-putting on one hand, but touching on the other, as we understand his pain and why he rejects parents because of the own rejection that he faced as a child.  Every character including the grand parents are used to greater effect here than in the 1971 film as well.  Every actor is perfectly cast, especially Freddie Highmore as Charlie, Jordan Fry as Mike Teavee, Anna-Sophia Rob as Violet, and Deep Roy as all of the Oompa Lommpas.This film is not so much a children's movie this go around as it has an abundance of dark humor that will go over children's heads, humor, which will make it  more enjoyable for adults.  At the same time, it is for this very reason that people who enjoyed the original version, do not enjoy this one, this film does not have quite the same feeling of wonderment that the 1971 film has, and for all the faithfulness to the text and intent of the author that this one has, there is one thing the 1971 film has over this one, and it is big; it is that it created a sense of anitcipation and mystery before he entered the factory and a sense of wonder and amazement when Charlie entered the factory.Since both film adaptations of "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" are equally enjoyable, but for starkly contrasting reasons, it is easy to see why people are generally divided in to camps with these adaptations.God Bless ~Amy
summary: On the Whole, Much More Faithful to the Book than the 1971 Version.

reviewerName: Livin' La Vida Low-Carb Man "Jimmy Moore"
reviewText: Like so many others, I thought Tim Burton's bold move to take on one of the classic films of all-time was going to crash and burn in his face.  Who else could EVER be Willy Wonka except for Gene Wilder?  I mean the man's entire career was predicated on that ONE role that he performed so masterfully complete with strange personality and a song or two to boot!But imagine my surprise when I decide to buy the Burton-version of "Charlie & The Chocolate Factory" with Johnny Depp as Willy Wonka.  As I watched this film, I couldn't believe that the actor playing Wonka was the same man who played in "Pirates of the Carribean!"  Depp's wide range of acting skills is amazing!From the high-pitched voice to the nervous words and actions, Depp's portrayal of Wonka reveals a much more psychologically-challenged man who we get to see a glimpse of what made him that way through frequent flashbacks to his childhood.  I rather enjoyed this aspect of the movie because it filled in some blanks that were left unaccounted for in the original.As it turns out, Charlie (played by an adorable young actor with an excellent British accent) helps Wonka resolve the issues he had with his own childhood and bring resolution to years of trying to prove he was right after all.  Excellent storyline!Even if you are a big fan of the original film like I was, you need to get this one, too!  Burton was brilliant and Depp was delightful!  A great addition to your DVD library!
summary: Big Fan Of Original, But Depp's Wonka Was Much Deeper

reviewText: I walked out of Tim Burton's remake of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory amused, but unsatisfied, and certainly not how I'd expect to feel after eating one of Mr. Wonka's scrumptdiliumptious treats. Sure, there were moments of crunchy goodness, but most of the experience involved the fancy wrapping.Mr. Burton's hit or miss storytelling (he can be terrific, as in Big Fish, or horrific, as in Planet of the Apes), mainly misses here. But that isn't the worst of it.  The biggest failure of the film is Willy Wonka himself. He is a character of little or no substance, inexplicable and odd for the sake of being inexplicable and odd.  As if in a last ditch effort to give the guy some depth, this hackneyed backstory about his father (who, irony of ironies, was a dentist) was spliced in through flashbacks that might be interesting if they weren't so one-dimensional.  Instead, they do little more than interrupt the flow of the story and set up an anti-climactic ending in which Willy resolves his issues with his father by visiting him.I must confess that I really like the original film version of the story. And it is in contrast to that gem of a film that the weaknesses of Burton's version stand out.  The Charlie of the first movie isn't a uni-dimensional angel (selfless, unflappable, never tempted), and his character is defined by a remarkable ending that offers him more temptation than even the best child ought to be able to resist.  The new Charlie, well, is perfect, start to finish.  Where's the challenge (and character development) in that?  Burton eschewed the important story features (the Slugworth bribe offers) that made the trip through the chocolate factory a rolling moral conundrum.  Burton offers no replacement story device to preserve this important subplot (instead, we get the Wonka backstory). One point of dissonance, though, is the scene in which Charlie finds a ten dollar bill in the snow and, without a second thought, uses it to buy candy. With the set up that Charlie is completely selfless, and that even a thin dime might help his starving, destitute family, his decision to keep and use the money was jarring. What lesson are we to take away from this?  Finders keepers?  (In the original film, Charlie finds a coin in a gutter ... a coin is one thing; a ten dollar bill quite another. Inflation isn't the answer. If Burton had thought about it, he might have had Charlie give the money to the candy store owner to await a claim by the real owner, and perhaps been given a candy bar as a reward.)Wilder's performance was one of depth and substance. Even without a backstory, you come away knowing exactly who Willy Wonka is: an extremely smart, wise, and artistic man who is on a mission to find a truly good kid.  Not a perfect one, mind you (Charlie, after all, stole the Fizzy Lifting Drinks, another episode that doesn't make it to Burton's film), but one of solid, core decency.  Wilder's character's sly comments, his fluency in multiple languages, and his knowing disdain for the creeps who've found his tickets present the picture of a person who ought to be telling us a story of right and wrong, of good kids and bad.  (Burton doesn't even have the sense to realize that it is better that we not know the fate of Charlie's competitors, leaving us to wonder whether they made it or not, and not really caring.  Instead, he leads them out of the factory like a parade of CGI.  Did we need that?  Of course not.)Depp's Wonka doesn't even come close to Wilder's.  He's an empty, Michael Jacksonesque misanthrope without a clue.  He doesn't seem particularly interested in Charlie, or even to recognize what makes Charlie special. They just seem to end up together because everyone else gets taken away. Even at that point, there is no meaningful interaction between them.There were moments of charm and humor in Willy Wonka; a twisted sense of humor infects some good scenes.  But the story is weak, and Willy himself is weaker.  Add to that genuinely uninspired and forgettable songs and dialogue that attempts to "explain" too much, and you have another remake than ought to have stayed unmade.

reviewText: I loved the original film. It was light and fun...great kids movie. I still love it. I found this movie just as good, but completely different. And he has the typical quirkiness of a true genius. Who, in this case puts his driven and strange intellect toward making chocolate.Mr. Burton decided to make the tribe of Oompa-Loompas played by Deep Roy. Who does a great job considering everything that this placed on his shoulders. The lyrics from these songs come right out of the book. But I must admit I had a hard time hearing them with the music chosen. I would have liked to be able to discern the lyric better. Other then that, I thought the movie is great. And I recommend both versions, but only the original one I feel is appropriate for young children.

reviewText: I know, I know.  People use this phrase all the time, but I absolutely mean it.  No movie I know is more charming and wacky than Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.  The acting is top-notch.  Each character lives up to their potential.  The screenplay is superb and Burton's directing is perfect.  I am 100% honest.  This remake, or reimagining, is in all ways better than the original.  Danny Elfman's music is astounding.  Whether it's the song about the downfall of a naughty child or the intro(that gave me the chills, by the way)to this work of art is enchanting in every sense of the word.  If you haven't seen this movie already, see it as soon as possible.  Very likely the best and certainly one of the most memorable movies I've ever seen.
summary: Very Likely My Favorite Movie Of All Time

reviewText: I've never been a fan of Tim Burton.  I've liked very few of his movies.  I thought the Charlie & The Chocolate Factory, along with Johnny Depp could possibly turn things around for me, and it did, in a way... the movie wasn't great, but it also wasn't bad.  It's sort of an in-between movie.There were flashes of brilliance, such as the over the top Oompa Loompa songs (especially the one following Augustus Gloop getting sucked up into the vacuum -- brilliant!), and I also like how this movie went more into detail about why Willy Wonka is the way he is, and why he's obsessed with chocolate.  That was something the original movie completely neglected, and I thought Burton did a great job implementing into the movie.There were also some epic fails, such as the Oompa Loompa's themselves.  Every single Oompa Loompa was the same actor, just CGI'd into a hundred different ones.  The original movie had a bunch of "Little People" playing the part, which I thought was a much better way of going about it.  I also didn't care for some of the obscure Tim Burton oddities, such as the crooked, Sleepy Hollow looking house Charlie's family lived in, amongst other things.  Johnny Depp delivered a pretty solid performance as Willy Wonka, but he didn't even come close to Gene Wilder's portrayal.  Depp in comparison was like comparing a minor leaguer to an All-Star professional.The characters in the movie were excellent. I thought they did a great job with the casting, and the the kids all did great jobs.  I especially liked the new Charlie.  I liked him even better than the original Charlie.  I didn't care for the new Grandpa Joe, however.  Tim Burton, in his typical fashion, picked just about the ugliest man you'll ever see in your life as Grandpa Joe.  He was an eyesore throughout the film.In in all, it was an "ok" movie. It certainly had its moments, and I have watched it 4 or 5 times since it's been released.  I own the DVD, and I can certainly say that it's entertaining to watch.  I just don't think it holds a candle to the original one, which was a masterpiece.  I just think this one fell a bit short.  If it weren't for amazon's flawed ratings system, I'd give this movie 3.5 stars, but it's certainly not a 4 star movie, which is why I gave it 3.
summary: Not a big Tim Burton Fan.... but not too bad.

reviewText: I'm not normally a Tim Burton fan.  Just the previews of his movies usually look weird enough to me that I pass right on by.  But, since this was a new version of one of my favorite books from childhood, I had to give it a chance.To be honest, I've never been a fan of the original movie version, either.  It took too many liberties with the story, changing the entire makeup of Charlie in the process and missing the point of the story.  But that's a rant for a different review.  The reason I bring it up here is because I went into this one hoping to love it and without the baggage of liking the previous one.The story is rather straightforward.  Charlie Bucket comes from a poor family that is barely making ends meet.  It gets even worse after his father looses his job.Charlie loves chocolate, which he gets one day a year - his birthday.  To make matters worse, he lives in the same town as the mysterious Wonka Chocolate Factory, the best candy factory in the world.One day, Willy Wonka announces that he will open his factory to five lucky kids who find the golden tickets in his candy bars.  As the winners come in, they are all selfish, obnoxious children.  Charlie doesn't have a chance of getting to go.  Or does he?  And what wonders await the winners in the factory?The movie is visually stunning.  This is a playground I would love to visit in person.  The colors are vibrant and everything is interesting.  Tim Burton obviously had a wonderful time creating the visuals to match the book.  In addition, much of the humor remains, including great puns and the wonderful scene with the chocolate mansion.Speaking of the book, this movie does a better job of sticking to the story in most areas, but especially in one key area, Charlie.  While he can come across as a goody-two-shoes at times (a problem with the book as well), just about anyone would with the obnoxious brats for comparison.  The original movie tried to fix that problem, but I much prefer him this way.The movie gets so much of the basic plot right, any fan of the book will love it.  With the advance of special effects, the story is brought to visual life in ways that weren't possible 30 years ago when the original came out.  While the characters have been modernized a little, it adds to the story rather then detracts from it.The real problem comes with the added back-story.  Willy Wonka now has a past involving a dentist father who hated candy.  Frankly, it more detracts then adds to the plot since the point of the movie is the wonders of the factory itself.  It also throws in a theme of the importance of family relationships that seems tacked on to the theme we see most of the time about the importance of behavior and manners.Compounding this is Johnny Depp's weird portrayal of Willy Wonka.  I knew from the previews to expect it, but it still was too over the top.  I left the theater wondering why he wanted to open up his factory period.  Granted, the character is supposed to be a crazy eccentric, but he was never this cold and almost creepy.This movie does have many things going for it.  The visuals, characters, and effects are great.  It's less likely to scare kids then the original, too.  Tim Burton's desire to add a back-story ultimately backfired, however, leaving the book as the best way to familiarize yourself with this story.
summary: Better Then the Original, But Still Not the Definitive Take on the Book

reviewText: It took me a long time to get over Depp in 21 Jump Street, 20 years ago.  I'm well over it now, and he just keeps hitting them out of the park as far as I'm concerned.I was a fan of the Gene Wilder film version of this story, and wasn't quite sure how I'd feel about this newer film.  The flick feels like a Tim Burton adventure from the get-go, from the Danny Elfman music to the dumpy, lopsided house in congested isolation right next to the middle of the action, to the dark-yet-lush, Burtonesque colors.It might have been risky casting Freddie Highmore (Depp's young co-star in Finding Neverland) as Charlie, but the young actor was perfect in the role.  In fact, I can't complain about any of the casting.  Helena Bonham Carter was the grunged up, wonderfully understated mom of Charlie, and the boy's whole extended family all fit nicely.  Christopher Lee took his place dutifully and expertly as Willie Wonka's estranged father.  Everything fit here.  The riskiest move was using Deep Roy, long-time English short-guy, as all of the Oompa Loompas, but I believe he pulled it off.Depp, though, carried the movie for me.  He could have been a silly Willie Wonka, or he could have not given nearly enough.  I think that he did a triple flip and stuck it.  He was childishly enthusiastic, wounded, simultaneously guarded and open... and ultimately captivated by young Charlie.
summary: Depp Strikes Gold, Errr... Chocolate with Wonka

reviewText: Johnny Depp normally turns me away from movies.  However, Depp's performance in "Pirates of the Caribbean" was enough to give me reason to cut the guy some slack.  This movie almost takes up all that slack.  But upon reflection, it wasn't Depp's performance that kept me from enjoying this film; it was the slow moving pace of the film itself.I can tell you that this is a fair remake of the classic.  I can tell you second hand that this is a fair version of the original stories by Roald Dahl.  Unfortunately, I can't suggest that you see this film, at least not in theatres.Among it's many problems is how nothing interesting happens in the film.  There are some interesting special effects, and there are some interesting twists and spin-offs from the original film.  But the only thing I got from this film was fatigue.  I remember at one point wanting to walk out of the theatre due to boredom.However, I must admit that I was in the minority on this film.  When the film was over, it received applause in that Midwestern theatre.  I suggest waiting to rent or own.  This movie's above average special effects will work well on a small screen as they do on a large one.

reviewText: I loved this movie as a child.  It had a magical aura about it, with all of the crazy creations in the factory and the eccentric and fascinating Mr. Wonka.This version is a good modern-day representation of the movie.  The sets are outstanding and creatively done.  The Oompa Loompas are slightly more disturbing in this version (which may have something to do with the fact that they're all played by a single actor), but they're entertaining.  There is a slight twist in plot in this version, as you get to delve a bit more deeply into Willy Wonka's childhood, but I feel it works within the story.This movie certainly has the Tim Burton stamp on it.  Even if you didn't know he was the director, you would be able to draw similarities between the feel of this movie and his others such as Edward Scissorhands.  It's worth a watch.

reviewText: Tim Burton's take on the Roald Dahl classic story "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" offers up a mouthful of oh-so-good entertainment for the whole family.  As with most remakes, folks tend to compare the original with the remake.  With this film, there really shouldn't be any of that.  Tim Burton's film based on the story by Mr. Dahl is a unique and fresh take on the story, not a shot for shot remake of the 1971 classic.  Burton's film sets its own course and does a damn fine job of doing so.  The visual look of this film can hardly be put into words but if you had to it would only fit into one: amazing.  The inside of the factory is stunning and breathtakingly beautiful and even the Bucket's modest home holds a certain visual appeal.  The whole visuality of this film has the look of a dream or of another world altogether.  The casting in my humble opinion is the only slight flaw of this film.  The supporting cast was about as good as could be expected but I didn't particularly care for the casting of Grandpa Joe or Charlie.  I loved Johnny Depp as the quirky and wacky Willy Wonka.  His performance flat out makes the film.  His energy and style shine through in every scene he's in.  While watching this film, you almost wanted to be a kid again and be one of those lucky five to walk through the enchanted halls and rooms of the incredible Wonka chocolate factory.  At times it seemed like Depp was a little too Michael Jackson for his own good, but it worked out well in the end.  An outstanding film from start to finish for adults and kids alike, this one will endure for years to come.

reviewText: Now this is the quirky weirdness of Tim Burton at his best. Wash The Planet of the Apes out of your mind before you watch this, and think rather of Edward Scissorhands or Big Fish. As usual, since this film is a remake of a film that is considered classic, it generated much controversy. Why remake a classic? As the filmmakers said, they weren't remaking Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, they were making another adaptation of Roald Dahl's children's novel, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. I consider both films classics. Depp's Wonka is much weirder and less benevolent than Gene Wilder's Wonka, but they both bring Dahl's eccentric character to life in different, but legitimate, ways. The visual world is as odd and fantastic as ever in a Tim Burton film, especially Wonka's factory. One thing I was wondering about was exactly how Burton was going to introduce Wonka. In the original, there is this terrific build-up to the "reveal" of Willy Wonka, where Gene Wilder comes limping out with a cane and his head down, then suddenly rolls into a back flip. I thought, "How will Burton do it? Can he beat that?" Well, he beat it, and the introduction of Wonka to the kids as they approach the factory is perhaps the best moment of the whole film.
summary: Burton and Wonka are both weird

reviewText: Depp almost holds this film together, but the pointless flashbacks and altered ending nearly kill it.Feeling as forced as constipation, sudden, poorly timed, terribly set-up and useless to the story are Wonka's flashbacks. Now Burton didn't change the title, he left Charlies name at the top, not Wonkas and rightfully so, but he turned the focus away from Charlie and to the depraved childhood of Wonka.The flashbacks are not Rould Dahl material, they don't meld into the movie and they don't help. Now, if Candy doesn't have to have a point, why does Willy Wonka??? Seeing him as a kid in braces and a full head brace that holds his mouth open for the supposed benifit of strait teeth, does nothing but distract from the tale of five children that the book was about. Four brats, how they did themselves in and how Charlie never did.Quickly the story feels broken, like the tour is the unimportant part, the five golden ticket holders are secondary characters and it's Wonka's boring, not in the book, childhood that we are supposed to be following.Finally, we get to the "great glass elevator" and realize there is no sequel coming because the thing's way too small. At this point I started loosing hope. I had suffered through three Umpa Loompa songs with music so loud that I couldn't hear the lyrics (lifted, wisely from the book, but set to Seventies-pop grooves for reasons we will never know).Finally the Great Glass Elevator takes off, Charlie learns the factory is his and when we should go get the old folks and parents head into space (and a what-could-have-been sequel) we get a prudish, parent hating Wonka stating that Charlie may not bring his family to the factory. He leaves, alone, then comes back and with Charlie visits his estranged father (and just when I thought the love story in Titanic was forced and fake and a big mistake!) who has been a closet Willy Wonka follower since his son left to make candy (the ultimate sin to Dentist Dad)Now do we blast off? Do we finish the movie with the glorious shot of the elevator ascending into the upper atmosphere? No! We end with all the old folks dressed and out of bed, eating holiday dinner and living in the factory with Charlie and Wonka. Is this ending better? No! It's bland, it's not the story Dahl wrote, it serves no purpose.I am not a book purist, I love the third Harry Potter film more than the more faithful first two, I think LOTR is brilliant and I've read the book 5 times, but with this film the changes where un-called for and distracting, the detracted from the fun of the story.Now, why four stars??? Because if you cut all the Wonka flashbacks you have a near verbatim adaptation of the book, good actors, and lots of entertainment. Just gut 20 minutes of not-in-the-book footage, re-tool the last five minutes to match the book and it's near perfect.
summary: Faithful and fun if they'd cut those distracting extras!

reviewText: I loved the book when I was young, but never really got into the sequel, about the glass elevator. I don't ever remember watching the original with Gene Wilder - but then I don't remember ever watching the original Oliver, but I used to have it taped off the TV, so I guess I must have watched it at some point. It's probably the same for the original.Steve Martin, Robin Williams, Christopher Walken, Nicolas Cage, Will Smith, Brad Pitt, Jim Carrey, Adam Sandler and Michael Keaton were all considered for the role of Willy Wonka. Marilyn Manson also badly wanted the part. I could quite imagine Marilyn Manson in the part actually, but there's something not quite right about Johnny Depp in this. I dunno what it was. Maybe it was because he's not in the least bit attractive in this (you'd have to be of a sick mind to find THAT attractive), or maybe it just didn't work. Tim Burton & Johnny Depp made a pretty good team in other movies, but just not in this one. I think they failed.Also, there was way too many special effects. Not something you would normally complain about, but basically, Tim used every effect in the book. And it's just too glossy in the end. The Oompa-Loompas are very weird also, and the songs were slightly nauseating.However, I did like Freddie Highmore in this - hopefully he won't turn out to be a precocious child actor. I also liked the fact we got a brief glimpse into Willy Wonka's childhood, and how he came to be the master of chocolate. It was quite interesting, but the brace was a little freaky - but apparently, that was taken from Tim's childhood.Also, I loved how the grandparents were brought to life, all those years ago when I first read the book. They were exactly how I imagined them, and it was fabulous.I think the glass elevator was incorporated into this, simply so there wouldn't be a sequel. I'm hoping so anyway, but as I say, I can't remember much of the sequel, because I couldn't get into it. Some of the buttons on the glass elevator say: Incompetent Fools; T-Bone Steak Jell-O; Secretarial Poodles; Cocoa Cats; Mechanical Clouds; Stars in their Pies; Nice Plums; Up And Out; Fragile Egos; Black Box of Frogs; Weird Lollipops; Mighty Jam Monitor; Creative Dog Flip; Elastic Forest; Leaky Canes; Dessert Island; People Poo; Pie Cream; Spewed Vegetables; Naffy Taffy; Lickety Split Peas; Honeycombs and Brushes and Old Sneezes and Smells Dept.It was very faithful to the book, although I think, if I can remember correctly (it has been quite a few years), the ending is a little bit different, as that bit was all new to me.I'm still not sure about Johnny's portrayal of Willy Wonka, it's quite disturbing actually. But I won't let that distract me from an alright film. It was nothing special really, and the OTT special effects, could have been toned down.
summary: Burton went OTT with special effects

reviewText: When I first heard that a re-make of "Chocolate Factory" was being planned with Tim Burton at the helm, I couldn't have been more pleased. I have long been a fan of the book but loathed the 70's treacle of Gene Wilder's film; the forced, insane cheeriness was highly unsuitable for the strange and somewhat sadistic rages against the evils of sloth and spoiledness that Dahl's book comprised. And Johnny Depp's collaborations with Burton have usually produced spectacular results, so I was very pleased to know that he would be starring.Unfortunately, the combination is less than inspired this time. The film's performances range from sketchy to perfection. Bizarrely, Johnny Depp's lands squarely in the middle of the spectrum, hardly something I expected from an actor I consider to be one of the finest...ever. His Wonka is just...weird. And not in a pleasant way. With his pasty skin, strange make-up, alarmingly perfect teeth, and honeyed, meretricious voice and mannerisms, he conjures up disturbing images of Michael Jackson, or perhaps the bizarre love-child of Jackson and Carol Channing. He is certainly a unique character - I've never seen Depp quite like this before - and it's a brave and risky performance, but it is just too freakish to quite be acceptable onscreen. Wonka would certainly be a bizarre social recluse, perhaps even a compulsive performer, but he is also here so weird and even sadistic that I found myself very uncomfortable at the prospect of him sharing space with children, even those as unpleasant as the four obnoxious miscreants. I was also slightly perplexed, too, by the fact that Wonka is seemingly more comfortable with the childrens' guardians than the children themselves; he cannot even bring himself to say the word "parents" and his own familial relationships are strained, to say the least. Given the fact that Burton has conceived of Wonka's Chocolate Factory as a child-like wonderland of a playground, and that Depp plays him as a boy who refuses to grow up, it doesn't make much sense for him to be so VERY uncomfortable around the children.Freddie Highmore, however, is absolutely amazing. He is not given much to say, and in fact is not center-screen as much as I had expected, but he steals every scene he is in. Not since Christian Bale in "Empire of the Sun" has there been such an adorable and absolutely prodigiously gifted young actor. I cannot be over-effusive in my praise. Highmore's performance is easily the most phenomenal and engaging in the film; with his sparkling brown eyes, teacup ears, freckled nose, and boyish grin, he is completely loveable and inspires absolute trust. His Charlie Bucket is ever-so decent, responsible, dependable, and sweet-natured, and yet Highmore conveys all this without ever making him maudlin, obnoxious, or treacly. There is no trace of bathos in his performance, a surprisingly difficult feat which he accomplishes perfectly. We can see why Wonka is willing to entrust his candy empire to Charlie, and why his grandfather would give up what would seem to be his last dollar to buy him another shot at the Golden Ticket.David Kelly as Grandpa Joe is endearing and another of the films fine performances, though sadly he and Charlie are not given much time to interact. Have we not all longed at one time or another for a grandparent like Grandpa Joe? He is old but still retains a rather sharp-edged humour, and his eyes twinkle frequently with delight and kindness. He is a pleasure to watch onscreen, even when he and the other guests are being visually (and otherwise) assaulted by the Factory.The Oompa-Loompas are actually one of the better things about this film, all played by the slightly menacing Indian actor Deep Roy. The musical numbers celebrating (there is no other word for it) the naughty childrens' fates are still here, but their styles range from Bollywood to disco to 80s pop, and are show-stoppers in their own right. They are, happily, not orange, and not particularly pleasant either; one feels slightly uneasy whenever they are around, and it is usually a justified discomfort.The visual design is the best aspect of the film (apart from Highmore). Tim Burton has gone wildly overboard with his fantasy world, but it is here not only justified but absolutely necessary. I particularly loved the Buckets' house: it leans so drunkenly that it could not possibly exist in reality, and bits and pieces of it are artistically missing. Charlie's grandparents all sleep (and apparently live) in the same bedraggled brass bed in the centre of the tiny main room, and Charlie himself sleeps in a nearly-roofless garrett with a view of the great Factory.The candyland of the Chocolate Factory is a child's idea of paradise, with its chocolate river and edible grass and foliage, but it also is appropriately Burtonesque in its suggestion of danger as well as delight: you can eat everything in there, but there is a possibility it could devour you too. Even the peppermint willow trees bend ominously over the riverbanks, stretching their red-and-white-striped branches out like skinny fingers in that peculiar way that only Burton's trees do. The wild ride down the Chocolate River in the flaming-pink candy-Dragon boat (a delight to look at) is inspired and a pleasure to watch, though the suggestion of slave labor (the Oompa-Loompas row the boat to the pounding of a drum strangely reminiscent of Ben-Hur's) adds another appropriately dark touch to Wonka's paradise. The trained squirrels who mete out the spoiled Veruca Salt's punishment were particularly impressive; apparently Burton had some twenty squirrels actually trained for the part and then replicated them with CG, which means these little furry things are unnervingly realistic. As anyone who shares space with squirrels knows, they can be quite menacing creatures, and Burton captures this very well; this sequence is possibly the most disturbing and uncomfortable in its suggestion of violence in the film, but it works. The effects are generally well-used in the film, though always maintaining a certain air of artificiality that becomes the tone of the piece. The opening sequence, an aerial trip through the Chocolate Factory, is thrilling and inspired.Ultimately, there are some very enjoyable moments in this film, particularly the scenes with Charlie and the rest of the Bucket family, but they do not coalesce into a proper whole. One is frequently agape and frequently left staring in slack-jawed wonderment at the Factory and its wonders, as are Wonka's guests, but sometimes it feels like we are not awe-struck but merely dumb-struck. The tone of the film is manic, almost distracted in places (much like Depp's performance) and never lets the audience really become engaged with it. Strange, how art imitates Wonka...

reviewText: Tim Burton did an excellent job remaking "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory." The film stays pretty close to Roald Dahl's book and the original movie adaptation, although there's this weird thing at the end regarding Willy Wonka's (Johnny Depp) father and the whole issue of family. Overall, though, I was impressed with this movie. The special effects are excellent, and the children are all hilarious and perfectly cast. (I especially loved watching Freddie Highmore as Charlie Bucket...that kid is so adorable!) The Oompa-Loompas are spectacular...they were all digitally multiplied and portrayed by the same actor, Deep Roy, who is very funny.Some people have criticized Depp's performance as Wonka, but I think it was brilliant. He really made the role his own by building upon the quirkiness of the character, which resulted in a fresh interpretation of the role that is drastically different from Gene Wilder's version of Willy Wonka, but not at all bad. I also loved the way that Willy Wonka's skin was the same grayish color of a human cadaver...that's Tim Burton for you! It really added to the overall creepiness of the movie.This is a very good film and is one of the best remakes to come out of Hollywood in some time.
summary: A solid remake of a classic story

reviewText: Roald Dahl is an excellent author for both children and adults, and "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is by far his best book, although "The Witches" is a very close second. This movie adaptation of Dahl's masterpice for children is both humorous and poignant. The Jean Wilder version is superb as well, surpassing this one only because of the excellent songs. However, Burton's version has catchy songs as well which are sung by the Ompa Lompa's, and that are adapted from actual poems within Dahl's book.Everyone should know the famous plot line of this superb story: a poverty-stricken little boy named Charlie Bucket loves chocolate and seeks to find a Golden Ticket hidden within an ordinary looking Wonka candy bar. Willy Wonka is the most famous and extraordinary candy maker in the world, and has decided to allow just five children to tour his famous factory. Four of the children, Agustus Gloop, Violet Bauregarde, Veruca Salt, and Mike Teavee are obnoxious and overly indulged by their equally despicable parents. Only Charlie is virtuous and truly deserving of finding a Golden Ticket. What will happen when each child succumbs to their own greed and disobey Willy Wonka's orders? The story is both fun and moralistic.Burton's adaptation is very true to Dahl's book, and includes scenes which are not in the original movie, but are in the novel. For instance, the stories told by Grandpa Joe to Charlie are included, and the sceen about Veruca Salt has squirrels instead of geese, which are the appropriate animals. Also, Charlie Bucket is from England, which is true in the book as well. Burton  adds an interesting touch by relating sceens from Wonka's childhood about the strained relationship between him and his dentist father who forbids his son to consume candy or to pursue his dream of becoming a chocolateer. These sceens are very poignant, and emphasise the importance of family over riches and success.All of the actors are very good, particularly Johnny Dep, and the man playing the Ompa Lompas. The boy portraying Charlie, who was also in "Finding Neverland" is excellent. This movie is very good and well worth watching. As a chocoholic, I recommend having plenty of candy bars on hand. You will get very hungry for sweets after watching this film. Happy viewing!

reviewText: I'm not a Tim Burton fan but I am a fan to this story. As a child I both read and watched the movie versions although I only had a vague recollection of them going into this film. An excellent group of actors both adult and child wise. The set was colourful and very techno for the time period and the ompaas were hilarious although they might be scary for small children. Depp was an eccentric and somewhat egocentric Wonka but delightful to just look at. Other than Charlie the kids were perfectly deplorable and you can't wait to see what will happen to the next rotten child (no one is killed). I found it entertaining and would watch it again.

reviewText: When it was first announced that director Tim Burton was filming "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory", starring the talented Johnny Depp as Willy Wonka, concerns were raised that it may not be as good as the original 1971 film "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory".  However, when the author of the original book, Roald Dahl (1916-1990), upon which both films were based saw the 1971 film, he was so disgusted that he forced the film's producers to rename it to "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory".  Though we will never know today how Roald Dahl would have reacted to the Tim Burton's 2005 version, chances are that Roald Dahl would have been far more pleased with the result.Unlike the 1971 version, the 2005 version both parents of the young Charlie Bucket (Freddie Highmore) are still alive.  His mother Mrs. Bucket (Helena Bonham Carter) and his father Mr. Bucket (Noah Taylor) struggle to support their son, as well as each of the aging parents: Grandpa Joe (David Kelly) who had previously worked at Willy Wonka's factory, Grandma Georgina (Liz Smith, who some viewers may recognize as the character Letitia Cropley from the 1994-1996 British sitcom "The Vicar of Dibley"), Grandpa George (David Morris) and Grandma Josephine (Eileen Essell). Unfortunately, things get worse financially for the Buckets when Mr. Bucket is laid off from the toothpaste factory where he had worked; but the announcement of five golden tickets hidden within five Willy Wonka chocolate bars that will grant the winners to a visit to the mysterious chocolate factory sends the world into a frenzy to find them.  The lucky children that do find them are Augustus Gloop (Philip Wiegratz) and his mother Mrs. Gloop (Franziska Troegner); Violet Beauregarde (AnnaSophia Robb) and her mother Mrs. Beauregarde (Missi Pyle); Veruca Salt (Julia Winter) and her wealthy father Mr. Salt (James Fox); Mike Teevee (Jordan Fry) and his father Mr. Teevee (Adam Godley); and finally, Charlie Bucket, who is accompanied by Grandpa Joe.Another interesting aspect that separates this film from the original is the exploration of Willy Wonka's childhood (Little Willy is played by Blair Dunlop). His father, the eminent dentist Dr. Wonka (Christopher Lee), forbids Little Willy from ever eating any candy or chocolate and forces Little Willy into a maniacal headpiece that prevents Little Willy from closing his mouth so that everyone can see the braces on his teeth.  However, Little Willy, after going trick-or-treating, finds a piece of chocolate that his father had not completely destroyed.  Upon eating it, Little Willy is obsessed with candy and chocolate, which eventually leads to Dr. Wonka abandoning Little Willy.  However, Little Willy has big plans and eventually opens his chocolate factory; but when competitors send spies into his factory, he fires all of his workers and eventually replaces them with the oompa-loompas (with the aid of special effects, each oompa-loompa is played by one actor: Deep Roy).With engaging characters, wonderful songs sung by the oompa-loompas, colorful cinematography, great dialog, superb direction and brilliant acting, I rate the 2005 "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" with a resounding 5 out of 5 stars and highly recommend it to everyone.

reviewText: Tim Burton's movie world is almost always concerned with the dreamer and the dream: think Frank Bloom (Ewan McGregor and Albert Finney) in "Big Fish" and Ed Woods (Johnny Depp) in the film of the same name. But his films are also often about the search for a father, either real or emotionally as in "Big Fish" again and "Edward Scissorhands."Burton's version of the Willie Wonka story is about both, the dreamer: Willie and Charlie (Freddie Highmore) and the search for a father:  the very strange acting and looking Willie Wonka of Johnny Depp for his estranged father, Dr. Wonka (Christopher Lee). Roald Dahl's source material as well as this film share the common theme of men aching from the loss of and searching for the most important relationship in a man's life: the bond between a man and his father.Burton's world is also one of perfection and beauty: think the Technicolor gone bananas neighborhood of "Edward Scissorhands." Philippe Roussellot's production here is likewise blindingly gorgeous and eye-poppingly dense with color and artful design.This version of "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is much closer to that of Dahl's in that it is wittier and likewise naughtily misanthropic than the previous Gene Wilder version. Burton's "CATCF" is sly and malicious, particularly in his treatment of the children that Willie tours around his factory. As in Dahl's story, these children represent a good part of the 7 Deadly sins: Gluttony in the guise of the chubby Augustus Gloop, Greed and Anger in the perfectly page-boyed and unctuous Violet Beauregarde, Pride in the obnoxious Mike Teavee (to whom Willie is perpetually saying "Stop Mumbling, I can't understand you!" when his speech is perfectly understandable) and Anger and Envy in the spoiled brattiness of Veruca Salt. Freddie Highmore as Charlie Bucket and his family stand alone as the embodiment of goodness, caring and love and they alone benefit from Charlie's visit to the Factory.Burton and Depp have a great time putting these kids and their parents in their "place" and though it is a bit cruel, it is fun for us nonetheless: we participate in the action despite our better judgment. And this is the genius of Burton's version of this material: it's dark, it's wicked but it's also full of whimsy and wonder: it's just a hell of a lot of fun.

reviewText: 5 lucky kids get a chance of a lifetime. They get to go inside Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory by trying to find 5 golden tickets in Wonka Bars. They enter the big gate, escorted each by a parent as they walk closely to the huge factory, the voice on the speaker tells them to come to the big front doors. The door slides open and a cheerful song with dolls and stuff blows into flames...then beside them they hear clapping...they turn as they see Willy Wonka standing there clapping, cheering. Anyway, after this ordeal, he brings them into the factory. He leads them around his crazy chocolate factory where the kids see things...wonderful and strange things. Only Tim Burton can pull this off and who better then to be Willy Wonka then have Johnny Depp (Tim Burton's Corpse Bride, Blow) in the drivers seat. It's hard to compare Depp's with Gene Wilder's performance in the 70's because Depp doesnt even touch Wilder's performance, he makes his own and might I say his performance is demented, dimwitted and fun. Some of the OopaLoompa songs get kinda annoying and their really tiny then the 70s version and their all played by the same guy. I think this movie put in things what the original didnt, like how did Willy Wonka come upon the OopaLoompa world and it even flashes back to his childhood where he has a strick Dentist father played by none other then the legendary Christopher Lee (The Lord Of The Rings Trilogy). The cast includes Freddie Highmore (Finding Neverland) as Charlie Bucket, Noah Taylor (Vanilla Sky) and Helena Bonham Carter (Big Fish, Fight Club) as his parents, David Kelly (Waking Ned Devine) as Grampa Joe and Missi Pyle and Violet's Mother. I grew up with the 70's version but I like this one too..I cant choose which one I like so I'll just decide on liking them both equally.
summary: Depp and Burton are at it again...this time it's Charlie and The Chocolate Factory

reviewText: I've never really been a big fan of the Willy Wonka story, finding the original nothing more than an overblown musical misfire.  However, Tim Burton and Johnny Depp give so much life and "weirdness" to the Roald Dahl classic that I found myself hopelessly involved in this morality tale of greed and excess.  Although Depp is reminiscent of Michael Jackson with his pasty white face and effeminate demeanor, he infuses Willy with a dark side, which the screenwriters explain by showing us his repressed childhood (with a nice turn from Christopher Lee as his dentist father).  Add the gorgeous set pieces, the absurdly entertaining musical numbers by Deep Roy as the Oompa Loompas and Depp's delightfully warped performance, and you have one strange and enjoyable movie.  The child actors are wonderful, especially Freddie Highmore as the titular Charlie and WINN DIXIE'S Annasophia Robb as the bubble gum chewing Violet.  David Kelly as grandpa and Helena Bonham Carter and Noah Taylor as Charlie's parents are great too.  The musical score by Burton stalwart Danny Elfman is delightful; Elfman even does the singing for the Oompa Loompa songs with lyrics by the book's author, Dahl.  With no slant on Gene Wilder's original Willy, I found this movie much more enjoyable and visually stunning.

reviewText: The moment it became known that director Tim Burton wasgoing to make a feature film adapting author Roald Dahl'sCHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY, one could anticipatetwo things. One, that Burton would present a uniquecinematic experience. With a maverick crew includingscreenwriter John August and composer/longtime creativepartner Danny Elfman, and a phenomenal cast featuringHelena Bonham Carter, Christopher Lee, David Kelly asGrandpa Joe, Freddy Highmore superbly portraying centralcharacter Charlie Bucket and the incredible Johnny Deppbringing a whole-new "wonkiness" to Willie Wonka, Burtonunleashes all the satiric genius and narrative heart whichcharacterizes his moviemaking artistry.The second point is that Burton's film would inevitablyattract a crowd of naysayers who feel that no one shouldtouch "their" memories of the Gene Wilder film made some30 years before, WILLIE WONKA AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY.Wilder himself, a gifted master of stage and screen, isreported to have gone on record as denouncing the Burtonfilm as a remake of his film; attesting that Burton andhis associates made their film only to make money.Such comparisons are unfair and unfortunate, since theyare totally off the mark. Burton's film is no remake ofthe Wilder vehicle, which was primarily a showpiece forthe music of Broadway composers Leslie Bricusse and AnthonyNewley. The fact is that the Wilder film paid little to noattention to the ingeniously subversive whimsy of the Dahloriginal. Tight and catchy though it may be, Wilder's filmbears little of the ethical impact that continues to makeDahl's work a hallmark of Children's stories for all ages.Burton's CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY takes Dahl'smonumental book into full account at all levels. Elfman'sadapting of Dahl's original lyrics into the outrageously-telling Oompa-Loompa song & dance numbers is a clear signalthat this film is an inspired improvisation upon an untappedoriginal source, playing second fiddle to no one. Only adiversified musicmaker such as Elfman could have pulledoff the genre-crossing orchestrations which enrich thisfilm. For a composer whose roots stretch from the avantgroove of Oingo Boingo to the wry symphonic portraitswhich embody many a film of the past 15 to 20 years,CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY represents a signaturemoment in this amazing career.Depp continues to amaze audiences with his daring abilityto portray the human condition at any level, always withcompelling conviction and a healthy dose of self-depreciatingwit. Depp's Wonka is a study of precocious vulnerabilityand dogged drive. We find out that much of Wonka's creativeimpulses and inner needs stem from his own missing childhood,setting up the soul of this film and a particularly movingclimax. Christopher Lee, whose current resurgence as amaster thespian was sparked by his brief-but-pivotal rolein Burton's SLEEPY HOLLOW, is no less pivotal here, and ajoy to experience. Joyous, too, is the highly-energized,gleefully-diversified of Deep Roy as ALL the Oompa-Loompas!Give this man whatever he wants!A special kudos must go to narrator Geoffrey Holder, themulti-talented artist whose cacao-rich voice alone made"Marvelous" a source of Third World pride and audacityin the 1960s. The twinkle in his tone STILL tells volumes...Top honors for acting, however, has to go to Freddy Highmore,whose first experience with Depp in FINDING NEVERLAND was anunforgettable triumph. Even more telling in the Burton film,Highmore's youthful naivete is tinged with an incredibleemotional range and knowing depth which is the center ofthis film. If Burton's film is vital in restoring theintegrity of Dahl's original work, Highmore's performancesingularly restores Charlie Bucket as the story's centralcharacter; rescuing him from the hapless sidekick role thatthe Wilder film placed the character into. Highmore, inturn, provides Depp's Wonka with the platform fora magnificent, powerful performance.The two-disc Warner Bros. Deluxe Edition is the bestway to fully appreciate all the works that Burton,cast, and crew lovingly put into this film. A primecase for why DVDs are so special, this edition delvesinto all aspects of this production, and includes afine vignette on author Dahl himself (whose familyworked hand-in-hand with Burton here).Everything about this film is wondrous. From its macabreopening amidst the mechanizations of assembly-line procedure,to the first look at the Buckets' crooked home of hard-foughtharmony amidst the cookie-cutter sameness of urbanizedregimentation, you've walked into the off-minor world ofthe surreal and the substantial which is uniquely TimBurton's.Equally vital, this film aptly reflects upon the wild nwooly, warmingly wise world of Roald Dahl. It's nice tosee this great book become a direct source for an equallyinspired film, at long last.

reviewText: Willy Wonka (Depp) has been in seclusion for years.  One day, it is announced that Wonka has hidden five golden tickets in the wrappers of five million candy bars to be sold around the world.  Those who find the tickets will get a tour of the Wonka candy factory.  One by one, the tickets are found, and the winners are announced...Augustus Gloop, Veruca Salt, Violet Beauregarde, Mike Teavee, and finally, Charlie Bucket.  The first four are gluttonous, spoiled, an overachiever, and a TV addict respectively.  Charlie, on the other hand, is just poor.  When the group arrives at the factory, they are all introduced into the the strange world of Willy Wonka.  Willy also tells the kids that one of them will get a special surprise.Johnny Depp plays Willy Wonka with a creepy intensity.  To say that he is odd would be an understatement, and most of the time he is acting unexpectedly.  The movie itself is a treat for the eyes, as most movies by Tim Burton are.  The chocolate factory is filled with wonders, and run by the Oompa Loompas, all played by actor Deep Roy.  They steal all the scenes that they are in, providing songs about the childrens' misguided actions.I have read that Roald Dahl's family is endorsing it, and can't help but think that most people will like it, especially if they liked the original.  Unfortunately for me, I found the movie only slightly less annoying than the original.  So, while I can say that it is an improvement, I can't say that it did much for me.

reviewText: If you were to take a glance back upon director Tim Burton's rather humble beginnings as an animator for the Walt Disney Company, his work, albeit unaccredited, appearing in such full-length animated feature films as The Fox and the Hound and The Black Cauldron in the 1980s, you would think you were staring at an entirely different individual from the one audiences are quite familiar with today. Following the moderate success of Pee-Wee's Big Adventure, just one of the few projects Burton has taken on which have raised eye-brows given his particular taste for the strange and bizarre, he solidified his ability to direct on the big screen with two back-to-back box office successes, Beetle Juice (1988) and Batman (1989). Starting with Batman Returns, the follow-up to the original Batman film which, though certifiably a box office hit, did not live up to what audiences had come to expect, Burton experienced a bit of a slump which continued with Ed Wood and Mars Attacks. Sleepy Hollow, starring Johnny Depp and Christina Ricci, returned Burton back to form, grossing nearly one-hundred million dollars by the end of its domestic run in theaters. Director Tim Burton collaborates with Johnny Depp once more, this being the fourth time together with the fifth being Corpse Bride which opens this fall, for his most eccentric project yet - an adaptation of the classic Ronald Dahl children's novel Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. Be assured that this has not gone without its fair share of controversy from purists, being they few and far between, of the Gene Wilder musical version.The story for Tim Burton's Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, albeit certainly a substantial improvement from the ridiculously overwrought musical production from the 1970s starring Gene Wilder, falls into the unsavory formalities which have come to mar the summer family feature, complete with wall-to-wall clichés, failing to separate itself from the rest of the pack with the exception of Burton's conventional oddities which are common knowledge amongst movie theater patrons. Applause should be given at the very least to director Tim Burton for remaining so true to the source material on which the film is based, having the family of the late-Ronal Dahl publicly endorsing the film upon it entering production last year. However, those unfamiliar with the classic children's novel, even if only in recent years, may want to read up on it if only not to be caught off guard by the film's gothic and semi-sadistic overtones and atmosphere. And although the inclusion of a background story for a leading characters, set up via a series of flashbacks, seems a logistical decision on the part of the filmmakers and was effective enough in director Ron Howard's live-action adaptation of How the Grinch Stole Christmas, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory on the other hand based its material on a full-length children's novel with more then enough material to go on without having to resort to stretching it as they did. Furthermore, background information pertaining to Willy Wonka's childhood and what shaped him into the eccentric candy innovator he is today eliminates the mystery, grandeur and allure the classic children's character has sustained for decades and what has made him the memorable figure he is.Johnny Depp, a regular headliner for director Tim Burton with Charlie and the Chocolate Factory being their fourth collaboration together, is amusing, if not a bit eerie, in the lead role of Willy Wonka. Supposedly, if rumors are to be believed, Johnny Depp beat out fellow competitors such as heteromorphic punk rocker Marilynn Manson for the role. Now imagine how messed up this film would have been had he been given the role. Depp who channeled British rocker Keith Richards for his outlandish performance as Captain Jack Sparrow in Pirates of the Caribbean: Curse of the Black Pearl does essentially the same thing with Willy Wonka, only instead of rock n' roll he instead switches genres and imitates the vagarious behavior of pop-star Michael Jackson. It only makes sense that Depp, playing a whimsical industrial innovator with no distinct memories of his childhood and a defiant animosity to parental authority, would choose to base his performance and appearance off Michael Jackson. Obviously this does nothing in the way of comforting parents wanting to take their children to see this film but credit should be given to Johnny Depp for pushing the envelope in delivering unique, if not a bit odd, performances. Let us hope that the irony of John Depp channeling pop-star and potential pedophile Michael Jackson in a remake of the classic Ronald Dahl novel Charlie and the Chocolate Factory fresh off his Academy Award-nominated performance in Finding Neverland is not lost on today's audiences.In spite of his charm, Jack Albertson's sportive Grandpa Joe from the 1971 Gene Wilder musical Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is in no way imitated in the performance of Irish actor David Kelly. This in turn makes the following version of Grandpa Joe all the more relatable to our own grandfathers, elderly and decrepit in physical stature and yet filled with enough spark in him at times to be almost childlike in nature, such as when Charlie discovers the last remaining golden ticket. Christopher Lee, much in the same way as Vincent Prince did in Burton's Edward Scissorhands before him, performs magnificently opposite Johnny Depp, giving a slightly bizarre and twisted perspective on the judging and yet loving father figure which shapes the son's future in defiance of his the father's best intentions. Sadly, the character of Dr. Wonka, Willy's father, decreases the imaginative mystery surrounding the classic character of Willy Wonka considerably and leads only to a rather bland and pedestrian finale, albeit a step above the Gene Wilder rendition.The problem with the character of Charlie Bucket lies not within the splendid performance of the young Freddie Highmore who also appeared alongside Johnny Depp in the Oscar nominated Finding Neverland but instead with the character himself. Sure, Charlie's purpose is to serve as the perfect foil to the other four children who are spoiled, rotten little punks who deserve whatever they have coming to them. Sadly, his personal quality is so positive, upbeat, and righteous that he is given an almost saint-like status significantly diminishing his connection with audiences. One of the very few positive aspects which can be said of the Gene Wilder musical adaptation of the Ronald Dahl novel is that it was able to make Charlie the polar opposite of the other bratty children on the chocolate tour but allowed him to remain a bit `mischievous' enough, with the help of his Grandpa Joe, to retain his humanity in the eyes of audiences who could easily relate to him. True, there was the scene in which Charlie discovers money lying in a snow bank and instead of using it to provide for his poverty-stricken family he rushes to the local convenience store to purchase a Wonka bar for himself. But seeing as how he ended up receiving the fifth and last golden ticket within that very candy bar he purchased in the convenience store, it will undoubtedly go unnoticed by audiences.Annasophia Robb is completely contemptuous as the inordinately competitive Miss Violet Beauregarde whose trademark is her ability to chew a single piece of gum for three months solid in spite of its loss of taste. The same however can not be said of her robust blue berry colored counterpart who in the eyes of Charlie's audiences strikes as being glaringly computer-animated. The fat suit, both back then and now, may seem a bit ridiculous, if not a bit laughable in light of the tremendous success of computer animation in Hollywood blockbusters, but it at least felt a bit more believable then a computer animated Annasophia Robb blown up to resemble a gigantic blue-berry. Nothing, not even computers, can exactly duplicate the likeness of a human being, even if they happen to be a fat-suit and dyed blue. And Jordan Fry is easily the least memorable child cast member in the role of Mike Teavee, a golden ticket winner who, surprisingly, lavishes in technology, particularly television, and expresses no interest in the production of chocolate or other `dumb' ideas. The musical number which marks his departure from the tour does not work as effectively as the others. Scenes imitating such memorable moments as Alfred Hitchcock's Psycho shower scene only add to the quirkiness of the production.Overall, Tim Burton's Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is not so much a failure, far be it from that to be sure, as it is a disappointment particularly to those who had such high expectations following the director's critically acclaimed Big Fish, this in spite of it's lack of award recognition, that this adaptation of the classic Ronald Dahl novel would be a step in the proper direction. Albeit far from the abomination which was the Gene Wilder musical Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, the manipulated title being just the beginning of the project's lengthy laundry list of problems, the Tim Burton/Johnny Depp presentation is honestly nothing beyond mediocre and has its own fair share of issues. For one, no matter how much actor Johnny Depp denies to the entertainment media that he did not base the eccentric behavior of the lead Willy Wonka on pop-star Michael Jackson, there are too many similarities and congruities between the two in this film for it to be merely a coincidence. How nave and stupid does Johnny Depp think we are? It is not an issue of criticism, although at moments it certainly crosses the line in becoming down right creepy particularly with young children in the audience who may or may not understand the parallel mannerisms between the two figures, as it is an annoyance for Depp not to fess up to his portrayal of Willy Wonka. Yet another dispute is that specific special effects shots, which would include among others the blown-up Violet Beauregarde and the diminutive Oompa Loompas, all of which are performed by British actor Deep Roy, come off as being too artificial which presents quite an unnecessary distraction for the audience. Other points of critique would include the haphazard background story of Willy Wonka which diminishes significantly the grandeur and illusion of the character when his outlandish behavior is blamed on `daddy not understanding him', awkward moments such as when the dolls singing the `Willy Wonka Theme Song' suddenly catch on fire or when Willy proclaims `Good morning sunshine, the Earth says hello' that do nothing for the plot and are not the least bit amusing, and finally the finale which wraps things up too neatly and feels a bit anti-climatic to say the least. Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is a welcome diversion from adult-oriented features flooding the market place, which would include Wedding Crashers and The Island, for the younger set but retains no distinctive value that would make it anything more then that.
summary: The Moose Hole - Peter Pan and the Chocolate Factory

reviewText: When I first saw this movie, it couldn't help comparing it to the Gene Wilder movie, so I was disappointed through most of the movie. That was until I saw the ending.The ending on the Gene Wilder movie was unsatisfying, to say the least. It really left you with a bad taste in the mouth, it was... really frustratingly ambiguous and vague for me as a kid. Must be one of the worst movie endings of all time. I loved the oompa-loompa songs in the old movie, but as a whole it wasn't very re-watchable, and thus I didn't buy the video.This one was different: The oompa-loompa songs are kinda... way too pop for my taste (the originals were more whimsical), but as a whole the movie is much more worth owning in DVD, and the reason for that is the sub-plot that finally develops in the ending, which is conclusive and not ambiguous at all. And the dark imagery, of course, makes it appealing to Tim Burton fans such as myself.
summary: The ending is much better on this version

reviewText: 5 lucky kids get a chance of a lifetime. They get to go inside Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory by trying to find 5 golden tickets in Wonka Bars. They enter the big gate, escorted each by a parent as they walk closely to the huge factory, the voice on the speaker tells them to come to the big front doors. The door slides open and a cheerful song with dolls and stuff blows into flames...then beside them they hear clapping...they turn as they see Willy Wonka standing there clapping, cheering. Anyway, after this ordeal, he brings them into the factory. He leads them around his crazy chocolate factory where the kids see things...wonderful and strange things. Only Tim Burton can pull this off and who better then to be Willy Wonka then have Johnny Depp (Tim Burton's Corpse Bride, Blow) in the drivers seat. It's hard to compare Depp's with Gene Wilder's performance in the 70's because Depp doesnt even touch Wilder's performance, he makes his own and might I say his performance is demented, dimwitted and fun. Some of the OopaLoompa songs get kinda annoying and their really tiny then the 70s version and their all played by the same guy. I think this movie put in things what the original didnt, like how did Willy Wonka come upon the OopaLoompa world and it even flashes back to his childhood where he has a strick Dentist father played by none other then the legendary Christopher Lee (The Lord Of The Rings Trilogy). The cast includes Freddie Highmore (Finding Neverland) as Charlie Bucket, Noah Taylor (Vanilla Sky) and Helena Bonham Carter (Big Fish, Fight Club) as his parents, David Kelly (Waking Ned Devine) as Grampa Joe and Missi Pyle and Violet's Mother. I grew up with the 70's version but I like this one too..I cant choose which one I like so I'll just decide on liking them both equally.
summary: Depp and Burton are at it again...this time it's Charlie and The Chocolate Factory

reviewText: It's extraordinary how Tim Burton can make movies that are totally void of humanity and energy and this is his most offensive attempt. It's equally stunning that a remake can eviscerate the brilliant script of the original, take away all humor, quirkiness and cleverness and repackage it with ridiculous changes. And then there's the awful performance of Johnny Depp who has no concept of this character. I believe the original choice for the remake was Nicholas Cage who would've gotten the nastiness of Willy Wonka. I loathed the children and acting all around. I loathed the lame songs. I loathed the money that was spent on this. Take a look at some of the making of extras of the original movie and you'll see it was a labor of love. Like all of Burton's latest movies, this was made for the money. It's eye candy, but it sure ain't sweet.
summary: eye candy full of empty calories

reviewText: The new version of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory represents exactly what the audience should expect from a Tim Burton film: exuberant sets that challenge all possible camera angles and show a kitsch quality; weird supporting characters that prove to be a critic and piercing look at the American suburban world, Danny Elfman's exquisite music and as a cherry top, the presence of Johnny Depp, in his fifth collaboration with Burton.The original 1971 film had a clear anchor in the pop visual look of the times; Burton's film evokes some 60's pictures in his art direction, photography and in the sweet innocence quality that all movies lack in the present. Without a doubt, the production design, art direction, costumes and sets are worthy of an Oscar; as well as Elfman's score, who added music to the verses written by Ronald Dahl, the author of the book.Likewise, we should speak of Johnny Depp's performance for his extraordinary creation of Wonka. Compared to Gene Wilder's character in the 71' film, Depp's Wonka is more repressed, more peculiar and far more apt to this version, because it looks real and nostalgia-free.The casting was terrific, from my point of view, and no one dissapointed in that department. A special mention to the man who played the Oompa Loompas...he was just superb and hilarious, in a freaky way, but terrific!!In conclusion, I think Burton's version is superior, its ending more wholesome and its sensibility definitely more contemporary. This movie has updated all the elements that became somewhat obsolete in the 1971 film. All these aspects have enriched the story, and this makes Charlie and the Chocolate Factory a very sweet treat.
