reviewText: Director Tim Burton's macabre sense of humor meets writer Roald Dahl's macabre sense of humor in this adaptation of Dahl's novel "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory". I hated the first cinematic incarnation of the novel, 1971's "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory", when I was a child, so I loaded this one into my DVD player with low expectations. I was pleasantly surprised to be at least mildly engaged in the story and generally entertained, though I have the same qualms about showing "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" to young children that I did about the 1971 film. The film's sometimes sadistic humor may be genuinely disturbing to children, and the eccentric Willy Wonka is just plain creepy. I actually thought it was a horror film when I was a child.Charlie Bucket (Freddie Highmore) is an "ordinary little boy" who lives with his impoverished but loving family. One day, the reclusive candy magnate Willy Wonka (Johnny Depp) announces that he will allow 5 children to tour his huge and mysterious factory, one of whom will win a grand prize "beyond your wildest imagination". Five Golden Tickets have been placed randomly in Wonka chocolate bars, and children all over the world vie to find them. Poor little Charlie has a wealth of luck and comes up with one of the tickets himself. He chooses his Grandpa Joe (David Kelly) to accompany him on the tour, and off they go with four other children and their parents to see how Willy Wonka makes all that delicious candy.Johnny Depp can make creepy, antisocial characters interesting, and he brings a sense of innocence to Willy Wonka that helps. But to tell the truth, Willy Wonka is an unsettling guy who doesn't even like children. Worse, the fates that await the youngsters could easily be the stuff of nightmares -so be careful if you know your child is sensitive. The child actors do a great job of expressing their characters' over-the-top personalities. If the writing has any fault, it is that Charlie is a good boy but a bland character, while his more mischievous companions have stronger personalities and do more to entertain. Annasophia Robb is especially fun to watch as ultra-competitive Violet Beauregarde. "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is obviously intended for children, hence the lessons on the value of family and consequences of disobedience...and the silly song and dance numbers. But the film is peppered with jokes and allusions aimed at adults. It's admirable that "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" strives to entertain its entire audience, but I wonder if the adults won't be just mildly entertained while the kids are just creeped out.
summary: Funny for Adults. Scary for Children. The Key Is in the Audience's Degree of Detachment.

reviewText: Another Burton classic.  As dark and rich as you're likely going to be able to swallow, but watch out for the nuts!  And this movie is full of oddballs, weirdos, nuts as well as several squirrels.As usual, Depp adds an unsettling twist to the character of Wonka that makes him interesting and just a tad obnoxious.  This version of the movie more accurately approaches the character in the book than the Wilder movie did ( but I like that one too.)  The cinematography is breathtaking in scope and detail with special effects that will please the most finicky of viewers.  The acting from the children is flawless, they almost steal the show away from Depp.  Almost.  And last, Elfman's score is one of his best to date; menacing, creepy but playful and intelligent.  Unlike the original movie, you can actually look forward to the next Oompa Loompa song in this rendition.  The only real drawback to me was a decision to overdue the digital makeup on Depp and some of the children in the cast.  Their skin almost looks plastic and distracted me more often than it should have.  Then again, I did see it in an IMAX theater so it was more obvious but the movie is larger than life so the huge screen was definitely a treat!

reviewText: Willy's back, and of course with Depp and Burton things have changed.  Some for the better and some for the worse, as is often the case.  Oh, and to clarify now, the film is not actually that dark.The plot itself feels a little awry.  For instance, Charlie is treated almost as a sub-character for much of the film, and we are pressed to pay more and more attention to the factory and Willy Wonka himself.  This is particularly true when Burton shows us the newer personal side of Wonka, filled with flashbacks and more.On top of that the whole feel of the musical has diminished, but admittedly they're just not as popular anymore so no surprise.  Oh yes, the Oompaloompas sing, and in quite a  variety of styles too, but don't expect Depp to crack out a note, or the kids.And speaking of Oompaloompas, in the previous versions where obviously a few characters played them, this version has one actor digitally cloned into all of the Oompaloompas.  Not only that, but he is not the most appealing Oompaloompa, as he actually fits the image of a man who I do not think should be around kids.  Oh yes, I definitely loved the musical numbers, and the shrewd comments based around them particularly by the kid characters, but still, scary man.So did I like it?  Yeah, I did, and although I prefer Gene Wilder's version this one gives us another side, perhaps unnecessary side, to this strange yet classic tale of a poor boy and his fortunate and strange trip to the Wonka Chocolate factory.

reviewText: Disclaimer:  I've never cared for this story.  The characters are too inactive in it.  They just wander around from strange scene to strange scene, slowly being picked off, until Charlie remains and then THE END.  Kind of like a slasher film without the charm of a low budget and a guy in a hockey mask.This version isn't terrible, but it's meandering.  Worse, it isn't nearly as colorful or imaginative as it's supposed to be.  I'm not saying there isn't some cool stuff in it, but a lot of it is stuff I saw in the original film.  There's really not much new to it except for the special effects, which are admittedly very good.But it always comes back to the story, and I just didn't care about it.  It doesn't help that I already knew it, knew everything that was going to happen.  It's hard to be awed by things you expect.  And the bit about Willy Wonka finding a family seemed labored and unnecessary to me.And about the Oompha Loomphas, two points:  They're kind of creepy in this version. Creepier even than the original if that's possible.  And I couldn't understand a word of their songs.  Very irritating.One positive note:  The Puppet Burn Center made me laugh and laugh and laugh for about ten minutes.  So I can't be too hard on the film in the end.  Still, not my bag.

reviewText: It's better than the original, which I've never been able to sit through without looking at my watch. The best part of the original, and the part that is most faithful to the book--darling Charlie, his loving parents and the four grandparents in their beds in the one-room cottage--are here, cast beautifully. You will love them and care about them. The contest, the chocolate and other treats, and the Chocolate factory, and the other kids and parents, are all 100 times better in this movie. Then there's Johnny Depp, who is unrecognizable and wonderful and fabulous and funny as Willie Wonka. It's wry, it's funny, the songs are great. Buy this DVD as a great addition to the family's collection.
summary: Better (yes I said Better!) than the original!

reviewText: I watched just for the Tim Burton FX, but surprisingly got caught up in the story.Never read a Roald Dahl story, saw a piece of the 70s "Willy Wonka" movie, but couldn't stay there long.This movie starts out very cold,dark and bleak (better for the uber-Technicolor entrance into Wonka's factory.) Depp's portrayal is rather unnerving in its similarity to Michael Jackson. Wonka is getting old, needs an heir and wants Charlie to divorce his family and come live with  him in the factory without any other adult intervention. Kinda creeps me out. However, up to that point the movie is quite entertaning and a feast for the eyes (up to the ride in the candy Viking ship it's best), after that the sets get a little sterile.What surprised me was that Wonka does not like kids; he especially despises RUDE kids (and isn't society over run with these nowadays!!!) Each little rude punk gets punished, but the punishments are not at all imaginative, in fact each one gets more boring. If Burton stayed true to the Dahl book, I wish he could have come with more interesting punishments.Overall, very good. I started to watch just to see the effects, watched the whole thing and watched it several more times. 4 stars for sets, effects, 2 for story.
summary: Creepy, But Entertaining. Not a Kid's Movie

reviewText: Now, I'm probably sounding a little lame by the title of my review, but, there's really no other way to put this movie than that.  I'm a big fan of Burton's work, and even bigger fan of a Burton/Depp collaboration.  I believe this is their fourth film collaboration.  Now, the movie itself is imperssive and imaginative. Johnny Depp is fabulous as Willy Wonka.  All the kid actors also did a great job at their roles.  Most people won't agree with me, but I enjoyed it a lot more than the original, which I didn't really care for.Most of you know the story, but here it is anyway:A young boy Charlie, lives in a small run-down house with his poor family.  He lives near by the legendary Wonka Chocolate Factory.  One day, his grandpa tells him the story why Willy Wonka (Johnny Depp)closed down his factory to public workers and machines took over the job.  Shortly after hearing this, Willy Wonka announces he will be giving 5 kids a tour of his factory, and he has hidden a Golden Ticket in five candy bars.  But poor Charlie only gets one bar a year, and that bar, sadly, does not contain one of the prized Golden Tickets.  But when Charlie finds a twenty dollar bill in the snow, he buys a Fudge Mallow Delight bar, and to his surprise, finds a Golden Ticket!And with that, Charlie soon finds himself standing by the front of the factory with five other lucky kids, but will they win the one big prize Willy Wonka has promised the best kid?Now, this movie is very funny, very visual and very VERY weird, but non the less, the 2 Disk Special Edition is truly and treat to have and deserves a spot on any movie collectors shelf.
summary: A Goofy and Crazy Movie Exploding with Gagworks

reviewText: Many fans of the 1971 Gene Wilder classic will find themselves picking at similiarities in this re-telling of Roald Dahl's Charlie And The Chocolate Factory.  Though Tim Buton claimed not to be an admirer of the original, I believe either he or Depp studied up on Wilder's performance.  Closer to the book than the original, there are still certain nuances, certain catch phrases that were not garnered from the book.  Depp's Wonka is a little bit scarier, a little more messed up than the Wilder version.  You get the feeling in places that he and Hannibal Lecter might get along together...Depp is that creepy in places, almost too emotionally damaged.  Overall a stunning Burton vision if there ever was one.  A little predictable...duh?  Is Depp classic here?  Yes.  Is it better than the original?  That's the million dollar question.  Childhood nostalgia clouds the answer for me.  My kids loved it and they love the old one, too.  Score there.  Overall, I enjoyed it tremendously.  Depp's over-the-top performances are always fun to watch.Dig it!
summary: New Or Old:  The Eternal Choice!  Depp & Buton Together Again

reviewText: I know that many people had complaints with this film because it wasn't the Gene Wilder Wonka from their childhood, but this is the true version of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. Tim Burton's vision is the closest thing Hollywood could possibly ever produce to Roald Dahl's fantastical world of a remarkably clever (albeit eccentricly crazy) very sweet man.Johnny Depp is perfect as Willy Wonka. He's actually beyond perfect. Depp is the character actor of all character actors and his portrayal of Wonka is so hilariously crazy that it is just perfect. The thing I find so remarkable about Depp's performance in this film is that it is his fourth starring role in a Tim Burton movie, and yet it is amazingly different from every other performance he has ever done. So many other actor/director combinations get stagnant and appear to repeatedly do the same thing over and over (Tom Hanks/Spielberg, Tom Cruise/Spielberg, Ben Affleck/Kevin Smith, etc...) but Depp and Burton bring a new character, a new scenery, and an entirely new production to everything they work on together. "Charlie" is no exception.And speaking of Charlie, his portrayal in this film by Freddie Highmore is awesome. I have to admit to being slightly disappointed by the casting of Highmore as Charlie because I was not overly impressed with his performance in "Finding Neverland" but he silenced my criticism by perfectly portraying Charlie Bucket. He was awesome. Depp was awesome. Burton's direction and crazy Burton-esque set design was priceless. This movie was tremenedously crazy fun and I cannot remember the last time I laughed this hard at the movies. "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" rocks!Hopefully they don't cut out too much of the set design on this full screen version, but it'll be worth it even if they do.  Depp's performance is pure brilliance.

reviewText: Does anyone remember "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory?"  Well, throw that one away.  "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is taking it's place as the movie Dahl invisioned.I don't need to give a summary of the story, as everyone knows what it is.  What I need to do, first, is dispell some isues.Where is the music?Why, it's there.  The Oompa Loompas sing, only they have much, much better songs.What about Charlie and his Grandfather drinking the bubble stuff?That actually did not happen in the book.What about the whole Everlasting Gobstopper thing, with Charlie giving his back?Again, not in the book.  The book was about the importance of family, not the importance of sharing.  And that is where the original movie went horribly wrong.  This newer version brings out the moral as Dahl wanted it.Depp, as usual, gives an incredible performance, and Burton shows off his as usual incredible directing skills.This Wonka was much more believable around the kids as he hadn't been around people for years.  His antics and his needing the cards made much more sense.  And the fact that he was weird only made it funnier.  His whole backstory was incredible, as well as sad.  The whole issue with his father and the scene where he and his father meet back up is very touching.  Depp did incredible with the character.  His adaption worked given how Wonka was supposed to be, and it made more sense.I though it was very touching that Wonka's father had been following his son's career, even though he claimed to not be there when Wonka came back.  It was very moving, to say the least.I liked this Charlie much better.  He was way more realistic, as was the Grandfather.  I loved the Grandfather.  He was incredible and funny.  And I liked the idea that Charlie's Grandfather used to work for Mr. Wonka.  That was awesome.This is an incredible movie, and is the only real book-screen adaptation of Raold Dahl's original work.  Gene Wilder's version is now inconsequential.  If you want Raold Dahl's work the way it was meant to be, then get "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" with Johnny Depp.  This is the real version.

reviewerName: Nathan Andersen "Gadget lover and author of S...
reviewText: A nice expressionist realization of a story that, at bottom, is about the viciousness and wonder to which children are equally susceptible, and the culpability of parents in the failings of their children -- i.e. for the parents' failure to cultivate in their children a sense of wonder and a healthy respect for the unknown.  (That is why I think Burton's addition of the backstory regarding Wonka and his candy-hating dentist father is very much in the spirit of the original.)  The Dickensian world of Charlie is lovingly recreated by Burton, replete with a leaning shack and twisted doors that suggest the German expressionist techniques evident in the Cabinet of Dr. Caligari.  The Oompah Loompahs are perfect, and Tim Burton admirably avoids the racism implicit in the original story by making the Oompah Loompahs (all but a few, as far as I can tell, played by the same suave actor) without resorting to the campiness of the prior movie version, by making them much more clever than the rest of the characters in the story.  Their musical numbers had me and my children laughing out loud, especially where in the song for Mike Teavee they become a perfect parody of 70's glam rock (nearly besting even Spinal Tap in this brief number).  Tim Burton has his hits and misses, but I liked this one.
summary: A fun collaboration between the magic of Dahl's story and the gleeful imagination of Burton

reviewerName: Nicholas Williams "movie, music, and book fan"
reviewText: For anyone born before say, 1980, the following words are enough to strike fear and giggles into the hearts of lads and lasses everywhere: "There's no earthly way of knowing which direction we are going. There's no knowing where we're rowing. Or which way the river's flowing. Is it raining? Is it snowing? Is a hurricane a blowing?" This is the chant that a deranged-looking Gene Wilder uttered as his magic gondola sailed down the chocolate river in 1971's "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory". It is a film that has delighted and spooked children for more than 30 years. And I had the pleasure of going to see this wonderful retelling of the now-named "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" not too long ago. The direction of Tim Burton ("Batman", "Sleepy Hollow") was nothing short of extraordinary! The performance of Johnny Depp ("Secret Window") as Willy Wonka was top-notch and hilarious! Supporting players include Freddie Highmore ("Finding Neverland") as Charlie Bucket, David Kelly ("Waking Ned Devine"), Helena Bonham Carter ("Fight Club"), Noah Taylor ("Lara Croft: Tomb Raider"), and Christopher Lee ("The Lord of the Rings" trilogy), in which they all gave unforgettable performances!For those who don't know the story, then hop into my gondola, everyone, and I'll tell you a little about a guy named Willy Wonka (Depp). He owns a big candy factory, and nobody's been in it for 15 years. And yet, it's been producing candy all this while. But how, if nobody comes in or out, does the candy get made? Little Charlie Bucket (Highmore) would like to know. He's a poor boy living on the outskirts of the Wonka factory in a strange, dilapidated house where his four ancient grandparents sleep in one large bed (two at the foot and two at the head). One day, after years of silence, Wonka announces to the world that he is putting five "golden tickets" into his delicious Wonka Bars, and the children who get them will be treated to a tour of the Wonka factory and vie for a chance to win a special prize at the end of the visit.Needless to say, Charlie gets one of the tickets, as do a quartet of prepubescent horrors: fat and gluttonous Augustus Gloop (Philip Wiegratz), spoiled rich kid Veruca Salt (Julia Winter), competitive gum-smacker Violet Beauregarde (AnnaSophia Robb, "Because of Winn-Dixie"), and the video-game-obsessed brat Mike Teavee (Jordan Fry). Wonka doesn't like these kids. He has unique ways of expressing disdain for each. And, in fact, each of the kids leaves the tour early, picked off by their own excesses. (Augustus falls into the chocolate river, Violet becomes a giant blueberry, etc.) We know throughout the movie that Charlie, along with his Grandpa Joe (Kelly), will make it all the way based on his kindness and manners. But what is the special prize?While Charlie is more fleshed out and real than the moppet of the first film, Wonka himself is a bizarre amalgam of Michael Jackson and Oscar Wilde -- only more androgynous than Michael and dandier than Oscar (imagine that!). Whereas Wilder's Willy Wonka was mischievously wise, Depp's is neurotic. He has family issues -- he can't bring himself to say "parent" -- from a troubled childhood with an overbearing dentist father (Lee). Wonka is not merely whimsical here. He is weird.Some may consider Depp's creation a miscalculation. But what kind of person could create a factory of such imagination and craziness and not be somehow crazy and imaginary in the process? The factory is a marvel -- very much like the one of the earlier film at first but more expansive and magical as it goes along. There are special effects now that were undreamt in 1971, and they are put to enchanting use. What exactly Roald Dahl's book and this film promotes in terms of childhood virtues is elusive. Is it moderate appreciation of candy? Respect for imagination? This is unclear. Crystal clear, however, is this: Quibble as you may, besides "Batman Begins", this is the most imaginative and delightful film so far this summer. It is a feast for the eyes and ears. (The Oompa Loompas, Wonka's trusty and diminutive servants, all played by Deep Roy, engage in dazzling production numbers, each themed around the exit of a bratty child. The horn section really soars.)And the chemistry between the strange Wonka and the responsible Charlie is touching and, at times, heartbreaking. This is Burton's most complete and rewarding film in years, especially since "Batman" and "Batman Returns", and certainly in a year full of "Fantastic Four"s and "Bewitched"s, "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" succeeds as the most reverential and enjoyable remake. See it, either right now in the theaters or on DVD when it's released!
summary: A magnificent retelling of Roald Dahl's timeless novel; Johnny Depp's best performance since "Pirates of the Caribbean"!

reviewText: ...That idiots who clearly paid no attention to the film aren't dwelling on the idea that Depp was impersonating Jackson?  Um... hello... DEPP'S WONKA HATED KIDS!  I don't wanna spoil the movie and say why Wonka in this movie chose to allow the brats into his factory, but Depp makes it very clear that Wonka is not socially stable.  He cringes at any physical touch (the scene where Violet hugs him), he picks fights with the children out of the pure inability to understand them (the 'you're all very short' scene), he needs cue cards just to welcome them into his factory... And my final arguement for the day, Wonka has a nose!!!Anyway, that aside:  This movie was awesome.  I recommend it to anyone on the grounds that it is incomparable to the first; Burton did a great job of making sure that this was a retelling of a story and not a remake of a movie.  Of course the original is a classic, but do not let that stop you from seeing this version, because you may be pleasantly surprised.Yes, everything is different.  The oompa loompas are somewhat more... disturbing... mostly in the sense that they're all played by the same man!  The 'bad' kids are nastier than in the original, and the 'bad' parents are even more pathetically clueless or tapped into their childrens' faults.  But the message is the same, and of course dear sweet Charlie is the 'good' kid in both films.  A lot of the scenes following the actual tour of the factory follow the same sequences from the old film, and it's of course amusing to draw parallels.  But in this film, we're given some extra exposition on Wonka's character; (oddly enough this isn't the version with Willy Wonka in the title...) and his rise to fame as well as what makes him a fallible character.I've also heard a lot of people say this movie is like acid on film... well, I guess I can go with that arguement.
summary: Ok, can we just PRETEND for one second...

reviewText: 2.5 stars.  I had long thought that Depp was a remarkable actor.  I remember over a decade ago when I shared that thought with some movie friends and was literally laughed at, now it's an accepted fact. Woo hoo for me.  Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is just another shiny example of the risks Johnny is willing to take to bring us unique characters and one of the things about this film I like is his total committment to his performance.  Course there was something inconsistent about an arrested developed man seeming to not like children.  Given his history with his father, I could understand him not liking parents, but in the movie, he really seemed to get along with them better.  Still a good Michael Jackson impersonation.  And for that I say Bravo.  The other great things about this the movie are the wonderful sets for Willy Wonka's extraordianry chocolate factory.  They are literally eye candy for the movie audience.  But as a whole, I can't say that I was blown away by this movie.  In fact, there are portions of the movie where I was bored and was entertaining doing a few house chores instead--and I HATE chores.  Anyway, this goes to show that sometimes even great performances can't save a movie.  Overall: watch at your own risk.

reviewText: Plot: Charlie is a boy who comes from a low-on-their-luck family. They haven't much of anything except each other. It is Charlie's birthday that will be soon arriving, and for his present he will get one Wonka Bar. But this year it will be different. Willy Wonka just so happens to be re-opening his factory, and five golden tickets are randomly placed in the most current production line of Wonka Bars. The five lucky children who find these tickets will receive a tour of Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory for an entire day. And one extra-lucky child will receive a mystery prize at the end of the tour beyond their wildest imagination. Sure enough, Charlie ends up being one of those lucky children to enter the factory. So, along with four others, he meets Willy Wonka on that anticipated day and enters his palace-like factory, unaware of the absolutely amazing things he is about to see. And once those doors shut behind them, the magic begins. Room after room, we (the viewers) are treated to some truly colorful and imaginative sights. Along the way are the singing Oopma-Loompas, giant waterfalls of chocolate, edible grass and trees, kooky new inventions, and plenty more. Throughout the tour, however, each child's curiosity and spoiled nature brings about problems, and one by one they create their own catastrophes sure to end their visit! By the end of the film, of course, Charlie is the only one left and becomes the winner of the fantastic prize. But when the prize is revealed, the most important things in life are finally seen by Charlie as well as Willy Wonka, ultimately leading to a heart-warming ending that holds an important message for children and adults alike.Johnny Depp certainly makes a delightful Willy Wonka. Through the movie trailers, I thought Charlie And The Chocolate Factory would be a bit weirder and more twisted than it actually was. Regardless, you can be assured that Depp's portrayal of Wonka is no less than absolutely nutty! Depp's acting combined with the usual greatness of Tim Burton's peculiarly fascinating style (as well as some assistance from scorist Danny Elfman) is plenty of a reason to see this superb remake. This is a wonderful and amusing film for the entire family!
summary: A Superb Presentation Of Pure Silliness

reviewText: I wouldn't say this movie is as good as the first one but it's good. Willy Wonka (Johnny Depp) looked better. He had a nice haircut. I would like to get one like his. The songs however were better. My two favorites were Veruca Salt and Mike Teevee. Veruca Salt's song sounded like a song from 1969. And that Hard Rock band that was playing on Mike Teevee's song reminded me of that band KISS and it also sounded like that song by Queen "Bohemian Rhapsody." When I heard this movie came out, I felt as though this was sort of like a historic moment because this is like the sequel to Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory (1971) since the old movie was made 34 years ago as of last year and that's a pretty long time for a sequel to come out. The plot is sort of the same where Charlie Bucket (Freddie Highmore) and his family are poor and there are 5 Golden tickets in any 5 Wonka bars. Later on Charlie finds it and he tours the Chocolate factory with 4 other kids Augustus Gloop (Philip Wiegratz) who eats so many Candy Bars a day, Veruca Salt (Julia Winter) who gets everything she wants because her father Mr. Salt (James Fox) is rich, Violet Beauregarde (AnnaSophia Robb) who chews gum all day long and also won many trophies for activites, and a nerdish kind of guy Mike Teavee (Jordan Fry) who likes watching TV and playing Video Games but hates Chocolate and Mr. Wonka. While in the factory, they don't listen to Mr. Wonka and do what they want to do and don't win the factory. However Charlie won the factory and also shows some new stuff not in the original movie like what the kids looked like after their incidents and Mr. Wonka lands his glass elevator into Charlie's poorhouse and tells his family he won the Chocolate factory but Mr. Wonka says he cannot bring his family with him so Charlie turns down the offer. Things turned out a little better for the Bucket family but not for Willy. Then later on Charlie is Polishing Shoes and Willy Wonka comes to get his shoes Polished and after Charlie talks about Willy, Willy reveals himself and says why he doesn't want Charlie's family to come to the factory because they tell you what to do and what not to do but Charlie tells him that they're just trying to protect you because they love you and later on Charlie takes Mr. Wonka to see his Dad, Dr. Wilbur Wonka who's a Dentist and actually before this part, it mentions about Willy's childhood. Wilbur didn't want Willy to eat one piece of chocolate or candy. But later on Willy likes it and starts eating just that and Wilbur doesn't like it so Willy runs away and that's how he ran the chocolate factory. Because of this, Willy didn't want to see his Dad but Wilbur recognizes Willy and realizes how much he loved Willy so Willy changes his mind and makes the offer to Charlie again about the factory and gives it to him under one condition, he brings his family along. Anyway, this was a pretty good movie, I thought it wasn't gonna be better than the first movie but it actually was and I recommend it to everyone especially Johnny Depp fans.

reviewText: Tim Burton hires Johnny Depp (gee, there's a first) to portray the slightly off-center chocolatier Willie Wonka in the recent version of 'Charlie And The Chocolate Factory'.The only fair way to make any comparisons between this one and the original starring Gene Wilder is by their storylines. The new version gives a lot more detail from the book than the original did. The more noticeable main differences between the two stories are: 1) Mike Teevee and Violet Beauregard are made to look more violent in the new version, 2) You get to see what happened to the children as they're escorted out of the factory, 3) the geese that lay the golden eggs are replaced by squirrels that toss out bad nuts, and 4) you get to see the childhood of Willie Wonka in the newer version.  I would go into other story differences but I don't want to give too much away.There wasn't a bad performance by any actor or actress in this movie, in my opinion. The one that deserves the most credit is Deep Roy who portrays every Oompa Loompa in the movie. Yes, I know, the computer special effects can easily make multiple copies of him; however, you can tell he went through a few dozen costume changes and alternate shots for the movie. AND, he does a better lip sync than Brittney Spears and Ashley Simpson combined.  I know.. that's not saying much.The most interesting thing about the movie I didn't find out until the closing credits. The lyrics of the Oompa Loompa songs come straight from Roald Dahl's book.One of the few downsides of the movie was the sound quality of the first couple of songs. You couldn't quite tell what the lyrics were in the Loompa songs for Augustus and Violet. For the music portion, Tim once again hired the amazing talents of Oingo Boingo (not to be confused with Oompa Loompa) man Danny Elfman. It was kind of funny catching some people singing the Willie Wonka song as they were leaving the theater.The movie is rated PG and is great for the whole family to see.Movie warnings: bovine S&M; (whipped cream room), robot cruelty, chocoholism, parent neglect, and karate kiddiness (I know.. not a word).Would I shell out $14+ to see it in IMAX (saw it for free on IMAX)? Hell no. I wouldn't pay that much for any movie. But, for matinee and regular movie prices, it's worth it.P.S. I didn't really see the connection that others did between Michael Jackson and the portrayal of Willie Wonka that Johnny Depp did.  The only common thing I saw was their skin complexion.

reviewText: Let's face it: In life there is good-androgynous and bad androgynous. The funniest evocation of the difference is probably that classic skit from Saturday Night Live called "It's Pat!". Pat in this case was a character of the most creepy androgyny, in an almost genius direction, and very funny. It highlighted what most feel, and certainly also gay people, that there  are differences in styles of androgyny. I am someone who likes masculinity as a cultural trope and biological ethos, and I see the virtue in it, which is not always recognized in our somewhat feminized culture. But at the same time, I am not bothered nor do I dislike fem guys, and just consider it a variation, and often a witty and charming  and beautiful one. But the  character made of the central Willy Wonka figure in this remake of the original Willy Wonka is just bad-androgynous in every way,  and very creepy to boot. Unlike the original with Gene Wilder character,  who was quite  delightfully oddball in his masculine way.  In fact one of the reasons I think the movie was such a failure is that it was  simply quite impossible to imagine reasonable parents  leaving children with this character. There were some good points in the movie, but since this central weirdness was a bit anxiety- causing, it failed as entertainment. Ironically, one of Johnny Depp's other movies actually proves the point exactly. When he played that pirate in many movies, it would be hard to conjure a simultaneously  more masculine yet swishy character. He swished through every scene, and was very fem in many ways. And yet, whatever that button is, he did not push it for creepiness. By contrast Wonka in this one surely does.This makes me think also how jejune and unprofitable it is  to read too much into these movies. It is just entertainment, and the reason one theme or style is chosen is often very ad hoc, if the actual history of movie making is any guide. Of course they make mistakes sometimes in choosing. By contrast, I remember being in 7th grade in Catholic school, when our homework assignment for Social Studies was to write a kind of analysis of a movie we liked. One of the kids gave a presentation about the original Willy Wonka, and gave it a very Catholic interpretation. He said Willy Wonka was like a Christ-figure and the Oompa-Loopmas were like the Apostles. He even said that when they break open that giant  colorful toadstool and it flows out with liquid chocolate, that such was like almost a Eucharistic sacrament!! Well, obviously the nun who taught the class was pretty annoyed by this analysis. The silliness of it reminds me how taking mere entertainment with all its ad hoc effluvia and factoids as descriptors of some larger meaning precludes our ability to plumb real lines of meaning, and find the actual compass by which to hermeneutically analyze the essential entertainment ethos. That goes for an academic school environment or elsewhere.
summary: Willy Wonka, Androgynous In a Bad Way

reviewText: I'll preface by saying I'm not a huge fan of Depp. I find his whimsical pseudo-insane persona in most of his movies off-putting. However, this really was a worthless movie.Here is what I recall from the original charlie and the chocolate factory:- fun- interesting- light-heartedHere is what is in this version:- dark- awkward- somewhat scary (for kids)I have nothing against good remakes but Gene Wilder in the original played an interesting and likable, if very quirky, guy. Frankly, Depp has a bit of a pedo vibe in this and in any case he is patently unlikeable and actually nasty. His factory is less like a fun place and more like a demented candy house. It scared my young kids a bit. That is ok, they are young, but as an adult there is no reason at all to watch this over the original.And so, it's like "upgrading" from A Lexus to a Kia. Skip this waste of time and go with the original. This offers *nothing* but updated special effects.One of the big networks is playing Charlie and the Chocolate factory on TV in the next week or so--the original, thankfully. They know this remake is without merit.
summary: Like upgrading from a Lexus to a Kia

reviewText: ...and I honestly don't get it! This meaning, of course, that I don't understand why the critics didn't seem to come up with worthy enough words to praise this new masterpiece signed a certain Tim Burton. At least the critics over here in Europe did, and after finally watching it (with a mixed expectation being that very often critics have no idea what they are talking about -funny how they mostly agree amongst themselves, isn't it? If a movie is weird enough it's a bit scary being the one who doesn't "get it", am I right?).And yes, this movie is weird enough -but it doesn't seem forced, and is not the problem at all. And I don't give a damn about the similarities between Willie Wonka and Michael Jackson! Ironically at first viewing it was like being served a big and tempting bowl of candy -but it didn't taste anything. The gigantic chocolate-factory stands there in all its' mystery containing all its' secrets, but when we're finally inside every room looks the same. It's been a while since I read the book (but I did recognize myself there from time to time), so my dissapointment has got nothing to do wether it is true to the original story or not -but I simply didn't find it amusing, and after finnishing the bowl I still want candy. Ok, enough with the candy -but how this movie has scored full pot with the critics is beyond me. It's ok at its' best, and I can swallow a child loving it of course -it's colorful, and at times like watching a childrens' show. But at the same time it's a comedy for adults as well, and somehow falls between two chairs.I must admit that my two stars on the other hand goes to Johnny Depp. He certainly "becomes" Willie Wonka, or the oposite that is. He was a pleasure to watch -and overall the movie is saved by good acting from the entire cast. It's the story itself I found flat as its' original script -and far, far overrated. It has its' moments I guess, but nothing remembarable. All the praise of amazing effects, well, I didn't notice anything special. And good and "believable" effects aren't everything (or haven't we learned?).Christopher Lee is wasted on a completely non-fit father/son-scenario switching between present/past (similar to other Burton-productions like "Sleepy Hollow" there with the main character and his mother), and is totally unecassarry -and ruined at least a desent ending. Over the top if you ask me! It just didn't make any sence at all -even for an fabled adventure-story...So sorry, Tim Burton, I'm usually a big fan of you -but you can do better than this!

reviewText: If you type "therapy," "therapist," or, "counseling" in to any search engine you will get, literally, millions and millions of returns, and you won't disturb anyone or air your problems in public.I guess no one ever told Tim Burton about search engines because he, evidently, views movie making as a bizarre form of public therapy for his unhappy childhood and, as a result, he continuously inflicts his parental issues on the movie going public by re-creating established icons in his own emotionally knee-capped image.This time around the classic he trashes is Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. Giving lip service to making a totally faithful adaptation of Roald Dahl's fantastic book, Mr. Burton instead took to immediately turning Willy Wonka into an emotional cripple because his daddy was too strict and wouldn't nurture his creative candy ideas. {replace the word `candy' with `movie' and viola' Willy Wonka becomes Tim Burton! How'd that happen?!}It isn't just Wonka whose psyche' has been converted to a dark abyss, no that would be to easy. All the parents who accompany their kids on the tour are totally worthless; they stand around and watch their children getting maimed and hardly raise a fuss or ask a question. They were pretty useless in the book too but at least they made some noise about their kids getting axed. Grandpa Joe is okay because he isn't technically Charlie's `parent' so it's alright for him to be nice in Mr. Burton's world.The ending from the book has also been cast aside so Mr. Burton can spend an extra half hour beating the dead horse of mean, uncaring parents and their emotionally stunted children. And what is the payoff for this extra time stolen from your life? We find out that Old Man Wonka has been secretly proud of his son's accomplishments all these years but he was too proud to say "I love you." Dare to dream, Tim.Now let's talk about casting; Johnny Depp has no business in this film whatsoever, even on his best day he would be totally wrong for this part, and this is NOT his best day. His uneven and bizarre performance has an extremely creepy child molester quality that is very hard to watch and is about a million miles away from the character that Roald Dahl created. In fact the entire film is poorly cast with two exceptions; Freddie Highmore as Charlie Bucket and Julia Winter as Veruca Salt. Both did very well with what they had to work with.Danny Elfman's score, which is usually the one bright spot in a Tim Burton film, doesn't work at all here. It almost sounds as if Mr. Elfman has run out of ideas for making Burtons films palatable and just phoned it in to get it over with. The Oompa Loompa songs, however, are very catchy and pretty well done. The one complaint about them is that the words are important but they are frequently intelligible because of the music. In the book those lyrics, and Wonka's reaction to them, help set the tone of the story and establish that all is not what it seems.I have avoided mentioning the 1971 version until now because I wanted the majority of this review to deal with Burton's remake and little else, but it is impossible to ignore the other film because Burton made such a point of publicly distancing his version from it. And therein lies the biggest obstacle to Charlie and the Chocolate Factory; the original adaptation of Roald Dahl's book nailed the magical yet dangerous feel of the factory so well and, Gene Wilder's portrayal of Willy Wonka was so spot on with the book that when Burton distanced his film from them he, in effect, prohibited his own movie from capturing the nature of the book or it's lead characters.Avoid this film if you can. Watch the 1971 version instead.
summary: Need therapy? Make a movie instead...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Danny Elfman's score begins. I hate Danny Elfman, but of course he would be used, he's in every one of Burton's endeavors. A CGI factory makes CGI chocolate in what seems like a mockery of the same imagery used to make cookies in the beginning of Edward Scissorhands... the narrator starts; in Burton's typical fairy-tale style comes images of fairy-tale times with fairy-tale dilapidated old houses, and I'm really beginning to not like it until......it all sucks you in. You watch Charlie's family as they anticipate the finders of the Golden Tickets, and their quite acute comments on the nature of the winners. You watch as Charlie simultaneously tries to hide his hope and maintain it at the same time, along with his family's fluctuating eagerness to get a Golden Ticket. And as Charlie finds a ten dollar bill on the ground, you suddenly realize, "Geez, this movie's a lot like the book... well, of course it was one dollar and not ten dollars, but who's really counting?" And a lot like the book it stays, with a few minor deviations which frankly are brilliant. Wonka's flashbacks into his childhood are perfect addendums to Depp's quirky new creation of the beloved character that most could not separate from Wilder, and in the end Wilder's character is still maintained because he is not blaspheme'd. Johnny Depp and Tim Burton make a new Willy Wonka that is standalone enough that all thought of Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory becomes mere nitpicking by people annoyed by change.In fact, considering the book, Willy Wonka movie, and Charlie movie, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is truly brilliant. It holds true to the book while still maintaining cinematic appeal by becoming it's own thing. It is not a remake of Willy Wonka, and thank God (or just Burton, as it was his choice anyways, right?) for that, because even though I like the older version, remakes are just incredibly tedious.Special appeal to Burton fans would be the almost demented acting of Johnny Depp... the strange grins when kids get in trouble, the timid voice when he becomes unsure of himself, the reclusive germophobe he makes of a once maudlin and glurgy character. In fact, all the characters are perfectly translated to the screen, even if they do look like porcelain dolls from time to time (I hypothesize this comes from the drawings found in many of Rhoad Dahl's books).Another great aspect of this movie is it's adherence to the musical bits in the book without really being a musical itself. Other than one other song, the Oompa Loompas sing everything, and though their music isn't really that good (I'd like to have it on a CD for laughs, but I don't really care for it otherwise), at least the situations are pretty funny, especially since all of the Oompa Loompas have the same face... and aren't like Munchkins.Another good thing to focus on is the insane amount of allusions.  Did I say "mockery of Edward Scissorhands"?  It's no mockery, the beginning channels that work for a reason.  Kubrick, Hitchcock, and Burton's own films are easy catches, but can you catch all of the homages in this film?As the movie progresses, it deviates more and more from the book, which is fine because it feels at that point like the trust has been salvaged. If people are still worrying about details so far into this movie, then I don't really see how they enjoy very many movies at all. About the time we reach the television room scene, it begins to feel a little tedious but right then wraps up everything pretty nicely (not to say there isn't more good stuff to come, but I'm not going to give away ALL the details). Eventually the credits roll and I'm suddenly realizing, "Wow, that was two hours... felt like two minutes." A sure sign of a pretty good movie if there is one.--PolarisDiB

reviewText: Note: While I indeed like the percentage rating, I am refusing to rewrite this review, because I am way too happy with it to just delete it.  Still, I'm giving it a percentage.First off, I love Tim Burton.  Quentin Tarantino is cemented as my favorite director, but if I had to choose other favorites, Tim Burton is easily one of my other favorite directors.  Granted, he's not a genius as much as some of his saviors would like you to believe (you know the kind), and I don't rate all of his movies five stars or even four stars (Pee-Wee's Playhouse and The Nightmare Before Christmas are prime examples).  However, I think he's more than just some goth symbol.  He makes great movies that really have great visual styles, and for the most part, he's an inspired director and someone I can always count on for making something good.Except when he tries to redo other movies.  Granted, he's only had only one other re-make, but Planet of The Apes stunk up something fierce, and this one isn't much better.  I actually don't like the Willy Wonka movie that much either (I actually like the book more), but it's not a bad movie for good reasons, and there are parts in the movie that  seem very heartwarming (god I hate that word).  If felt engaging many times, and while it's also kind of dated, it still retains some form of engagment and emotion.  This movie, on the other hand, left me feeling cold throughout, with nothing to grab onto, with no character development.  Visual style can only take you so far, and while I liked some of it, it didn't do enough to save the film from becoming a total mess.This isn't a terrible movie by any stretch, but there's just not anything to grab onto.  Tim Burton is usually known for his quirkness and strangeness (boy, how dumb does that sound), but I always thought  he did so in a way that was always engaging, really making the world, characters, or situations come to life in some way.  In this one, the weirdness is there because he wants to be weird.  It does nothing to bring the world to life, just makes the world seem like a place that reminds you of a retirement home.  I actually have felt more emotions at a retirement home than this movie, I'm not even joking.  Plus, unlike the book which still had the heart but some of the deranged fun, this one doesn't have much with the sterile characters, and the two main people: Charlie and Wonka, being incredibly annoying on both counts.Ah, the annoying characters.  An example of this one would be the main character himself, Willy Wonka (?).  This Willy Wonka is just plain annoying and totally unengaging.  He has no real motivation in his actions, makes the stupidest and lame jokes, and just seems like the kind of person that tries to be all weird but in any case comes off looking like a person starved for attention.  The lame subplot about his father was also worthless, a backstory that made me feel absolutely nothing and did nothing to make me like this character at all.  Besides, when you don't give two _________ about the character now, why did you think I would care now?  He's annoying, he's weird because he can't offer anything else, and comparing the two characters makes you realize how much more soulless this Wonka is (The Nostalgia Critic did some cool comparisons, although I have no idea where the heck James Bond villian came from).I also liked the way the Nostalgia Critic pointed out how the Charlie character in this one is underdeveloped and annoyingly perfect.  This is a boyscout indeed, a kid that is so perfect and unrealistic that you just want to deck whoever put together this moron kid together.  As he said, the Charlie in the Wonka version (his name is in the title of the BOOK FOR CRYING OUT LOUD!!!!) is kind, but is more like a kid.  He can get greedy, he is tempted at times, but really comes out at the end after conflict (at the end).  He's more like a real kid.  He's crucial to the story, which makes it all the better since he's engaging while the focus of this movie does not involve a character that's in any way interseting.  See above for that reason.However, there are some improvements, although most are on the visual front.  The whole chocolate River is much improved, the original version did very much look like liquid _________.  The river in here was extremely gloppy and looked very much like chocolate.  I also thought the gobstopper was improved, I mean, what were the original gobstoppers supposed to me modeled after.  The factory is kind of interesting to see at times, but not entirely all the time.  It's kind of a person thing, but I think it overall looks pretty cool for the most part, and Tim Burton knows his stuff (too bad it didn't save the movie).There are some plot points cleared up, and the character updates shows they weren't entirely lazy (Gloop is pretty much the same).  The updates of Mike, and ESPECIALLY Violet, are very welcome.  I also like seeing the kids come out after their survival through the factory.  However, Veruca Salt was not improved at all, as the one in the earlier version was so __________ spoiled and bratty that you wanted to beat for being such a bratty son of a __________.  And the opening parts weren't that bad either, although nothing special considering the characters weren't that interesting, so setting up uninteresting characters doesn't really make the movie better.  It would only count if the characters were actually interesting.  And when they do, there's not much screen time anyway.Oh, and one other thing.  The MUSICALS NUMBERS $U(% @$$!!!!!!!  The whole different songs played during each kid's demise are totally annoying.  Why Elfman why?  Oh.  _______ the Willy Wonka song.  Eh, at least it's better than A Whole New World.Sorry Burton, I love ya, but I'm not a patsy.  It's worth a shot if your a Burton fan, but if you are going into the movie expecting to see something akin to the original, you're in for a rude awakening.  I'm actually glad I saw this movie for some Tim Burton greatness scattered about, but there wasn't that much.  It's kind of too bad.  Oh well.  I'm glad Ed Wood was released on DVD in special edition.Directing: 7/10Characters: 3/10Improvements in visual style 4/5musical numbers 0/5plot: 1/10
summary: Let's Just Hope He Does A better Job With Alice 38%

reviewText: Before I get to my review for this movie, I would like to say that I haven't seen the previous version, nor have I read the book, so my review is based purely on this movie only without comparing it to anything. The trailers looked intriguing, and since I loved watching Tim Burton's movies like "Edward Scissorhands", "Sleepy Hollow" and "Big Fish", I thought I would go see `Charlie and the Chocolate Factory' and I wasn't disappointed one bit!The story is about young Charlie Bucket (played by the talented Freddie Highmore), a poor boy with a good heart, who one day wins one of the five golden tickets to see Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory (the biggest factory which closed down a few years ago, and where no one is allowed to go in). Now starts the surreal adventures that take place once Willy Wonka shows the winners around his factory.I am usually speechless after watching most of Tim Burton's films (because they are all so good), and this movie had the same effect on me. I knew Freddie Highmore was talented when I first saw him in `Finding Neverland' and he once again acted his role flawlessly as Charlie. I feel Johnny Depp performed his best in this movie, because apart from the makeup, he played the silly, eccentric Willy Wonka so well that you feel like you are seeing him in a new light. It's not a surprise that Tim Burton would do an amazing job in directing this movie.This is a fun movie that anyone would enjoy watching. It is funny, silly, and emotional at the same time. I cannot wait for the DVD to come out so that I can watch it over and over again.
summary: As sweet as it can be!

reviewText: Seeing a re-make come out of the absolute classic that defined such a piece of my pre-pubescent youth gave me plenty of doubt that Mr. Depp could pull off anything like the original.  Yes, it has special effects, and some quite dandy music, but Johnny Depp does not unseat Gene Wilder; heavens no.  The Roald Dahl story is a great one; I think I now need to read the book.  It kept me aware of just when this thing might end.  I liked the kids better in the original; Charlie is a pretty bland player, and Grandpa Joe in this one comes nowhere close to the great Jack Albertson.  Call me old fashioned, call me what you will, but I'll rate the original almost a whole star higher.  Make this one 3.9 stars.

reviewText: As I was watching Charlie And The Chocolate Factory, it occurred to me that this review would basically conclude that this version of the movie adds absolutely nothing to the old version, Willy Wonka & The Chocolate Factory, starring Gene Wilder and Jack Albertson.If you're not familiar with the plot, Willy Wonka runs a Chocolate Factory, but no one has been allowed inside with him for years.  He distributes 5 golden tickets randomly in shipments of chocolate bars.  The children who find the tickets will win a tour of the factory.  Young charlie is one of the lucky kids, from a very poor home, who finds a golden ticket.  The tour commences and the kids - each with one adult family member - see strange and wondrous things inside the candy factory.Johnny Depp is probably the best actor available for the role, almost ideal, some would say - but not better, for this particular role of Willy Wonka, than Wilder.  Danny Elfman is one of my favorite composers of movie scores, especially Tim Burton movies, but in this case his music is actually worse than in the old film.  And the dancing rock numbers of the Oompa Loompa's is horrendous.  The old film was in color, had decent art direction and special effects, fine acting, and both films follow essentially the same plot, with minor variations, not much funnier in the new film.  Plus they left out the "Candy Man" song, one of my favorite parts of the old version. And so I would have given the film only 3 stars, for it's almost as good as the original, though unnecessary since it's not better, and then one less star because I missed "The Candy Man."But then the end came, and then they DID add more in this version, and it's good - morally and emotionally satisfying - and it involves Christopher Lee.  So I'm giving it 4 stars and recommend it for the whole family and everybody.  And the old version as well.
summary: Good ending, but wheres The Candy Man?

reviewText: Time Burton does it again with his trademark gothic and bizarre movie backdrops. One cannot deny the dark imagery and the visual effects that make the film a Burton production -- the irony and the dysfunctions of his characters that are played out with each child and their relationship with their parents.  This is the core issue in the film as well as for Wonka's personality; Wonka cannot even say the word p-a-r-e-nt.  The landscape of the film almost depicts a time that has long passed -- the Cold War imagery of espionage, stealing the Wonka candy formula.  The film has traits from past Burton films, such as EDWARD SCISSORHANDS and BIG FISH as well as from other twisted fictitious narratives, LEMONY SNICKET, and forgive me, THE CAT IN THE HAT.  Johnny Depp presents a unique Willy Wonka with his somewhat androgynous appearance that has been suggestive as a cross between the "King of Pop" and Carol Channing. Burton follows the same plotline as the original CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY film, WILLY WONKA AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY and stays true to Roahl Dhal's novel as well as a few extras that explain Wonka's childhood.CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY by all means does not follow the musical giddiness of the original movie with memorable numbers, such as "The Candyman," "Pure Imagination," and "I've Got a Golden Ticket."  However, the Oompa loompa numbers somewhat fill the void, and proceeds the same as the WILLY WONKA film where each child is eliminated from the factory tour.  The most delicious scene throughout the film is the Wonka chocolate bar, and the river full of hot chocolate amidst the edible green hilly pastures with its cherry candy trees and puffy whipped cream -- how yummy.Overall, the film will indeed entertain and enchant each viewer.  It is appropriate for children eight years-old and older.  However, children under eight years-old should be accompanied with an adult because of particular situations and references that are mentioned in the film that they may not understand.

reviewText: Tim Burton's CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY is a more faithful, darker rendering of Roald Dahl's 1964 book than the 1971 film. In that, although Gene Wilder was his usual delightful self, the direction, writing, and all other performances were mediocre and date badly. The changes from the book gave it a bland tone and a cheap look. Burton's film is a completely different vision, more like Dahl in its sophisticated whimsy and nightmarish quality, accomplished in Burton's inimitable style. Depp is a dismissive, sardonic Wonka; Wilder was just loopy. Any notion that Depp's subtle, eccentric performance has anything to do with Michael Jackson is way off-base: Depp's Wonka actually despises children, revealing that he was trying to find a child who was "the least repulsive," a far-cry from an adult who wants to recapture his own childhood. The Burton film is not unlike Nicholas Roeg's faithful adaptation of Dahl's THE WITCHES--really close to Dahl's curmudgeonly view of children and the world; but CHARLIE goes farther with an ingenious, stunning visual style. The performances and look are genuinely funny, surreal, or moving. Depp acts rings around Wilder (these days, around anyone: it seems his range and flexibility are limitless). There is an added subplot dealing with Wonka's background, presumably written so that Christopher Lee could be included, about which some have complained. I think it works beautifully, and Lee is always a joy to watch. Recall that Dahl *disowned* the 1971 film and even refused to permit the use of his original title. He had been asked to write a screenplay, which was then radically altered into the bland mash that became WILLIE WONKA AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY. The Burton film has no such problems. However, I'm not sure I'd recommend it for all American children, given its morbidity and nihilistic tone. Unlike Americans, the English have never been afraid to show their kids the world without candy-coating it--another reason that the Burton film is far more authentic than its pallid 1971 screen predecessor. I think Dahl would have approved of this one. The DVD presents a crisp, colorful transfer in widescreen (avoid the zoomed/cropped full-screen version).

reviewText: A poor boy finally gets his chance when he wins a golden ticket into an eccentric mans' candy-making factory with five spoilt children. All sorts of surprises await for Charlie around every twist and turn. Including an extra special surprise.I had no idea what to expect of this film when I first walked into the theater. I left it thinking "Woah! That was nothing great..."All though a lot of the sets are better, such as the giant candy room, it just didn't have the magic like the orginal did. Although I must say that the new Charlie was a lot more likable than the orginal. The Oompa-Loompas  were very different. They weren't orange, they all looked the same, and they were not dwarfs but a normal man srucken through CGI.Over all, an okay film, the original was better in some places. Worth seeing it in the theaters, just don't expect much.

reviewText: I have to offer a counterpoint to all of the reviews praising this movie for being so faithful to the book.While many things about the movie were based more on the book than the first Willy Wonka movie, this new movie added a ridiculous plot tangent where Wonka is a dentist's son desperate to seek his father's approval. This sub-plot (which has *nothing* to do with the original book) featured some of the worst acting I've *ever* seen from Depp -- which shocked me, as I consider Depp the best actor of his generation. Still, everyone has to have a miss or two. Depp went for creepy, and got it, but far too many of his scenes (including all of these "dentist flashbacks") feel like he's forcing it. I was watching a man act, not watching a character.As for the rest of the movie... it was pleasantly dark, but lacked the sense of wonder that the first movie brought to life so well. Gene Wilder may have been too nice and accessible as Wonka for some, but his factory felt like an otherworldly place of mystery and surrealism. Depp's factory feels fake and lifeless, and ultimately makes it very difficult to lose yourself in this new, strange place. And that, my friends, is the only way by which a film like this can be judged, hence my low rating.
summary: NOT that faithful to the book - don't believe the hype

reviewText: The ultimate storyteller of current postmodern society does it again. Tim Burton does it again. "Charlie and the chocolate factory" a film written by John August and Burton himself, is the 2005 adaptation of the legendary Roald Dahl's tale.Faithful to the traditional "bizarro" aura that has become his film trademark, Burton manages to deliver a moving and beautiful story with a strong ethic & value-oriented message that will be the joy of kids (all ages) and adults (all ages too). A feast for the eyes, and the soul. Exhausted and somewhat bored of his own success, Willie Wonka, the obscure owner of a world-class chocolate factory decides that the time has come for him to find an heir to his creamy empire. In doing so, he decides to temporarily leave his usual secludeness and issue a worldwide contest by way of which five lucky golden tickets, hidden in an equal number of chocolate bars, will in turn allow five lucky kids to tour his mistery factory, and get the chance of winning an all-star prize "beyond their imagination". After a series of unthinkable and (at times) very dark situations inside the factory, four pitiful kids fail the test. Each of them consumed by gluttony, greed, arrogance and despise. Only one child, the pristine and humble Charlie Bucket, manages to complete the journey, earning the coveted prize, and ultimately giving Willy Wonka the lesson of his life.I have to say that I loved this film so much that I even forgave Tim Burton for making his Willy Wonka a Wacko-Jacko look-alike....but hey Tim, don't push it!

reviewText: Tim Burton, Johnny Depp, and lots of fun stuff, approved by Dahl's daughter (a producer), can only make me believe that this is a definitve version. Roald Dahl didn't like the first version (with Gene Wilder), and it was risky to attempt a new version, but Burton is intelligent enough to do it right. One thing I didn't get was, if the old grandfather worked for Willy Wonka, why didn't Willy age accordingly. As Dahl intended, it's a lesson that rotten little spoiled kids will not always get everything they want. Previous reviewers made references to Michael Jackson, and other nonsense. What I experienced was a fine version of Dahl's difficult story, well presented and very entertaining. What I got out of it, as the book intended, is that greedy kids won't always get what they want; that a poor kid with dreams and hope may get more. The combination of Burton and Depp has never failed to entertain me (Edward Scissorhands, Sleepy Hollow, Ed Wood). Both are among the most talented artists in the film medium, and I enjoy that. "Charlie" is another feather in Burton's cap, and Depp, with his intelligent side-glances, removes any doubt that he's the finest actor today, risky and complete.  If you know the book, you'll understand. If you don't, just enjoy the film. Burton did a fine job.

reviewText: Last weekend I went out and saw Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. I've not read the book, nor seen the original, so I had no expectations for the story.This was typical Tim Burton fare: well-directed, with impressive visuals and a great cast. Burton always manages to assemble a great cast, and bring the best out of them. Not that Johnny Depp needs any real coaching to do a good job, mind you. The kid actors are splendid, which was good to see; if they hadn't been capable of doing a good job, this movie would have been toast.As for the storyline...it's a little oddball, and Willy Wonka clearly is calculating and non-personable (though I'mnot sure kids would see it this way)....all the kids who suffer horrible fates are clearly suffering pre-planned fates. Willy Wonka is clearly a character which needs redemption, and he does get it by movie's end, but the achievement of that goal seems a little weakly executed. This is a weak point on my part though, and shouldn't stop folks from enjoying the movie.This is not Tim Burton's best work, but it's still good, and definitely something to take the kids out to see!
summary: Tim Burton and the Chocolate Factory

reviewText: Many years ago, Charlie Button's grandfather worked for Willy Wonka's Choclate Factory.  Their chocolates were amazing.  Seemed like Wonka could invent candy other folks just dreamed of making---like ice cream that never melted even on the hottest day.  So amazing, in fact, that a good many of the employees performed industrial espionage.  Soon, Wonka's competitors were offering no-melt ice cream and gum that didn't lose its flavor.Willy could have no idea that at least one or two of his competitors could steal in no time flat.Sadly, Willy Wonka closed the door on the factory and let all his employees go.  No one's been in there since, but the choclate keeps pouring out.In an unprecedented move, Willy offers five golden tickets in his Wonka Bars.  The children who win these five tickets get to visit the chocolate factory for a day--and one will come away with an unheard of prize:  which Willy will not list!Charlie badly wants to win the prize, both for himself and his grandfather.  But, how does poor Charlie stand a chance if he only gets one bar of chocolate per year---on his birthday.Meanwhile, kids are finding the Golden Tickets.  First, there's a fat German kid who eats chocolate all the time.  Then, there's a spoilt British girl whose industrialist father buys her hundreds of thousands of chocolate bars just so she can get the one.  Then, a kid hacker from Colorado who pegs the system and knows just which bar to buy.  Finally, the world's champion gum chewer and her stage mom win.They're down to one.  Charlie finds a dollar in the snow and gets the last ticket.The next day is the tour of the chocolate factory.  Wonka, the five kids and their respective parents go on an amazing tour where they discover that a tiny race of people--the oompah loompahs--are who now work at the factory creating choclates.  Throughout the tour, each of the children is tested---til only one remains.The effects in this film are pretty amazing.  I will admit I wasn't certain Depp could pull the role off, but he did.  He's a somewhat more disociated Wonka than Gene Wilder, but still interesting.  Overall, a very enjoyable film and a sweet deal for both the young and the young at heart.

reviewText: I'll start off by saying I've never been a fan of Johnny Depp.  So it surprised me that I really enjoyed this movie - and have watched it multiple times, all because of Depp.Yes, I grew up on the original film version of the book and Depp's performance of Willy Wonka was one of an eccentric chocolatier. One that Gene Wilder tried to pull off, but wasn't as successful. Depp's Wonka clearly is more insulated the Wilder's and is creeped out by kids and parents alike. Wilder's Wonka was mildly removed.The costumes, hair and the teeth only accentuate the left of center behaviour that Depp portrays.  Anyone thinking his is a throw away performance needs to look closer.The story is no less child-friendly than 'Willy Wonka & The Chocolate Factory'...though I don't find Elfman's 'Oompa-Loompa songs as enjoyable. The kids are ok - Charlie being the best of them, though I loved Veruca Salt (still not as good as the original Veruca).  I will say I didn't not understand Violet's 'flexibility' at the end of the movie at all.  And the kid they got to play Mike Teevee has eerily physicial similarities of the original kid...and really...you can't go wrong having Christopher Lee as Wily's dad.Visually, there was no one other than Burton to (re)make this movie. I thought both he and Depp did a great job.
summary: Candy doesn't need a reason.....that's why it's candy

reviewText: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (Tim Burton, 2005)The best way to look at Tim Burton's new reimagining of Roald Dahl's classic kids' novel Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is that it's a reimagining of the source material rather than a remake of the older film. They descend from a common ancestor, but have no more in common than you or I do with the Monkey Chain of Trust. (Well, not me. I'm not so sure about you sometimes.)In some ways, this version is closer to the source material than the older one-- for example, they have the right Oompa-Loompa songs this time (and thank Heaven for that). For about half the film, the kids seem truer to their book roots, as well, though things have been updated a bit (Mike Teevee, for example, is now a videogame devotee instead of a watcher of TV Westerns; either way, he gets his daily quantity of violence). Apart from that, though, this movie diverges as widely from the book as does the first one, but in decidedly odder ways. Not that this should be much of a surprise from Burton.The character of Willy Wonka, played here with far more an air of overt menace than Gene Wilder took in the original film, is the principal oddity. Wilder played things off as a nice fatherly sort of chap, which made it kind of hard to believe when he suddenly turned around and started raging. Depp's Wonka is thoroughly screwed up from the very start, and were I a ten-year-old about to accompany him into a factory, I'd have to check to make sure chocolate hadn't gotten into my britches on a regular basis. Whereas Wilder's Wonka was all about showing off the goodies, and taking as much delight in them as the kids did, Depp's version wanders through the landscape as if he has no idea what he's looking at. Positively creepy. (This makes the cutting of the original film's most infamous scene, the boat ride, all the more inexplicable.) One could make a pretty strong argument for Depp's character mirroring Willem Dafoe's brilliant performance as Count Orlok in Merhige's Shadow of the Vampire rather than anything that came out of the mind of either Dahl or Wilder.It's not a bad comparison, though one has to buy the idea that Depp himself actually took the path that Murnau (John Malkovich) provided as Orlok's cover story in Shadow. Depp looked into the motivations of his character, which are explored in depth here, and came up with a neurotic bag of bones who's so ill-socialized that, even when it comes to the moment he's been dreaming of these past few years, we still can't buy it. I'm relatively sure no one reading this review could possibly have gone their entire lives without seeing either the original film or this one, but I'll still not spoil the ending for you; let's just say that when it happens, it doesn't sit right.This is an immensely interesting film for all the wrong reasons. Johnny Depp's character is endlessly fascinating, but that's a whole different ball of wax than saying Willy Wonka, or the film that surrounds him, is immensely interesting. **

reviewText: In this interesting remake of a classic that delivers a very different movie to be enjoyed by a very different audience Tim Burton and Jonny Depp go to extremes in Charlie and the Chocolate factory. Unlike the 1971 original there aren't the musical scores and balance of weirdness and good humor here, this one is all about weirdness.  But coming from Burton who brought us greats like "Pee Wee's Big Adventure" and "Edward Scissorhands" we can only expect a strange take on the film.  Depp of corse adds his own dash of strangeness to the blend making this a film that feels dark quirky and strange.  While the premise of the original and (the book) are roughly the same to this one it is the feelings that have changed and while both movies can be split into two parts, before Wonka and after Wonka, in the Burton's remake the second half is all Wonka where the children only play a supporting role.What this film has going for it is an amazing display of great effects and visually stimulating scenery and some wry and sarcastic lines from Depp.  While Gene Wilder's Wonka was a character that was strange but loveable, Depp's is well just strange.  The oompah loompahs do get more speaking parts and sing actual lyrics from the actual book which coming from Dahl are naturally very cute and funny with just an aspect of the bizarre.  What the film lacks is that emotional charge that made the audience sympathetic to Charlie - of course the title is a misnomer - this film is all about Wonka.While this film is a completely different film from the original it is still worth seeing.  I will say that I like the original better but this is an interesting take on the same story.  Tim Burton and Jonny Depp fans will certainly appreciate the film since the film literally exudes their essence.  Considering the competition of this summer's films I am sure that this film will do well.  So enjoy this one I don't think this one will be the classic that the 1971 version was but it is still a decent film.
summary: Bizarre yet Decent Remake of Wonka
