reviewText: I can only imagine what the meeting at Warner Bros. looked like when they first devised plans to do this atrocious (and not to mention blasphemous) remake of the classic 1970s children's film Willy Wonka & The Chocolate Factory.Studio Head:  Remakes are the thing now, gentlemen.  They're the only things making money at the box office nowadays.  We should make one.  Any suggestions?Flunky #1:  How about Porky's?Studio Head:  Nah, too raunchy.  R-rated comedies rarely do well.Flunky #2:  What about Bambi?Studio Head:  Too nice and cheery.  A family flick needs to have some bite to it in order to work in these times.  Just look at The Incredibles and Shrek.  Besides, the Mouse owns the rights. (looks at Flunky #3, who is eating a candy bar)  what do you think we should do, Jennings?Flunky #3:  Mmmm... this candy bar sure is tasty!  The milk chocolate is divine!Studio Head:  Wait a second... chocolate... how about we remake Willy Wonka?  It's not too cheery and there are lots of colorful sets.  Audiences will be mesmerized.Flunky #1:  Do you really think a musical would work in this day and age?Studio Head:  Nah, but who cares?  We can eighty-six the musical numbers.Flunky #2:  But wouldn't purists complain?Studio Head:  Okay, okay, we can leave one or two in, but none of that crap from the original.  We'll write some of our own stuff.  (turns to Pickles the Monkey)  Are you up to writing a song or two for the Wonka remake, Pickles?Pickles:  EEEEK!  EEEEEEEK!Flunky #3:  How about the star?  Surely, we can't hire Gene Wilder.  He's too old.Studio Head:  You're right, Jennings.  He's also not young or pleasing to the eye.  Box office death.Flunky #1:  I know of someone perfect!  (pulls out cell phone and dials)  Hello, Tom Green?  We were wondering if you'd like to play Willy Wonka in our new-what?  You think doing a remake is stupid?  (hangs up phone)Studio Head:  We don't need him anyway.  Say, give me that rolodex, Jennings.  It's time we pick our players the old-fashioned way-in a game of rolodex roulette!Flunky #3:  Ah, yes, isn't this how you cast War of the Worlds?  (hands his boss the rolodex)Studio Head:  (opens rolodex, spins it and points blindly)  Okay, Tim Burton.  I guess he can direct the film... and... (repeats his previous auctions) Johnny Depp!  Warthington, get on the phone to Mr. Depp!Flunky #1:  (dials his cell phone)  Hello, Johnny?  It's Warner Bros.  We're wondering if you'd like to star in our new remake of Willy Wonka?  What?  You'd love to!  Excellent!  But what?  You want to make a few changes?Studio Head:  That's fine, that's fine.  He's Johnny Depp, for crying out loud.  (looks up at his 21 Jump Street poster)  I LOVE HIM SO!Flunky #1:  No songs?  Well, we already nixed the songs, John.  No likable characters?  Okay, that's fine, too.  It works for all of Reese Witherspoon's movies.  And you want your Wonka to be creepy, pasty-faced and almost pedophilic, like Michael Jackson?Studio Head:  A ripped from the headlines Wonka, just like the Law & Order franchise on television!  My God, the man is a GENIUS!  (slams his fist on the table)  It's a deal!  The world will LOVE the new Wonka!The rest, as they say, ladies and gentlemen, is history.

reviewText: The 2005 version of the classic children's book is much closer to the original than most people (having grown up with Gene Wilder) might care to realize. Yet, this story about the mysterious candy maker does indulge in some liberties of its own.In addition to updated special effects, it attempted to explain why Willy Wonka ended up the way he did.Willy Wonka (Depp) was himself an unfortunate child at one point. He grew up with a sinister dentist father and never quite forgot the experience. Even when he became famous and rich, Wonka remembered where he came from. This gives him something to empathize with. The film honestly could have flown without this subplot being tucked in, but because it (again owning to Burton's direction more than anything) did not distract from the overall storyline, the inclusion is tolerable.The Wonka in this film is a gothic metrosexual type. Frankly when I looked at him, I first thought of Marilyn Manson or another shock rocker. While I usually only see remakes of classic films (regardless of how accurate the originals themselves really were) only because there is nothing else to do, the idea of seeing 'Marilyn Manson' give spoiled brats (who, yes, are especially mean in this film) their just deserts was something which I could not miss. Sure enough, it provided me with a tasty summer treat.Ed Wood did a marvelous job with this film, understanding Dahl's original work. Because Dahl's work was never meant to be 'family friendly' these two are the perfect combination for each otherIt's so easy these days for studios to attempt substituting flashy graphics and other special effects for any semblance of plot, but the special effect innovations in this film were used sparingly.  Even the computer-replicated oompa loompas looked remarkably real and were not just thrown in for the sake of it. Plus, they've got some new songs.
summary: Bittersweet tale is a yummy confection

reviewText: I have watched the old Charlie and the Chocolate a few times and I do enjoy it for it is a very imaginative and interesting story. Upon hearing a remake I was intrigued to see how well Depp could fill into the role Gene Wilder seemed to master. Definitely he did. I'm not surprised though because Depp always picks the riskiest of roles. While most actors only take a role or two that is a risk for their career, Depp takes them all the time in bold confidence and that is why he is one awesome actor. He is certainly worth watching in this film from his haircut to his humorous, quirky personality. Honestly though Depp makes you laugh in this film and he makes the Wonka role very believable as the eccentric he is. The others, the parents and the children actually played their roles well so I don't know what other reviewers are talking about- but indeed Willy Wonka was the one you always paid the most attention to.Now if you compare the two films, the older and this new version, there are differences you should know of. Now I don't really want to give away anything but there are differences you're going to point out but honestly they do not affect the story from its true storyline. Matter of fact, this film fills in a few gaps that the older version failed to give out, such as Wonka's past. This story is still very powerful and still very creative as the old one and worth the watch. Depp is someone certainly that needs to be watched- he is a natural when it comes to roles as these.If you want to watch a colorful, creative, and humorous film, this is the one to watch. I highly recommend it. Although I still think the older one is just a little better still (I give the older version a 4.5 and this a 4) I still find this a very good remake and again, definitely worth seeing.

reviewText: **1/2Tim Burton, normally one of the most innovative and inspired of modern American filmmakers, comes a cropper with "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory," a cold and crass adaptation of the beloved children's story by Roald Dahl.  This is actually the second filming of the work, the first being the charming and delightful 1971 film renamed "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" to give Gene Wilder the title role.In this remake, Johnny Depp takes on the part of the famed chocolate manufacturer who decides to open up his factory to the first five children who find a gold ticket in one of his bars.  Charlie is the sweet-tempered young boy who is the fifth to do so, and, thus, gets to take the tour along with four other obnoxious brats who have none of the purity of spirit he does."Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" fails to make us care about either the situation or the characters.  Depp plays Wonka like a bizarre cross between Michael Jackson and Carol Burnett, and Burton, even with all his attention to detail in the sets and special effects, is unable to distract is from the fact that not a whole lot is really going on in the film.  The early scenes, involving Charlie's eccentric relatives and their attempts to secure the ticket for him, have a warm, familial feel to them, but once the tour itself begins, we become as imprisoned in the claustrophobic setting as the characters themselves.Locked in a tedious monotony, the plot essentially consists of Wonka, the children, and their respective parents moving from room to room where each of the four brats meets up with his or her well-deserved comeuppance in the form of a bizarre factory accident, until only sweet little Charlie is left.  Interspersed throughout are a series of inane song-and-dance sequences a la Busby Berkeley and uninteresting and undramatic flashbacks to Wonka's deprived and unhappy childhood that are somehow supposed to explain why he has become the creepy character we find at the center of the story.The art direction and set decoration are fine but not impressive enough to make us overlook the dullness and unpleasantness of so much of the film.  Mr. Burton may need to go back to making the kind of small, quirky films that he cut his directorial teeth on and leave these empty, bloated big screen extravaganzas to others.

reviewText: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory hit me very hot and cold. First, the look (which Burton excels) was very close to how I pictured it in my head when it was first read to me. The casting was absolutely flawless, especially the excellent acting of Freddie Highmore as Charlie--an asset to any movie. All the kids reflected the various deadly sins of pride, greed, arrogance and gluttony with great humor.On the negative side, the extreme departures from the book were glaring. You can take license so far and then it becomes another Hollywood hack job. If Burton would have removed all the Oompa song and dances (which will date the film in a year) and added more book elements, he really would have had a movie. Willie never had issues with his parents, nor was he suppose to be so much in need of therapy. My wife and I previewed this movie and are not sure if it is appropriate for our kids.I think Burton should have just come up with some other movie instead of using Willie Wonka and the Chocolate factory as a backdrop for something young kids really should not watch.

reviewText: This one captures the magic of Dahl's book perfectly.  Any kid would love the imagery. The original "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" has plenty of imagination, but there are moments where it gets overly tedious. For instance, it took way too long to get into the factory itself. Then there were the unnecessary musical interludes ("Cheer Up Charly"? Puh-lease.)In this new iteration, however, you will notice that they get to the factory as soon as possible. There are not even any songs until they finally arrive at the door of the factory. This helps further differentiate the imaginative, fantastical air of the factory from the monotonous drudgery of the "real world". When we first watched it in the theater (I went with my brother, his wife and their [then] two daughters) my brother admitted that he was so surprised that they didn't have a long unnecessary song in the scene where Grandpa Joe gets out of bed for the first time in years. The scene played out better for that simple omission.Don't get me wrong, I thoroughly enjoy the Gene Wilder version, but this one has a charm and energy that is simply frenetic, while the other one got a bit too caught up in justifying certain aspects of the story-telling.Wonderful movie. Imaginative and colorful. Even the elements that were added to the story (i.e. Willy Wonka's relationship with his father) have a very Roald Dahl feel to them.

reviewText: Instead of the pastel cotton-candy delight that was the 1971 -Willy Wonka-, this version opts for the more bittersweet charms of a more realistic story & Roald Dahl's original Oompa-loompa songs.Johnny Depp inhabits the darker clothes of Tim Buron's/Roald Dalh's candymaker.  Unlike Gene Wilder, whose Wonka was a conniving [what else do you call his 'slugworth ploy' & short temper] kid-seeker, Depp's Wonka has a real reason for confectionary perfection.  Christopher Lee is superb as a sadistic dentist who doesn't understand his kid.  The other 4 Golden Ticket winners are stickily nasty, Charlie's family *feels* poor - none of this Lil'-Orphan-Annie sacccharine 'poorness' but real, grinding poverty w/the attendant low self-esteem - & there's a sinister  feel to Wonka's factory.Deep Roy works well as the Oompa-loompas [all of them], masterfully 'creating' the personalities of half-a-dozen individuals.  & there's real chemistry between Depp & Freddie Highmore [courtesy -Finding Neverland-, where Fredddie was Peter to Depp's Barrie], which translates to Wonka's 'falling' for the gentle Charlie, after his [Wonka's] original antipathy to both kids & parents [again, not surprising considering Wonka's years-long isolation from people].Finally - thank the goddess! - there's an actual *ending* to his 1!  I kept waiting, thru the sweet strains of Leslie Bricusse's tunes, to learn the fate of Charlie's family, but they seem to have vanished into the same dark hole as every1 else but Charlie, Wonka, & Grampa Joe.  Here, we learn their fate - & Charlie seems the more reasonable & responsible for his choice - leading into resolution w/them *&* Wonka.  A superb film.

reviewText: "Charlie and Chocolate Factory" is a  expensive, creepy  film. It's perverse on a level kids may not get but does transmit to adults, who might wonder what director Tim Burton, and star Johnny Depp as Willy Wonka, are getting at, exactly. It's dark, episodic and surprisingly unfunny, aiming for that demographic that enjoy watching episodes of "Maury" where the bad kids get sent to boot camp to get humiliated and browbeaten.True, the book by Roald Dahl is not exactly a lark: Five children are invited to the reclusive Willy Wonka's massive confection factory after finding golden tickets inside their candy bar wrappers and four of them are ironically punished for their various bad habits.  One impoverished Charlie Bucket (Freddie Highmore) is polite and reserved during his visit, and thus rewarded for being the kind of child Dahl preferred: The saint.Played by Highmore as a nice, shy boy, Charlie finds his golden ticket in the third Wonka chocolate bar he buys; he takes his Grandpa Joe (David Kelly in a diminished, useless role) to Wonka's factory just down the road. He's joined by lard German Augustus Gloop (Philip Wiegratz), spoiled English aristocrat Veruca Salt (Julia Winter) and two competitive American punks, Violet Biodegrade (AnnaSophia Robb) and Mike Teevee (Jordan Fry). Gloop is a glutton, and the rest are grabby and annoying. But none of them know what to make of Willy Wonka, played by Depp as if he were channeling...someone very strange.Is it Michael Jackson? Vogue editor Anna Wintour? Jude Law's character in "Artificial Intelligence?" A John Malkovich villain? It's mannered and organic - clearly Depp had to rewrite some of this material toward his characterization - and a rallying point for the bad kids.  These brats don't much like anyone, but they have reason to suspect and loathe Willy.So when Gloop, Mike, Veruca, Violet get theirs in Burton's vision, their calamities are presented straight away while a bemused, detached, fey Depp looks on in his bob haircut. Burton also cloned one actor (Deep Roy) through CGI for all the Oompa Loompas, whose primary function is to perform dance numbers closely parroting 1970s songs most kids wouldn't know, the lyrics of which zoom by with such speed you don't know what the Oompas are singing about anyway.Burton never really brackets these numbers, or many of the scenes in "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory." The movie just unfurls, unaware of its own rhythm, unwilling to comment on anything except Willy's childhood (one of those classic Burton deals of a father isolating his son) that doesn't begin to explain Depp's behavior. He's Willy Weirdo, not Wonka, and that the movie made a pile of dough is not a tribute to its quality but marketing and a lack of audience taste.

reviewText: I was really excited to see this movie, but I was somewhat unimpressed with it after the movie.  I spent the time watching it, and when I think back to remember specific scenes, nothing stood out in my mind.  About 30 minutes into the movie, I thought about turning it off because it just seemed so slow...  Plus, I feel like there were flashes of Tim Burton in the first part, but he didn't put his touch on the movie in the beginning when it really needed it.I thought Johnny Depp was great.  He is a versatile actor, and this really proved it.  His facial movements and curt responses were hilarious, and he had the perfect perky/sinister combination that one would expect of a second generation mad scientist (behind Gene Wilder).  He basically carried this film...I agree with a previous review that the Oompa Loompas really didn't do it for me.  I didn't like that they used the one guy and that they looked so computer generated.  In the first version of the movie, the Oompa Loompas were a little creepy and added to the sinister undertones.  I remember being a little scared of them when I was little.  Now with their pop interludes that were somewhat difficult to understand, I was just kind of put off...Like I said earlier, I was excited to see this movie, but was wholly unimpressed after watching it.  It is difficult to separate the two movies in one's mind so as not to compare them, but if you're going to remake a childhood classic movie it had better be good, and this didn't live up to its predecessor.

reviewText: If you're a fan of Roald Dahl's book, this movie is definitely for you. Unlike it's very good predecessor starring Gene Wilder, this one stays closer to the book and doesn't add new storylines. Gone from the Wilder movie is the fizzy lifting drink scene. The golden eggs from the older movie are replaced by squirrels and nuts, as stated in the book. Still missing in action, however, is the chapter "Square Candies that Look Round". The other four children also have two parents go with them to the factory in the book.What is missing in the adaptation is made up for by Johnny Depp and the rest of the cast. If you are a Depp fan this one should be at the top of the list (right there with Pirates). The Oompa Loompas are all done by the same guy through some advanced special effects. While the popular "oompa loompa" song is missing from this version, the oompa loompas sing the old lyrics that are printed in the book.Tim Burton's influence is also worth it. While it does add a bit of darkness to the story (which you won't find in the Wilder version) it does make the film very impressive.Special effects are excellent. The movie is also family friendly and doesn't have the sex or f-bombs that many modern movies have. I recommend this to anyone, especially fans of the book and Johnny Depp.

reviewText: Tim Burton offers the most charmingly off-beat yet visually sumptuous movies in Hollywood.  From his stop-animation work ("The Corpse Bride") to dark romances ("Edward Scissorhands") to horror ("Sleepy Hollow"), Burton never fails to offer feasts for the eyes that manage to make you squirm just a bit uncomfortably - all the right notes are there, but some are played just off-key enough to create the thrill of tension.Perhaps no other director was so suited to film Roald Dahl's most famous work, "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory," and remain true to the author's vision.  Most people associate the tamer, goofy "Willie Wonka and the Chocolate Factory," starring Gene Wilder, with Dahl's tale, but forget that Dahl had a healthy streak of Lemony Snicket sensibility to him.  So it is perfect that Burton makes a darker, more dangerous film for all to enjoy.The visuals in "Charlie" are astounding.  The chocolate waterfall and river look like actual liquid chocolate (not the icky brown water of "Willie Wonka"), and the squirrel-nut-sorting room is a classic of mind-blowing set design.  And that is not all - oh, no, that is not all!Possibly the most visually stunning element in "Charlie" is Willie Wonka himself, played by Burton favorite Johnny Depp.  Depp sinks so deep into his roles that he becomes one with them, and one wonders what inspired Depp's quirky, nervous, mean-spirited, selfish concoction.  Depp plays Wonka as tight as he plays Jack Sparrow loose, and he never misses a note. But whereas Gene Wilder's Willie Wonka was more genial puppetmaster, Depp's Wonka has a sadistic streak in him, perhaps instilled by his dentist father.  This is a great, if much-maligned, performance.The most infamous element from the first movie was the seemingly-drug-inspired presence of the Oompa-Loompas, Wonka's army of diminutive henchmen.  In the Wilder film, the Oompa-Loompas were dwarfs given to sophomoric dance numbers to the irritatingly catchy "oompa-loompa-do-be-de-do" tune.  In this version, all the Oompa-Loompas are played by the same character (even though there are hundreds of them), and their dance numbers are even more fantastic.  However, the songs don't have quite the same sharp punch as the original songs, which pointed out the various failings of the kids and their parents as they got eliminated from the contest. Indeed, there are several lyrics that I just couldn't catch in this film version, and that is a pretty major quibble.Far from a feel-good movie, but definitely a good movie, "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" deserves to be seen and, for fans of artistic visions, studied.
summary: Amazing visual effects and solid acting make up for second-rate sound

The squirrels are scary for kids though.I'm definitely getting this one when it comes on DVD.And Grampa Joe?  Well, he's still a ratbag industrial spy.

reviewText: I was always a large fan of the Gene Wilder version over the yeras, since I was a child, and I knew that any "remake" would have to work *hard* to earn my admiration and respect.  Not to mention I'd always had very little respect for Tim Burton and I'd never seen Johnny Depp.So when I settled into the theatre to watch this movie, I was both astonished and very, very pleased.  Generally this version stays closer to the original book than the first movie, and Charile just stays an ordinary little boy having an extraordinary adventure.  Depp as Wonka evoked many powerful emotions in me--the character hates children, dislikes being touched, and uses outdated slang, but is very passionate for his candy and, coupled with the flashback bits, there's a hint of deep sadness in him.  I loved how the movie was resolved; however that resolution involves a Wonka backstory that was in neither the book nor the first movie.  Still, I think it fits perfectly.I would reccommend this movie to most, except for very young children.  Some of the demise of the 'Ticket Winners' in this movie may frighten a very young child under, say, six.

reviewText: Charlie and the Chocolate FactoryWilly Wonka's (Johnny Depp) plan to spruce up his chocolate business is to plant five golden tickets randomly in his Wonka bars inviting the holders to a tour of his factory. For poor Charlie Bucket (Freddie Highmore, "Finding Neverland"), chances for a ticket are slim, but luck is on his side; joining spoiled Veruca Salt (Julia Winter), competitive Violent Beauregard (Annasophia Robb), perpetually consuming Augustus Gloop (Philip Wiegratz), and violent Mike Teavee (Jordon Fry), Charlie meets Wonka, the reclusive, eccentric fellow behind the delights of his factory. As the tour commences, weird things start happening to the selfish, misbehaving children, leaving Charlie alone to deal with Wonka's bizarre behavior, and to try to help him out.If not exactly a classic film, Mel Stuart's 1971 fantasy creation, "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" has stood the test of time with its tender realization of childhood sugar fantasies and morbid, goofball humor. With Gene Wilder at the helm of the considerable steerage of oddities, this loose Roald Dahl adaptation has aged as a major 1970s peculiarity, yet, at the same time, remained wonderful. Over 30 years later, noted quirkmeister Tim Burton has taken up the challenge to bring the book (with the true "Charlie" title) to the screen again, and he's out to reclaim the cinema version for himself.Immediately, comparing the two productions becomes a fruitless quest. The Stuart film was made in an era of musicals, practical effects, and gee-whiz kid acting. Burton's film exists in a more cynical time, with a more sarcastic filmmaker. Opening with Danny Elfman's familiar scoring backing the creation, by cold steel machines, of the Wonka bars, the tone is clearly set: this is no candy shop, and the candy man can't. Burton has more in store for his audience than simple sweets and soft-shoe.With a rapturous and meticulous production design, a tongue firmly placed in cheek, and the appearance of Christopher Lee as Willy's dentist dad, this is a Burton film through and through. That being established, "Charlie" is a chilly affair, more concerned with technical prowess than heart or plot. For the most part, this change in focus is fine, for Burton's take on Willy's chocolate factory is a marvel, packed with infinite candy rooms, singing, dancing, cocoa-bean worshiping Oompa Loompas (all played by movie MVP, Deep Roy, "The Neverending Story"), and legitimate danger. While a lot of the film is sweetened with CGI, Burton still palms the primal magic of Wonka's wonderland with his extensive visuals, and the depth and life he gives the factory is almost perfect.Almost perfect can also be said of Johnny Depp, who steps out of the mile-long shadow of Gene Wilder to fashion his own twisted take on Willy. Since the aim for "Charlie" isn't pointed at the heart, Depp's Wonka is a strange fellow who hates parents, is easily annoyed by children, and appears to be a germaphobe. Not exactly the winking teddy bear Wilder went after in his legendary performance, but Depp's oddball acting fits heavenly with Burton's vision, and the two team up yet again for another rousing, wildly original collaboration.However, with Depp and the computer effects taking the lead, poor little Charlie isn't left with much to do. Freddie Highmore is an inspired choice for the unlikely Golden Ticket winner, and his English puppy dog demeanor does the film a world of good in the emotion department. But Burton keeps Charlie at arm's length for the entire film, along with the other kid actors (who aren't nearly as interesting or natural as Highmore), leaving unfair comparisons to the stellar child acting work in the original incarnation to dance through the head.Tim Burton's "Charlie" corrects many mistakes from the Stuart film (the Oompas aren't creepily orange and green anymore, and Burton has mercifully done away with the infamously bizarre, psychedelic boat trip sequence), along with raising the epic visual stakes for the more visionary angles of the story that needed it. Burton has created a genuinely fun movie for the family, blessed with a zippy running time, and those tired of the Wilder warmth for this often ominous tale will rejoice over this new icy stab at detailing Wonka's outrageous tour.

The cinematography of the entire movie was on target and reminded me somewhat of the Lemony Snickets movie in that respect. The movie had comedy throughout, and was one of the best remakes I have ever watched.

reviewText: Visually, this film is wonderful, and it has many fine moments, right up until the very end.In the novel and in the original film, Wonka sees and appreciates Charlie's  good  heart and his love of family.  When Charlie wins, he excitedly invites both Charlie and his  family to live with him, no questions asked.The whole point of the original novel and movie is to show Charlie's big heartedness.True to form, Burton throws in his own dark,  twisted touch; he gets hung up on the idea of Wonka as a socially maladjusted wierdo.  In Burton's vision, Wonka can't comprehend Charlie's love of family.The story isn't supposed to be about Wonka, but about Charlie's big heart.
summary: Marred by Burton's Obsession With Psychology

reviewText: I hate to compare remakes to the originals, because oftentimes they should be able to stand on their own merits and are worlds apart from their counterparts.  As is the case here.Tim Burton's remake of Ronald Dante's bestselling children's novel is very much a Tim Burton film.  Dark, dramatic and with a lot of hidden meanings for the adults.  And this, I think, is the first problem with this film.  The original version was light and funny.  Silly, sure.  But it never seemed dark, even in its most serious, retrospective moments.  It was a child's fantasy and despite the now-cheesy nature of Willy Wonka's chocolate factory, the cheese quotient just seemed to work.  Of course we knew those candies were blown up beach balls and the choco-river was brown colored water, but we wanted to believe in the fairy tale and so we did.Mr. Burton's version is definitely much more spectacular with the special effects.  But somehow they just don't translate into a fluffy child's fantasy.The second problem, and a much larger problem, is the casting of Johnny Depp as Willy Wonka.  I think Johnny Depp is a tremendously talented actor and he was perfect as Edward Scissorhands.  He brought depth and emotion to a troubled and dark character.  But he was terribly miscast as Willy Wonka.  He played Wonka as a flat out oddity, he of deathly pale skin and pageboy hair cut.  His effeminate voice and pure glee in the discomfort and almost destruction of some of the children is disturbing at best, and borders on cruelty.  Whereas Gene Wilder played Willy Wonka as an eccentric but loveable fellow, Depp's Wonka belongs on a therapist's couch.  Whereas you could laugh at Wilder's Wonka or believe that he truly loved making candy, you just have to wonder how Depp's Wonka could have made it successfuly as a business man.Add to the mix the background story of Wonka's childhood and his dentist father, from whom he is alienated . . . well, do we really care?  Isn't the story about Charlie and his wish fulfilled?  Rather, this version seems to be about Tim Burton and his wish to remake a child's classic as far from the original as possible.The children bring bright spots to the otherwise heavy film.  They are splendid little actors and perfectly cast.  As in the original, the parents have little to do, other than stand by while their children are taught lessons.The Oompa Loompas also make a return appearance, although the songs here, rather than being silly little ditties, are geared almost toward music videos.All in all, I would steer clear of this one and pull out the 1971 version.

reviewText: I went into Charlie and the Chocolate Factory with high expectations. Comparisons to the Gene Wilder original aside, Burton had promised a darker movie that was truer to Roald Dahl's classic book. With modern special effects, that sounded like something to experience.The good news is that if you've read the novel, this flick does incorporate many of the elements that the 70s version left out. You get your Indian Prince story, a much grander boat ride down the river of chocolate, and the infamous scene in the nut room. Charlie's father is also back in the story now, and has his job in the toothpaste factory.But then the flick takes some odd turns of its own. The Oompa-Loompa songs use the original lyrics from the novel, but take off in a very garish direction that's neither good nor bad, just...bizzare. Johnny Depp, for all the critical acclaim he's had playing eccentric characters, feels rather forced here. He's distinctive and amusing, but I can't help but feel Gene Wilder was closer to what Dahl envisioned. Finally, the movie tacks on a very sappy subplot about Wonka's dentist father and his parental issues. For all that Burton said about making this movie darker, these parts felt as sugary as the happy ending in the original.I like the Burton version, but oddly enough I still find the 70s original to be a truer interpretation of the whimsical and discomforting world Dahl created. The best effort would probably be a mix of both, and it might be worth another remake 20 more years down the road to see that happen. This deluxe version has some okay extras, but not enough to justify the price tag difference if you see the bare-bones one significantly cheaper. Fans will want both versions for comparisons, families are probably better off investing in the 70s version and saving this one for a rental.

reviewText: Of that Wonka bar! Holla, my peepenheimers - I finally gave into my curiousity and watched the new "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" directed by the highly overrated Tim Burton and the almost equally overrated Johnny Depp.  PUH-LEASE!!Look, I will not disguise my absolute unabashedly love for the original classic masterpieceWilly Wonka & the Chocolate Factory (Widescreen Special Edition). Gene Wilder is pure genious as Mr. Wonka, in a performance that simply cannot be repeated, bettered, or even equalled.  Depp was foolishly ill-prepared to try.  Whereas Wilder invested a truly menacing, disturbing side to Wonka, Depp makes him simply 'kinda weird'.  Thumbs (and gobstoppers) down to him.Much is always celebrated about Tim Burton's visual and overall atmosphere created in his movies.  Yeah, he is a capable visual stylist.  But it matters very little when he doesn't do anything else right!  I'm not saying he never has (I lovedFrankenweenie). But more often enough he just comes across like a dork.I liked Deep Roy as the Oompa-Loompa's (and he was also the film's narrator).  But I thought the new Charlie was too goody-goody and he embarrassed his grandpa.  After his Grandpa was happy about being able to go to the factory, Charlie was all "Oh but I should sell the ticket to help the family" and made his Grandpa look like a big jerk.  There is a limit to how "helpful" a child should be.  Talk about a killjoy.  The actor playing the Grandpa is utterly delightful!  Best performance in the film.I didn't like the kids as much as in the original. I don't mean the young actors themselves, heavens no. I think Burton gave them one direction, something along the lines of: "Oh, you've all seen the original movie, right? Cool, just act like that."  I don't blame them.  Some of them talented, especially Anna Sofia Robb who shined inBecause of Winn-Dixie.  But I don't know why they used a digital fake for Agustus Gloop instead of a real boy!
summary: Give me a break, give me break, break me off a piece
Title: N/A

reviewText: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Tim Burton's make on the book by Roald Dahl and his remake of the 1971 classic: "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory."Johnny Depp plays Willy Wonka, a strange man who lives in a factory that makes lots of candy.  Some of it is strange candy at that (an everlasting Gobstopper and a piece of gum that holds breakfast, lunch and dinner).  Well, Wonka has decided to put Golden Tickets in his bars, five in total.  Five lucky children will be able to tour Wonka's factory.  Charlie, a poor boy who can't really afford any chocolate bars, stumbles onto the Golden Ticket after having a third bar.The other children who got these bars: A husky gentleman named Agustus Gloop, a rich snob named Veruca Salt, a champian named Violette and a boy who loves science named Mike Taevee.The movie isn't bad.  It's fairly good.  Johnny Depp makes a good Willy Wonka, but you can't replace Gene Wilder.  Johnny Depp is only good because he's good at playing strange characters, and Tim Burton often makes strange and dark films (films we love, no doubt).  Gene Wilder will always be Willy Wonka in my eyes.The look of the film is incredible!  Well, to put it simple, it's an update to the 1970's version.  Some parts look abosolutely stunning.  The special effects are top notch, and the Oompa Loompa's are pretty cool (considering only one person played all of 'em).  The songs the Oompa Loompa's sing are very good and very well choreographed.  They're NOT better than the songs in the original.  The original was more interactive and more riddle like.  This one is just here to be upbeat and "keep up with the times".However, the problem with this film is simple: It's virtually the same thing we saw in the 1970's version.  Some words of dialogue are almost exactly the same (Violet's monologue when she finds her golden ticket is word-for-word the same).  Everything that happens to the kids when they're "bad" is the same.  The only difference is that we get to see the kids afterwards, unlike the 1971 original.The changes in the story (which weren't a lot, but some were big) can sometimes be pleasant.  I didn't much care for Wonka's past, but they threw it in this film, and it made the ending a bit... stranger.  I was pleased that we saw what happened to the kids as well.  Wonka, is totally different than what he was in the original, and in the book.  Courtesy of Johnny Depp.  In the original he was a lonely guy but was testing to see if the kids would steal his greatest invention, the everlasting Gobstopper.  In this, there's no real test to see who should keep his factory.  It's all based on who the last kid left is (the one Wonka will say is the "Least rotten").It's a good film.  The look Tim Burton gives it is nothing short of brilliant.  The children who visit his factory are forgettable, except for maybe Charlie who manages to be BETTER than the original Charlie (although I was disappointed that the song "I got a golden ticket" didn't play when he got it).There are funny moments, some you'll die of laughter.  Johnny Depp delivers the character of Wonka very well, but as I stated before: Gene Wilder WAS Willy Wonka.  Filling Wilder's shoes is hard, and not even Johnny Depp (who after Pirates of the Caribbean seems to be the guy to get for your "strange" people) could surpass him.Before I close I will say one other thing.  The music is perhaps one of the best musical scores I've ever heard in a movie before.  Most Tim Burton films have excellent music, and this is no exception.  Each track goes along quite well with the situation.  The opening theme is the best one!Will fans of the original like it?  More than not.  Some will abosolutely hate it!  If you loved the original for it's characters and such: you probably won't like this one.  But if you enjoyed it for the story... it's nothing new, virtually it's the exact same as the original with an extended ending and update in it's look to make it more "modern".I'd say the original is better, but this one is just as good.  The characters (with the exception of Charlie) aren't really anything to write home about, but overall this is a good film.
summary: Fans of the Original will be pleased

reviewText: The next movie I am going to review, is one that I had wanted to see in the movie theatres, but a member of a movie club, that my family (not me) is in, the movie was picked as a surpise, I didn't even think it would have been picked. And so I was ditched, by my family, but I knew that I had to see it on dvd.The first movie was called Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, this one is called Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, which is more appriotaly titled, since Charlie is the main character. The first 35 minutes I feel were rushed, because by that point they were in line at the factory, in the older version, it was about a hour before that happened, and there were all these musical numbers that took some time. The first movie ran 1 hour and 40 minutes, this movie runs 1 hour and 55 minutes. As the movie begins, we meet the hero of this story Charlie Bucket (Freddie Highmore) who lives with his Mom (Helena Bonham Carter) and Dad (Noah Taylor), and his grandparents Grandpa Joe (David Kelly) , Grandma Georgina (Liz Smith) , Grandma Josephine (Eileen Essell) , and Grandpa George (David Morris). And that leads Willy Wonka to annouce that he is closing his Chocolate Factory, and he looks the gate, and all the workers inclduing Grandpa Joe out of a job. reviewText: From the opening scenes of "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory," I expected to see Michael Keaton in the batsuit pop out at any moment. For, make no mistake, Tim Burton's adaptation of Roald Dahl's classic novel, is very "Burton-esque." The crazy visuals and wacky characters abound. Depp's performance is kinda rediculous, though there are moments where he's funny. The kids, however, are very good. They are the star of the film, in my opinion. Freddie Highmore gives the best performance of the film as Charlie, and his portrayal of the character is the only thing that is better than "Willie Wonka," as he doesn't whine and complain like Peter Ostrum.The funniest scene in the movie is the TV-Room. If you, like me, are a fan of "2001: A Space Odyssey," then you'll be dying lauging at this part.Despite Burton's freaky visual style and Depp's ludicrous performance, kids and parents will find much to appreciate in this film. But I still recommend "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" over this one.Movie/DVD Grade: B

reviewText: Tim Burton may be a visionary genius but he isn't a renaissance man. He should have had more collaborators.The first Willy Wonka is a work of great originality and beauty with music and presentation that is warm and hopeful.  Burton's feels a like a clunky model of a film.  For example, the grandfather lacked warmth.. Depp's Wonka is a bit creepy despite his considerable charm, and the film's tribute to imaginative childhood delight feels muted and unfocused.The film does have Burton's dreamlike aura of fable which is always enjoyable, but it seemed to lack impact and direction.  The weird little Oompa-Loompas were curious, but unlike in 1972 they weren't wise or all-knowing. Here nobody is especially wise - Wonka is an eccentric oddball.. so instead of a delivery of wisdom from Wonka to Charlie it's really the opposite, with Charlie giving direction to a drifting and immature Wonka.Charlie Bucket again shines as someone who makes the humanist choice for his family over a potential sellout for wealth, but it's less clear than the sublot in the older version.Moreover since Charlie was noble at the beginning of the film already, his virtue was never in question, and without Charlie's inner struggle and transformation the movie really had less to say.  Willy Wonka transforms instead.  He loves his father and reconnects to his family..that's nice..  It's a different theme for a different film.  It may be more true to Dahl's book, but I prefer the other version.Oh well. Hopefully the older film will be adapted to make a run on Broadway and Burton will recognize his limitations and let others carry the ball for his next project.It's worth noting: Little Veruca Salt will soon be a child star.
summary: Genius in the distance - Not in the foreground.

reviewText: Anybody who grew up with Charlie and the Chocolate Factory probably has images of what tht world looked like. For the most part, director Tim Burton sticks to the formula, but I can't imagine anyone ever thought that Willie Wonka, owner of the factory, ever looked like James Dean, the young Marlon Brando, Steve McQueen, Ryan O'Neal, Michael J. Fox, or... Johnny Depp. So Burton gets Depp to work his usual magic, i.e. model a character after a well-known character from popular culture - it had worked in the Keith Richard-inspired Jack Sparrow character from Pirates of the Carribean, so for Tim Burton why not deconstruct.... Michael Jackson! And so, added into the story are all sorts of clumsy flashbacks to Willie's childhood, and allow Willie to reconcile with his father (Christopher Lee, harkening back to Burton's treatment of Edward Scissorhands and another icon from old horror films, Vincent Price - hey, Burton and Depp aren't creative geniuses, they're self-plagiarizers!). None of this was in the book as I recall, where Willie Wonka was wacky, self-confident, and a little dangerous. In fact, I seem to remember the mean kids being disposed of permanently, quite sinister. The highlight of the film, besides Charlie himself and his unfortunate family, are the Oompa Loompas, played by a single actor. Nice touch, Tim. But if it had been me, I might have cast Kirk Douglas as Willie Wonka.

reviewText: What this movie has in computerized special effects, it loses in character development, wit, humor, musical performance, and joy. In other words, it is another Tim Burton remake of a 70s flick ("Planet of the Apes" should be considered a crime against humanity). Let's hope that in another 30 years, a better director comes along who is able to capture the frivolity of the original film, especially with its heavyhanded moralizing. Johnny Depp is forgettable in this movie as Willy Wonka, and all his lines fall flat. This movie has no laughs. Don't bother with it.

reviewText: Okay, the first thing you have to consider is that this is the trio of Johnny Depp, Helena Bonham-Carter, and Tim Burton. reviewText: from Tim Burton. The original will have nothing to worry about, as this film isn't within 50 miles of it. Lacking memorable songs, heartwarming characters, and other candies besides chocolate, this remake falls flat on its face.I preferred Gene Wilder's warm-hearted and child-wise Wonka to Depp's deeply disturbed chocolate prodigy. In the original, there was more respect and affection between Willy and Charlie.  In the new version, the relationship seemed more superficial, needing Charlie to get Willy out of his shell. Why should a child have that responsibility?Also, I am sick of issues of origin in movies. Why is Willy Wonka the way he is? Why not leave it up to the viewer's sweet imagination? We don't need flashbacks of Willy's terrorized childhood victimization by Christopher Lee. Chalk a couple of those scenes up to a bad dream instead.While Tim Burton is a talented, original, and imaginative director, he needs to put more substance behind his stories and characters. They come across as one-dimensional and jokey. He needs to balance his gothic leanings with some true-to-life realism. Why not have a boring, white-bread, average Joe who has a soft side for lizards and turtles? How about a wrong- side-of-the-tracks guy clad in black leather, who, just may be guilty of sacrificing children to his favorite Aztec god?I love outsider and misfit flicks just as much as the next goth, but, once in a while, let's mix it up a bit. Be unpredictable and realistic. Put some flesh behind those Count Chocula cartoon cut-outs.

reviewText: As I'm sure you have heard before, this is not a remake.  True, a movie was made in the past with the great Gene Wilder, but this movie hearkens more truthfully to the children's novel.  It pulls a much darker tone and mood from the sugary 1970s version.  And I think Tim Burton did a great job creating a different version that is in no way connected to the "original movie" (though I do think that this one is much much better).Burton and Depp are back at it, pulling out incredibly strange and creative visions from the depths of their minds.  For Burton, the landscapes take the best of his movies and stand as genius in terms of presentation.  Once we get to see inside the Chocolate Factory, we are with Charlie at once amazed and excited.  Imagine actually seeing rivers of chocolate.  It brings back childhood memories where our imaginations were huge and not limited by the harsh realities of life.  Burton is incredibly adept at tapping into this inner-child to create images that as adults we might scoff at or think strange.  Most people fall into two camps in relation to Burton:  he's either incredibly weird or incredibly brilliant.  I fall into the latter category and applaud his rich visual style, especially in this movie.Then there's Depp, the actor who has once again created a unique character.  Depp's man-child Wonka will, for good or bad, remind people of yet another man-child in our society.  On the surface, we have Wonka who creates candies for children, allows 5 of them to enter his "Neverland" of chocolate, and yet has an apparent sour core.  He has a clear distaste for children and seems to take glee in the various ways they are kicked from his factory.  It's lucky that he allows a parental figure to go with each of the 5 children.  Yet his character who has this apparent disdain for children, also has a huge heart.  And it is through Charlie that Wonka will finally show his heart and face his own fears.The music is also, of course, fantastic.  Danny Elfman proves once again that he is a strong composer of exciting and different music.  He has been getting a name for himself recently, what with his continual work with Tim Burton but also in doing music for Spiderman 1 and 2.  His music, however, always works best in my opinion with Burton's style and here it helps accentuate it.Your eyes will not be bored.  Many splendors are seen in the 2 hour block.  From the great Oompa-Loompas who no longer annoy me(and are played by one actor who is digitally duplicated), to the great Glass Elevator and the aforementioned rivers of chocolate, to even the slight homage to Stanley Kubrick's opus 2001, the movie is a visual delight.  It is also pretty faithful to the novel.  Overall, this story was great when I read it as a child and it's nice to see it pretty faithfully interpreted in a movie.  It will delight children of all ages.  A must see.

reviewText: Tim Burton is original and creative, there's no denying. Johnny Depp is daring and talented, no doubt. So, putting the two together would seem like a reasonable idea. And to start off with, it usually is. I felt that Willie Wonka was similar to Edward Scissorhands in that the first twenty minutes are wonderful, and you're sure you're gonna love it, and then suddenlly, as if they sensed your unwanted approval, the infamous duo reels off into a land all their own, generating laughs from some and bewildered head shakes from many more. I think this film could have been much better if Burton had stuck with the mood of the beggining and if Depp had been given a bit more amusing dialogue/action. But Depp's fiesty, almost sinister, portrayal did amuse in several moments and Burton's larger-than-live, colorful directing is fun to watch. I also liked how they slyly implied their other collaborations(when Depp is cutting the tape with scissors in the air, the skulls on the candy, etc.) If weird isn't your flavor, avoid. If a touch of the bizzare makes you grin, go for it. All in all I think Burton's Chocolate is an aquired taste.
summary: Clever to Bizzare... the regular Burton/Depp dish

reviewText: Anyone that's read my Wonka review knows I'm a fan of that movie. Unless you have no sense of humor, take any critique literally, and are immediately offended that is. Being a fan of Wonka, I was made physically ill to find that it had been remade. Remakes are a certain trend in Hollywood made possible by the fact that Hollywood is: 1. Concerned only about money, 2. unwilling to take chances, and 3. now lacking in any talent. I approached the Wonka remake with the same disgust that I have for The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, the Hills have Eyes, and the same way I would approach the remake of Gone with the Wind and Casablanca.We begin this movie with a CG opening because Hollywood is also now obsessed with computer animation. Mainly because it takes out all the work that real animation requires and gives jobs to untalented computer nerds who couldn't draw themselves out of a paper bag.We are then introduced to this film's Charlie Bucket. While the original Charlie was a good looking young chap that was probably pretty cool in real life, this Charlie is a ghastly, mouse-like, gangly, nerd in training, who, in real life, will only know the touch of women who want to "Make it with that kid from the Wonka movie." Upon seeing the interior of Charlie's house I get the inclination that this may not just be a remake of the previous Wonka, but downright plagiarism!Just as things are getting started, we're interrupted with some lame story about Wonka building a chocolate Taj Mahal for some Indian prince. Not only is this story long winded and silly, but it quite frankly is racist. It portrays Indians negatively as dullards that don't realize the chocolate will melt. It makes fun of their culture by a drip of chocolate falling on the prince's forehead, as if it were a tika mark. It then shows melting statues of Ganish and Shiva. Thanks for making fun of Hinduism Tim Burton. This story is but one section of a long flashback sequence, unnecessarily narrated by Grandpa. I could bring up the fact that good movies show instead of tell, but what would be the point?The first act drags on as it shows Wonka bars being shipped all over the world. Why? Everyone that got a ticket was a white European or American. Maybe next time Wonka should avoid putting all the winning bars in the same box.The first winner, of course, is Augustus Gloop. Unlike the original Gloop, this one cannot act, and neither can his parents. This scene is painful to watch. It shows him eating a chocolate bar for a full minute while he reads off some cue card for the voice over. "I...am...eating a chocolate bar...and...I taste something...that does not...taste familiar."The next winner, Veruca Salt, suffers even more so than Gloop. She is gangly, has a horrible put-upon smile, and fails to be the slightest bit intimidating. Her idea of being pushy is yelling, politely, "Where's my golden ticket? I want my golden ticket," certainly a far-cry from the original. (pardon the pun.)Winner #3 is Violet Beauregard, now a violent, bobbed tomboy. She says she gave up gum to find the golden ticket but then immediately claims she's been chewing the same piece of gum for three months. I guess her vice is lying? Winner #4 is Mike Teevee, who's vice, you'd think would be watching too much TV. In this version, it's kid of unclear. I guess he plays too many violent video games.Charlie of course gets the final Golden Ticket, but unlike the original film, Charlie gets the ticket in a candy bar he buys for himself. In the original the ticket was found in the bar he bought for his grandfather, therefore a good deed was rewarded.When the big day comes the kids enter the factory where they are greeted by some stupid singing automatons. Their song is long, uninspired, banal, nasally, and just plain annoying. Then Wonka shows up, unlike Gene Wilder's Wonka, Depp looks like Elton John on a bad day. Wonka's wit, along with the other forced humor in this film is atrociously unfunny, especially when juxtaposed with its original forbearer. Not to mention this newly-lisping Wonka is kind of scary, he's like the Michael Jackson of the candy world if you think of it. I assume they cut the scene where Wonka invites the children to spend the night. He even tells the kids that he's "eatable." This is just sick, Burton.The story is once again interrupted by some 5 minute story about how Wonka found the Oompa Loompas. Once again, the story is highly racist. It involves the Loompas being a jungle people that, "are good workers," and worship cocoa beans.The demise of each of these children is much more horrific and realistic than in the original. While you could chuckle at them before, can you laugh at these kids as they moan and scream in agony? I hope not. Likewise, while the people in the original movie had their faults, they were still likable. There's no redeeming factor in any of them this time, they all come across as axxholes that go around criticizing one another.During Veruca's scene when she tries to take one of Wonka's squirrels he exclaims, "Little girl, don't touch that squirrel's nuts, it'll make him crazy!" I'm not joking, he really says this, maybe Burton forgot he was making a kids movie, or perhaps he's just a moron that could care less about exposing children to sexual metaphors. Go to HeII, Burton. Soon a pack of rabid squirrels fall upon Veruca and attacks her. They gruesomely bite at her in what looks like a scene from Willard, or one of Richard Gear's fantasies, take your pick.Long story short: I wish; this thing just drags on and on. They tack on like an extra 20 minutes after the movie is supposed to be over! And there is this new, stupid, ridiculous ending that ruins the entire meaning and moral of the original. There is no reason to watch this film, trust me. Why eat imitation chocolate when you can have the real thing?

reviewText: There is something intrinsically magical about Roald Dahl's book "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory". The story of Charlie Bucket, a little boy who lives with his dirt poor family in a shack near the famous Wonka Chocolate Factory, Charlie is lucky enough to win one of five golden tickets offered by Willy Wonka for a one-time visit to tour his amazing factory. Each of the other four children is the very embodiment of a problem common to young people; Augustus Gloop is a greedy kid who eats all the candy and chocolate he can get his hands on, Veruca Salt is a spoiled brat who gets everything she wants, Violet Beauregard is a little know-it-all who simply has to be best and Mike Teavee is obsessed with all things television. And then there is Charlie. Charlie is so poor that he doesn't want anything that he doesn't already have, and all he has is the love of his family. Arriving at the factory, the five children and their parents, meet Willy Wonka, the eccentric, strange chocolatier, and their lives will be changed forever.That we all know from the book, which I will venture to put forth, may be the best children's book of all time.Previously made into a film in 1971, "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" stars Gene Wilder as the strange man who lives in a large factory populated by pygmies. The film is well - remembered for its fanciful, day glow renderings of the interior of Wonka's factory, Wilder's tour de force performance and the other elements faithfully recreated from the book.Tim Burton's new film, "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory", starring Johnny Depp as Wonka and Freddie Highmore as Charlie (both in "Finding Neverland") will also be remembered for it's fanciful, vivid renderings of the interior of Wonka's factory, Depp's tour de force performance (for both good and bad) and all of the other elements faithfully recreated from the book.They sound similar, don't they? Yes. I wouldn't classify "Willy Wonka" as a classic, it's more of a cult classic. And Burton's version is very good, but not great. The major improvement between the two is the improved production design.Depp's performance is good. Wonka is a strange guy and Depp seems to be channeling the spirit of Michael Jackson for the role, which is actually more than a little fitting. Both characters were deprived of a childhood and now spend every moment of their adult lives trying to recapture it. I wonder if Jackson will consider the performance a compliment or an insult. Like Michael Jackson isn't going to see the film?Wonka's bobbed hair, porcelain face which never seems to age and odd clothing give him a slightly effeminate look. Depp uses this as the first step in recreating the role. As Wonka, Depp imbues the character with a childlike sensibility and vocal pattern. As he speaks with his five invited guests, he seems most comfortable when they are acting like children. This also means that he is most comfortable around Charlie, because Charlie hasn't had had the influences the other kids have had. When they aren't acting like kids, he becomes bratty, belligerent and confused.Freddie Highmore is the real standout of the film. He seems to completely get the character of Charlie; despite the odds of finding one of five golden tickets, throughout the world, he still holds out hope. Even as glimmers of hope cross his face, we also see that he realizes the odds are pretty great. All of this is conveyed just through his facial expressions.The other four children are purposely one-dimensional and meant to convey four of the bad traits children can develop if left unchecked. All are portrayed well and serve to make the characters funny and amusing.Charlie's family is the counterpoint to the bad children's parents. Living in a one -room shack that appears it will blow over, the family subsists on a diet of cabbage soup but the important thing is that they have each other's love, which helps them get through. Mom (Helena Bonham Carter, with a dental prosthetic) and Dad (Noah Taylor) care for their parents, all four of which spend every day in one bed. Grandpa Joe (David Kelly) and the other three grandparents provide Charlie with the love and support he needs. All of this helps Charlie become a pretty fantastic kid. He uses the bad toothpaste caps his father brings home from the toothpaste factory to create a replica of Wonka's factory, keeping the dream alive.Once we enter the factory, Burton recreates the journey with vivid colors and designs. The main room they enter, with the chocolate river, is surprisingly similar to the same set in the first film. The addition of more advanced special effects adds another layer to the setting, but really, they are the same.There are a few differences between the two versions. In "Charlie", Burton and screenwriter John August ("Big Fish") have added a back-story for Wonka. This is an interesting and well done touch. Through a series of memories, we see Wonka's childhood with his father (Christopher Lee), a dentist. These moments retain the fable like quality of the book, helping them seem fully integrated, but they also serve to slow down the story. Later, through stories and further memories, we learn about other points in Wonka's life. For instance, how he met the Oompa Loompas (all are played by Deep Roy). These are equally intriguing and well-done. They also seem a little more generic to the story.But are these additions enough to warrant a new film? Not really. "Charlie" is well-made, interesting, and the back story adds another element of depth, but nothing new is done with the core story. For a director with such a vivid imagination, it is disappointing that Burton didn't take it further. Ultimately, "Charlie" seems like a stop gap for Burton, until the next big idea hits him."Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is a very good film, and one of the better films out there for you to take the kids to, but it is ultimately an unnecessary film.
summary: 3 1/2 Stars - Faithful Remake - To The 1971 Film

reviewText: I wasn't sure if I wanted to see this movie at all when it first came to the theaters. The commercials for it didn't really 'do it' for me, and as much as I love Johnny Depp, I didn't think he'd be a big enough draw for me either. So, I waited until it was on dvd when my sister bought it, and we watched it.I ended up liking the movie more than I thought I would. However, in many respects, I still prefer the old version, maybe because it's what I grew up watching, so it holds a special place for me.This new version parallels the old in many respects, and then of course, it doesn't. It's very obviously a Tim Burton movie. Anyone familiar with his work would notice that right from the onset. This version has oompa loompa songs, but they aren't anything like in the old version, except for the particular kid being sung about. These songs were just ok and aren't songs that would stick in your mind, like the older songs did.Instead of the scene with the golden geese, there are squirrels. I wasn't too keen on that part. It was a little creepy to see a ton of squirrels all over the place, and especially creepy when they carried someone off. I don't mind squirrels as a general rule, but that many all together was strange.Also in this version, you learn more about Willy Wonka as a child, and get a glimpse into how he turned out to be such an odd character. His father was a dentist. Well, what better way to rot children's teeth than to start your own candy empire? So, that's what Wonka did, in antithesis of his father's life's work.There are certainly more differences in this version, but those are the few that stood out for me the most. As far as Wonka's go, Johnny Depp's version didn't annoy me as much as I thought he would, and was in fact kind of funny. But, I still prefer Gene Wilder's interpretation. He was just the right blend of an eccentric, slightly mad, smart aleck who still managed to be loveable in spite of being a nut.

reviewText: This film was captivating from the get-go. The stark visualization of the Wonka town and Charlie's meager surroundings was outstanding. Charlie's lopsided little house bespoke his poverty, yet also accurately represented his close-knit, but delightfully off-kilter family.One of the best parts of the movie was the characterization of Charlie and his relationship with his grandfather. Charlie's poor, but caring family contrasts sharply with Willy's childhood with his father.  As mentioned in a previous review, Johnny Depp DOES look like he is channeling Michael Jackson.  It is almost eerie. However, he makes an effective Willy Wonka and the scenes of his early life with his father, the dentist, certainly explain his eccentric behavior.  The other children (and their parents) give adequate performances... enough so that you are glad that they "get what's coming to them."The 2-Disc Deluxe Edition looks as if it has ample extras and I would certainly recommend this set to anyone who likes the book or the movie.

reviewText: Ok, right off the bat.... I loved the Gene Wilder one. Who the heck couldn't like that movie? I had heard a lot of grumblings about the new movie, how people were stunned at how different it was from the original. After seeing it though, I can say this is a much better movie than the original. First, it is much closer to the book (which was the original source material for the first movie) in content and "feel". Second, while Gene Wilder was AWESOME in the first one, Johnny Depp plays an amazing and complicated Willy Wonka (Depp has to be one of the greatest actors of our generation, even though I am no fan of his personal opinions). While I have heard people complain that this Willy Wonka is a weirdo, folks, THATS THE WHOLE POINT. He's SUPPOSED to be! It makes perfect sense in the story. BRILLIANT acting by Depp.Lets move on to the Oompa Loompas. I have heard complaints that its all the same guy and the songs suck. I totally disagree. While the original Oompas were cool as hell, these Oompas are just as great, and I think the 'look-alike' aspect of theses Oompas added a lot to the whole movie. The dancing choreography was pretty great too. The songs DO NOT suck, they actually are quite entertaining, its just that people love the originals so much they don't give the new ones a fair shake. I thoroughly enjoyed the song and dance sequences.My final thoughts are on Tim Burton. I never really got why people like him, as most of his movies are REALLY BAD. Edward Scissorhands was good, but most of his others aren't. I can say that this movie is Burton's best of all. He does quite a good job with the direction, and even his signature dark and quirky sets work wonderfully in this one.This movie doesn't replace the original, it actually goes hand-in-hand with it. They are companion pieces, different takes on the same source material. Unless you are hopelessly addicted to syrupy sweet fantasy, give the new movie a try.
summary: I LOVED the first movie...This one is BETTER!!!

reviewText: Weird, creepy and strange. It was exactly these words that came into my mind after watching `Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.' Yes, I know, this is a Tim Burton film, in which being weird means quirky type of charms, but for all its considerable merits, I was not charmed by the film.You don't need the long summery of the story. In short, good boy Charlie Bucket and other four bad kids are invited to the magical factory of one Willy Wonka. For bad kids only, the factory turns a horrible place, where they must learn a lesson in a fairly terrifying way. Rather cruel edge of the original remains in the film, and that part actually is the point of the film, when the preachy moral is told in a well-rehearsed musical style. You may hate this, but still can find it more tolerable than Depp and his acting, which, unlike `Finding Neverland,' would not bring him another Oscar nomination.Too bad, but it's true. The acting of Johnny Depp, and the unnecessary subplot about Mr. Wonka are the worst part of the film. The unfortunate comparison with Michael Jackson is understandable if you just watch him. Even if the avid fans of Depp can ignore the uncanny resemblance between Jackson and Depp wearing sunglasses, they would certainly admit that his acting here is misguided, always - yes, always - relying on curious mannerism. He is constantly weird, and to make matters much worse, seems not conscious of what he is doing.To remedy the alarming amount of weirdness, Tim Burton added the father-son relation between Wonka and his father, stern dentist played his favorite actor Christopher Lee. That only makes the whole story unnecessarily longer and more sentimental. After so much of Depp's bizarre acting, it is too late for anyone to correct the image of the eccentric factory owner, and make him look more like a human. Better acting would do.Ironically, the film is much better when it doesn't show Wonka in it. The house of the Buckets, slanted in a crazy way, shows what Tim Burton can do with better and level-headed judgment, and the entire household is charmingly described. David Kelly provides a delightful portrait of a wise old man in the family, with a little bit of craziness hidden in his eyes.For all its wonderful designs and good Danny Elfman score, I couldn't help thinking about this. As many have already pointed out about this film, Depp's Wonka repeatedly betrays his dislike of being addressed to by the children while he can talk pretty normally (though drily) with adults. So why should he invite these kids to the factory? Or why should all the kids dream about going to his factory in the first place? I talked about weird things about the film - Michael Jackson theory and so on - but this is the weirdest part of the film, which I am still trying to figure out.
summary: Very Weird (Especially Depp's Acting) And Too Weird For Its Own Good

reviewText: When WILLY WONKA AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY was released in 1971, Ronald Dahl, the author who wrote the original story, was horrified. The filmmakers had taken Dahl's script (based on his own story) and butchered it to pieces under the writing revisions of David Seltzer. In fact, Dahl was so upset that he never allowed the studio to make a planned sequel that was to be loosely based upon CHARLIE AND THE GLASS ELEVATOR.  Fast forward a little over 30 years to a Hollywood that has lost all creative juices and is in a makeover frenzy. Warner Brothers hasn't had very many family hits in awhile and family films are bringing in more moolah than ever before.  So, why not remake CHARLIE? Kids who grew up with the original are full of nostalgia now and will see it with their own children. Put Tim Burton at the helm to direct because he's the only director who's crazy enough to get the okay from the Dahl estate and you've got an instant success on your hands.CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY is a quite different movie from WILLY WONKA AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY. Just look at the title of the two films for starters. Whereas WILLY was drenched in this fairy-tale optimism detached from reality (and from much of Dahl's original story), CHARLIE is full of the dark humor characteristic of everyday life (and of Dahl's original story).The plot of the film is rather familiar.  World-renown, but never-seen candy-maker, Willy Wonka makes it known that he is going to open his factory to 5 lucky children who can find a Golden Ticket. Through some coincidences (or Providence), Charlie Bucket finds one of the tickets. He and his grandpa and the other 4 children and their adult guardians are given a tour of Willy Wonka's wonderful factory. But one by one, the children fall to the vices they are most prey.  Until only Charlie is left. As the last child remaining, Charlie wins a very special prize, but one that comes with a price that Charlie isn't worth paying. But in the end, it all turns out fine.Johnny Depp is amazing as Wonka. His portrayal is quite different from Gene Wilder's, but full of the suspect-sinister that Dahl's story version contains.  Freddie Highmore portrays Charlie and this youngster has Oscar written all over him; one shouldn't be surprised if he takes an Award by the time he's 15 (Haley Joel Osmont hasn't got a thing on Highmore).  The other actors do a fine job, though I especially enjoyed Miss Pyle portraying Mrs. Beauregarde--she brings the character to life, making her a woman to die for. Other performance of note is that of Deep Roy. This little Indian portrays all of the Oompa Loompas and despite CGI effects, actually portrayed each one of the 150+ tiny humans (he also received a nice million dollar salary for his work).Musically, this version of the story is quite different than the 1971.  The songs include Dahl's original lyrics and each song is written in a different genre of music, from pop to rock to reggae to country. Instead of the repetition that the 1971's songs, this approach provides a different tone and thus signifying a different lesson for each of the incidents they follow.Overall, CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY is a delightful romp through imagination. The youngest of viewers might be frightened by some of the images (but like the original fairy tales, they should be) and fans of the 1971 movie might be prejudiced by the new take. However, this version of Ronald Dahl's story is closer to the source and spirit of the original story and for that, I think it's a tad bit better.

reviewText: Having seen "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" when it first aired on television, I enjoyed the music and the sets were great. But it wasn't the book. After seeing Burton's version of "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory", I realized he actually understands the book. This version is very close to Dahl's. The big change is in how Willy Wonka is presented. Willy Wonka in the book does really strange things (they become stranger in "Charlie and the Great Glass Elevator") with seemingly no motivation, but Burton softened him by giving him an unbending father that sort of explains his actions. Johnny Depp captured Wonka's eccentricities perfectly. Freddie Highmore as Charlie was very good.I love how the music incorporated the poems Dahl wrote for each of the "naughty" children, and the dark tone of the music itself. The movie opening credits was fantastic. Although the special effects were fantastic, they never overwhelmed the story, but gave it more of that fairytale feel. The Oompa-Loompas were funny and a little scary at times. Burton got it that Dahl's books can be dark and frightening because children are thrown into some truly horrific and surrealistic situations, but in the end the kids always adapt and triumph.The Two-Disc Deluxe Edition is wonderful with really good Special Features. I absolutely loved the featurette on Roald Dahl's life that had footage of him, his books and his family. I also have a great appreciation of Deep Roy who played all of the Oompa-Loompas after seeing what he had to do!Another really good movie adaptation of a Dahl book is Danny DeVito's "Matilda"Matilda (Special Edition)This is my favorite movie adaptation of "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory".
summary: Tim Burton Understands Dahl's Book, Great Movie

reviewText: What more can I say about this movie than the title of my review?FORGET THE ORIGINAL. This version is one that I'm sure Roald Dahl would be proud of. And FORGET all the stupid people who are saying that Johnny Depp is just like Michael Jackson in this film, because it is just NOT TRUE.Depp is an absolutely fabulous actor, with more talent than he can cope with. His portrayal of the wacky Willy Wonka (alliteration rules!) is perfect. And though he is known to look a little strange in this film, it just accentuates how good-looking he is. So no more Jacko comparisons please....Freddy Highmore I would say is not an extremely good Charlie Bucket, as I found his performance a little wooden. However, this is side-lined by the other performances. Depp's is obviously the stand-out one, with every line delivered with perfection, and each line basically a fantastically funny one-liner. But Violet Beauregarde is extremely enjoyable to watch, with her over-competitiveness and hard-core attitude. Veruca Salt is as rude, snobbish and bossy as she is supposed to be, and Agustus Gloop is amusing to watch (who would have known it would be a German boy to play him? ^_^) The movie in itself is extremely funny to watch; I laughed both times that I went to see it!And the Oompa Loompa's are fantastic, accompanied by the wonderous song arrangements by Danny Elfman, one of the best movie soundtrack composers ever to walk this earth (see "The Nightmare Before Christmas" and "The Simpsons" theme tune fore proof).In conclusion, this is one of the best children's movies you could EVER watch, and should be bought as soon as possible.

reviewText: All this movie does is cause you at every scene to recall the superiority of the original.Johnny Depp is NOT FUNNY, or cute. or mysterious, or charming, just creepily weird, and absolutely not in any kind of enjoyable way.  Gene Wilder played the part with requisite weirdness, but it was like a starry-eyed mad scientist poet that was at once bequiling and enchanting.This is Michael Jackson weird, this is I-can't-imagine-a-parent-turning-their-back-for-a-second-when-he's-near-your-child weird.  He plays Wonka like a jaded preteen outcast aspiring homosexual who is mildly autistic. Quite unpleasant and NOT FUNNY.  If you found this to be funny you may be succumbing to some kind of group pressure, and you may want to check to see if your one of those people who always turn to make eyecontact after a 'funny part' for confirmation.First Mistake: remaking an incredible movie.Second Mistake: Tim Burton?! He is WRONG WRONG choiceThird Mistake: Casting, from top to bottom, every character pales in comparison to their forerunner.1 stars for the kid with the ridiculous braces.Actually the DVD messed up about 2/3 through, and I was kind of relieved that I could get some credit back at Hollywood Video and I didn't have to finish it.
summary: Never let Tim Burton and Johnny Depp get together again...PLEASE!
