reviewText: Everyone says this, but I gotta say it too: loved the original and the book. It was wonderful to see things from the book in the film, like the squirrels, musical numbers, and even little things like having charlie's father actually alive.But to me, the big thing that could make or break the movie was the casting of Wonka, and there are dozens of actors I would have chosen over Depp, and it is painfully obvious that this was just an excuse to cash in on depp's popularity. FOR GOD'S SAKE, ITS LIKE HE'S A STRANGER IN HIS OWN FACTORY! It's like he was visiting there for the first time, and just happened to the be the tourist of the group carrying the map, wandering around aimlessly.Neither Depp nor Wilder hit the character right on, but Wilder had that spring in his step, that twinkle in his eye that showed that he knew what was going on, and was in control at all times. The kids were horrendous compared to the eccentric, wonderfully terrible brats of the original. Charlie wasn't bad, and I'm happy to say he was very well cast, and I enjoyed him.The badly placed backstory and inclusion of Christopher Lee (whom I love) was pointless, and changed the message of the story from "good things work out for those who are good" to "family is most important". WHICH DONT GET ME WRONG, IS A GOOD MESSAGE, but not what I wanted from a story I loved. It ruined the point of them being in the factory and everything, and only worked to make Depp more pedophile-like. As another reviewer said, Burton wanted to be more faithful to the source material? Well, way to add in an entirely usless subplot that changed the entire message, Tim!Visually, it was stunning, as all Burton films are, and the score was creepy and marvelous, brought to us once again by the peerless Danny Elfman. Depp lost his appeal to me a while ago, and this was just salt on the wound, to watch him try to tackle a role that I loved and cherished. I keep saying it, they should've had Mr. 'more cowbell' himself Christopher Walken. Come on! 'Willy Walken and the Chocolate Factory'! Think about it: "Children...Welcome...to my factory?"
summary: It all hinged on who played Wonka, and YIKES was it bad...

reviewText: It just occured to me that Willy Wonka could've been played by Mike Myers, had Johnny Depp not been Tim Burton's most used actors in his movies. I am not very fond of children's movies, but I had to check this out, because I think Depp is a brilliant character actor and I love Helena Bohem Carter. To my surprise, I actually enjoyed this movie more than I'd expected, and I must say that the set design and special effects are absolute eye-candy! The child actors all tried their best to steal scenes, but Freddie Highmore was most adorable and impressive. Deep Roy managed to stand out from the crowd as the multiple Oompa Lumpa. Helena was severely underused, and I am starting to think maybe she should stop doing this kind of mundane supporting roles, despite she's also Burton's favorite cast. Johnny Depp's bizarre and heavily madeup look is quite striking, even more striking than his roles in Pirates of the Caribbeans and Before Nightfalls. Yes, this is a fast-paced and delicious movie perfect for the whole family.

reviewText: Wow. This movie seems to go in all directions at once.First, there's the nominal kids' movie. Lots of color, no real violence, occasional and amusing bits of song, and a proper moral tone about the value of family, money, and good behavior. Then there's Willy Wonka's (Johnny Depp's) bizarre character, ambiguous in his liking for the kids he invites, and gleeful in the self-inflicted weirdness that four of the five children experience. For the grown-up dragged along, there are witty references to bunches of other movies, including Kubrick's 2001, Sweet Haven architecture from Robin Williams' "Popeye", Edward Scissorhands, 1930s-style song-and-dance movies, and I don't know what all else. There's a remarkable echo of the new Hitchhiker's Guide movie, in Wonka's glass elevator, but the release dates of the two movies make intentional reference unlikely. Of course, Tim Burton's mad gadgeteering needs an outlet, which appears in a frightening bit of orthodonture.Some bits may be a bit intense for skittish children, but the sense that "[s]he had it coming" generally outweighs any sense of threat. The Oompa Loompa's original diet is a high-grade gross-out, perfect for small boys (but maybe not their mothers).This isn't Disneyfied, sugary pap. It's a lot more interesting than that. It seems to address approachable complexity to young viewers, but still give adults material of interest, something I haven't seen in recent kids' flicks.The kids are optional, though. An adult can enjoy it too.//wiredweird

reviewText: This movie creeped me out and not in a good way. Johnny Depp is an awesome actor and I usually find him sexy but in THIS stinker I find him really creepy and gross. Maybe it's the Michael Jackson-ish look he has going on with the black wig and white face. Could they have picked a more horrible look for WW? He looked really feminine and mime-like. It looked like they took him to a costume store and put a 10$ wig and 5$ clown makeup on him! Depp's character had a really awkward and uncomfortable feel (done on purpose but not in a funny way) with bizzare, dead sounding dialogue. The musical numbers were not catchy and there was an odd lack of music through the rest of the movie giving it a really inhuman, unnatural ambiance. I also disliked the one guy playing all the oompa loompas, it looked really fake like a clone attack and did nothing to make the movie more watchable. I love Tim Burton's other movies but this one sucked BIGTIME! It gives a new perspective on Willy Wonka but this Willy is someone I would keep kids AWAY from. This movie is childish if you're an adult and pales compared to the original. If you're a little kid it's way too dark and scary and has 'humor' that is hard for most people young or old, to understand. I found myself asking, "Was that supposed to be funny?" on multiple occasions. The children (other than Charlie, who is underdeveloped) are really mean and bratty to the point of being unwatchable(as if we need more bad examples for kids!) Maybe I am biased because I loved the original Gene Wilder version. I would have been open to seeing a remake if it was GOOD but this movie was dissapointing. All the actors in this movie are very talented and it's a shame to see that something about this movie just didn't 'click'. This movie was not really about kids, or fun or candy, it was about Tim Burton falling in love with his own work and failing to realize how lame it was. Tim needs to stick with his own original stories (Corpse Bride for example, was great) and I think it shows a huge ego when someone tries to remake a classic movie like this! It's amazing how so much money and effort go into special effects and expensive sets and the script is hollow and lousy. The whole thing just had a creepy vibe with almost sadistic undertones. It has a very cold, lifeless feeling to it and had none of the warmth and joy of the original, almost like someone made a bad parody of WW. I didn't laugh, I didn't cry, I wasn't entertained in the least and I think this fails as a kids movie and as a grownup movie. The only reason I gave it 2 stars instead of 1 is because I love Depp and Burton, if you are not a fan of either, don't waste your time with this steaming pile of poo!

reviewText: This a borderline disgrace of the original Willy Wonka and The Chocolate Factory.  It's as if someone zapped the soul out of every character in this film.  Johnny Depp seemed like he was on vicodin or something.  One minute he was up, the next down.  His character went in and out of personalities.  Most of his jokes fell flat after their delivery, leaving the viewer with an uncomfortable CREEPY feeling.  His character of Willy Wonka was a cross between the church lady from Saturday Night Live and Jack from Will and Grace.  Does that tell you anything? Some of the dialogue was almost identical to the original, the only difference is they edited out all the wittiness that made the original so special.  All of the soul, intellect and attitude were missing from all of the characters portrayal's in this film.  There was an all across the board lack of emotion that resonated like a plague throughout the entire film. Some of the special affects were cute but even the sets seemed to lack the magical quality of the original Willy Wonka.  The musical numbers with the oompa loompas were surreal and did give a campy feel to the movie but overall this is a totally different movie than the original.  It's very difficult to compare the 2 of them but I will say the first one is heartfelt and magical.  Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is a sour imitation, a souless, dour, unfunny tragedy. A sign of the times of what kind of world we're living in now.
Title: N/A
